story:
For the past several years, I have been drifting around the world, photographing different places and cultures and writing about my experiences. This is how I earn my livelihood. You can find links to some of my travel stories on davidjoshuajennings.com

Yesterday morning I flew into Colombo, Sri Lanka, to spend one month traveling around, photographing and writing about the country. Unfortunately, shortly after I left the airport my camera bag, which contained all my camera equipment, my passport, my phone and my wallet with all my money and debit cards, was stolen while I was at the bus station in Colombo.

Thus I find myself marooned for 30 days in one of the most beautiful islands in the world, with little money and no camera, unable to do my work or even simply capture its beauty.

In an attempt to turn this negative experience into something positive, I thought I would use the theft as an impetus to create art. I would like to raise money for another camera, and then, inspired by contributors, dedicate the next two months of my travels to capturing high-quality artistic prints to send to them.

After 30 days in Sri Lanka, I will be flying to New York, then traveling via Greyhound to Chicago and Madison, then hitchhiking with a friend through South Dakota, Minnesota and Wyoming, down to Boulder, Colorado, and then onto Oklahoma. Along the way, if I raise enough for a new camera and traveling funds, I will be capturing images that I will post online to my website (along with around 100 or so of my photographs from the last few years). From these, contributors can choose whichever images they like, and I will mail them the print size according to their donation.

As a preview, here are some of the images I've taken during the previous few months of travel, all of which will be available (along with hundreds more) on my website after the funds have been raised. Contributors will also be added to the mailing list, where will I will post updates, stories and photographs from the journey that their contributions allowed me to continue.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this.

story:
Short Summary


Hi my name is Bryton Gore  creator of Creatures of Gore, the story srarts when I was left with more than a handful of clothes after my mother passed away,   After a rough couple of months and a good ol' bout  of insanity. I began to make stuff toys out of them, and posting them to Facebook,

 My friends started following the  idea, loving my designs, offering me money and gifting me recycled materials and buttons. All of  a sudden friends of friends took interest, and I started getting really quirky and odd request such as ; A flamboyant pirate bear, a pigeon with a peach body, and fancy cow. All of which had wonderfully sentimental stories behind why someone would order such a thing.

The beauty behind this is, we are unique, we are keeping the originality and love behind a fairly factory operated industry. Not every stuff toy is the same. Because of our niche we will probably never be a HUGE business.. but hey, being the diamond in the rough is kind of our thing. We want to be the Etsy.com shop you talk about, or the hidden market stall you bring your friends to see on the weekends. Out  of the way but still very much available to anyone who needs a bit of individuality in their life.



What We Need 


I've asked for the minimum amount of funding right now to pay  bulk amount of materiel to start a web shop ready to send orders. We will need postage materials, the flesh and blood of our little critters (stuffing and materiel) and basic small business and trading permits.



What You Get


Pledge $5 and over

Pledge $5 and receive a personal hand written thank you card

Pledge $10 and over

A $10 pledge will get you a miniature Creatures of gore stuffed one-off key ring made especially for you.

Pledge $25 and over

I usually sell my original toys at $50 each. pledge $25 and receive a one of a kind Creatures of Gore stuffed toy as a token of my gratitude.

Pledge: $50 and over
And receive your own custom designed Creature of Gore. Any thing your mind can come up with I'll make it for you, as a BIG thank you !

Pledge : 100,000

Scented Candle.

story:
Short Summary

I am an art student currently enrolled in the BFA program at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock as a painting major and holding a 4.0 GPA.

I am going to completely run out of money after paying my July rent/bills and luckily for YOU I have a stockpile of one-of-a-kind original artworks and time to make unique and personalized commissions in a variety of mediums!

What We Need & What You Get

I will realistically need to come up with about $1200 to keep the roof, the A/C going and food in the cupboard until my loans/grants/scholarships/work study funds come through in September.

Contributors can pick from a wide selection of price-points for original works or commissions in graphite, charcoal, chalk pastels, acrylic or oil paint.  Pick something I've done that you like, or I will make a picture of you, your baby, dog, a narwhal, late Stooges guitarist Ron Asheton, late Stooges guitarist Ron Asheton riding a narwhal... anything you like!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to help out financially, maybe you know someone who is in the market for what I've got, or if you use the Indiegogo share tools to put the word out for me either way that would be a fantastic thing that you did!

See my work at facebook.com/zahrnart or instagram user name @spencifer.

story:
Short Summary

A year ago I painted FOUR 8x4 feet paintings for my first art collection called "Vulnerable and In Love"! A transparent series painted with my finger tips expressing a transformation in my life. Last year I was asked to participate with a new artist showcase with Brick Lane Gallery in London but I turned it down because I wasn't sure how I was going to ship my work. This year I was asked to be apart of it again...but this time I'm moving in faith!

What Is Needed

The Brick Lane Gallery team organizes almost everything. For a successful exhibition, their professions team provides installation, set up and hanging, the preview evening, promotion and sales as well as staff for the duration of the exhibition; all this while taking 0% commission on sales. Their services have proven to be a very convenient and exciting opportunity for international artists and predominantly providing new possibilities for artists who are looking to broaden their artistic career and exhibition background. Because I'm not signed to the gallery there are still things that I must do in order to participate.

  • A portion of the money will go towards shipping Two of my 8x4 ft paintings overseas! They are extremely heavy and HUGE...they take extra special care to ship.
  • Fed Ex shipping is $700-1,100 for each piece depending on how  far in advance I can ship
  • A portion will go towards my ticket and a place to lay my head.
  • Currently prices are 1,300 for a round trip ticket
  • Hotel is ranging around 1,000 due to the long stay. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to give anything, but you can still help:

  • Your prayers are always appreciated!
  • Share this with friends and family
  • Encouragement and positivity

story:
Soaring above your everyday struggles, free like a bird. It's an idea we've all wished could come true in times of difficulty and stress. Now, fueled by your generous donations, Artists Melissa Schilling and Jamie Lloyd will be able to gift children in a disaster zone the ability to fly above their problems. Wings for Tacloban are imaginary art wings created by children for children. 
Follow us on the adventure: 

www.projecthopeart.org

instagram: Project HOPE Art

twitter: @projecthopeart

We look forward to providing you with updates, ideas and visuals of all our flying children.

Thank you for your support!!! We aim to be in Tacloban this May or June.

-Melissa & Jamie


The Wings

Project HOPE Art is an art collective that responds to disaster with pencils, paints, music and imagination.
We want to remind the children of Tacloban that they can overcome obstacles by gifting them the power to fly with wings.  These wings do not just live on the chalkboard or wall. These wings belong to them and will allow them to fly and rise up above their problems, environment and situations. They should use their wings not just to solve their own problems but those issues facing their communities at large.

Nothing can stop a large group of living angels.

See our Wings Art Project in Haiti, featured in School Arts Magazine: http://www.schoolartsdigital.com/i/141579/54

Why Wings?

It has been nearly three weeks since Typhoon Haiyan, the world's biggest-ever storm to make landfall, struck the central Philippines - killing more than 5,200 people, displacing 4.4 million and destroying $547m in crops and infrastructure.

In Leyte Province, 70 to 80 percent of the area was destroyed. Tacloban, the capital of Leyte, where five-metre waves flattened nearly everything in their path, suffered more loss of life than any other Philippine city. Outside the town centre, in a hillside cemetery, city workers have dug a mass gravesite which stretches along 100 metres.

Much of Tacloban has been turned to rubble, leaving many survivors homeless and dependent on aid. Philippine Energy Secretary Jericho Petilla said on November 14 that it may take six weeks before the first typhoon-hit towns get their electric power back.

Visiting the city, it is clear that - despite the help of the international community - it will take a very long time for the town to recover.

What We Need 

Money to coordinate on-the-ground logistics!

  • $1200 for two Instamatic Cameras and enough Film to gift each child a photo with their wings, a lasting memory
  • $600 to print many pairs of large wings and transport them around the world
  • $250 for paints, brushes and mixing containers for personalizing community wings

The Impact

Our Mission:
To inspire, heal and improve the quality of life for children in need through the creative process of art.

Our Values: 
Art is the universal language which transcends differences in cultural and customary barriers.
Art is a tool for education that encourages creative thinking, problem solving and growth.
Art gives a voice to the voiceless.
Art is good for the soul.

Our Actions:
Project HOPE Art uses art as a vehicle to inspire, to educate and to create intentional whimsy. We work with children in hospitals, orphanages, schools and communities in disaster stricken areas, utilizing art to help establish self esteem, self expression, self respect and stress relief for our students. We create art for art’s sake, while educating through our art, science, nutrition and literacy programs. We twirl in tutus and face paint because it’s good for the soul. Since our inception in January 2010 we have made multiple trips to Haiti and have recently launched a Visiting Artist Program, creating a sustainable way for artists in any medium to share their creativity with our kids and project partners as we strive towards our mission to inspire, heal and improve the quality of life for children in need.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate now, but still want to participate? 

  • We would love your help spreading the word about our project
  • We always accept art supply donations, contact Melissa@ProjectHOPEArt.org for more information

Thank You!

Since our inception in January 2010 we have made multiple trips to Haiti and have recently launched a Visiting Artist Program, creating a sustainable way for artists in any medium to share their creativity with our kids and project partners as we strive towards our mission to inspire, heal and improve the quality of life for children in need.Other Ways You Can HelpCan't donate now, but still want to participate? 
We would love your help spreading the word about our project

Thank You!

story:
The First Squares

My dad, Richard, was commissioned to reproduce a 20''X30'' poster, and he knew the easiest way to accurately render the poster would be to use the grid drawing system. It’s a tedious process, and after finishing the poster Richard wondered if he could improve the grid-drawing process by removing the need to draw and erase the grid.

Flash forward some days later and Richard is in his garage playing with an old painting frame. He gets the thought to weave a string grid across the frame.  A few prototypes later and Richard Hudson invents Grid Master, a draw-through, reusable, string grid.

Richard took Grid Master to our local Jerry's Artarama, and spoke with the store manager who then presented it to the Executive President of Jerry's Artarama, Ira Goldstein.  Mr. Goldstein liked Grid Master and its application, but there is nothing like it on the market. 

So we need your help to show that the world is ready for Grid Master. We'd love to see people's advocacy for the grid drawing technique, and we need enough money to send Grid Master to manufactures to meet a domestic and international demand.

With your help, everyone in the world can realize their artistic potential.


We Believe in Grid Master Because We Believe in Artists

We want to support artists and art programs near you and around the world.  Richard says, “It’s helped my drawing ability. It raised the level from not very good drawing to very good. I wouldn’t even have continued drawing because of my own self-critique. However, Grid Master keeps everything in proportion. Without it I would not have developed nearly as large a body of work as I have.”

My story is similar.  For many years I doubted my drawing ability because what I drew never seemed real enough, proportionate or accurately rendered. Eventually through perservering, I became decent at drawing. When my dad gave me my own Grid Master, I saw that a lot of the hesitancy diminished and my inner-critic quieted, and I too have started making so many more drawings.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wcRTqPv1mNE

We want people to believe in their own ability to draw, which is basic to art, an excellent and time-honored tool of self-expression.

Grid Master requires no electricity unlike light tables and projectors in order to replicate drawing. It runs on imagination.

By donating to this campaign, you bring Grid Master and the ideas this invention represents into reality. 


Risks & Challenges

We already have the support of manufacturing and marketing facilities through Jerry's Artarama. We just need your financial and thoughtful support to show that there is a market and a desire for Grid Master.

If we don't reach our entire goal, then that shows that there probably isn't that much of a market for Grid Master. We'll always love the arts, and we'll probably end up using Grid Master to make our own art and continue our contributions to the world in that way. 

However, there are at least 63 million hits on Google for searching “grid drawing”. Imagining a dollar for every hit, it’s easy to believe we’ll reach our goal!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, please, by word of mouth or social media: Everyone can draw!  Even if you can't monetarily support us, support the artists and the art community around you and the artist within you. Art will always be a part of Life, let's draw it together!

story:
Hi there! My name is Chris Hong and I'm an artist based in Canada. You may recognize my work from Instagram or YouTube and if so, thanks for stopping by!

I recently won a partial scholarship to IMC which stands for Illustration Master Class, and it's an intensive 7-day workshop held in Amherst, Massachusetts from June 11-17, taught by some of the industry's best. The partial scholarship takes $1000 off the $2685 USD tuition, which covers food and housing for the entire duration of the workshop (I will be covering the travelling costs to and from the workshop). With this campaign, I'm looking to cover the rest of the tuition ($1685 USD), and for your generous contributions I will share everything about my personal insights and experience in a dedicated IMC YouTube video, as well as offer some perks otherwise not available through other means! 

So why IMC? Here's a little backstory for context:

I went to school for animation, and afterwards I started my career at a television animation studio. I quickly realized working in animation, at least in the production stage, was not what I wanted. Looking to get back to what made me want to pursue art in the first place, I started laying down the stepping stones to slowly steer me away from animation and towards just creating art that made me happy, and somehow find a way to make a living with it. Late last year I left my animation job and became officially self-employed, which, is terrifying and I'm constantly wondering if I'm on the right track, and that's why I find IMC so compelling at this point in time. 

My main reasons for wanting to go to IMC is to learn more about the illustration/fine art and gallery world that I am less familiar with. I want to feed off of artists who are as equally driven and dedicated to honing their craft. Having worked from home since 2015, this kind of interaction with other artists and industry professionals is something I'm desperately yearning for. IMC really feels like something I need at this point in my career, to help push me forward. 

Thank you SO much for reading, and for making this possible! Stretch goals, potential new perks, and process images of the next Mermay piece to be released throughout the campaign, so please stay-tuned! :)

- Chris.

I want to feed off of artists who are as equally driven and dedicated to honing their craft. Having worked from home since 2015, this kind of interaction with other artists and industry professionals is something I'm desperately yearning for. IMC really feels like something I need at this point in my career, to help push me forward. Thank you SO much for reading, and for making this possible! Stretch goals, potential new perks, and process images of the next Mermay piece to be released throughout the campaign, so please stay-tuned! :)- Chris.

story:
WHO AM I?

My name is Natalia Esteve: I am a Mexican, London-based Post-Ritualistic artist whose practice illuminates the inherent concurrence between the undertaking of the Being-process as such and the finite impermanence of the Being that discerns and fathoms it. Through a series of embodied rituals I come to surface the experience of the embodiment of the disembodied state of Being in which we encounter the unconcealed SELF: Being as Being noBody. 

Undertaking the final year of my Post-Graduate Masters Degree at the Royal College of Art in London, I find myself facing comprehension of what it is that I embody as an individual in this brave, changing, beautiful world. Santuario Tabula Rasa is the space that I conceive as my uninterrupted, unedited truth. Santuario Tabula Rasa is the body of work that I have been fully immersed in for the past years of my life- this is the culmination that will be presented as part of my graduate Show at the Royal College of Art in London.

I believe that the space beyond the tangible, beyond the human, beyond the sensuous and beyond the apparent is the space of truth where we can all encounter ourselves beyond who we think we are.  This is what I call the space between the breaths, here is where Santuario Tabula Rasa births from. 

SANTUARIO TABULA RASA

Santuario Tabula Rasa is a space of total embodiment and therefore total disidentification. It is a place of no walls, a place of no place; of no words and no mind-made reductions of experience. The Sanctuary is the space between the breaths- Sanctuary in which we encounter the atavistic archetypal entanglement of the No-Self. It is somewhat ironic for me to use a composition of language to introduce the one thing which language is utterly unable to grasp and comprehend without it monstrously reducing it to something the human mind can comprehend and categorize for itself. Santuario Tabula Rasa lies within no existing category, it is of its own Self alone. The formless I am surfaces through the disturbances of no-space and mo-time which we encounter within the Sanctuary. 

 

ENCOUNTERING SANTUARIO TABULA RASA (MAY 2021)

With your help, I will be able to raise the funds to produce a live immersive experience and living archive (documentation film) of the Sanctuary. Allowing a space that embodies Dissolution and Disidentification to become a tangible meditative Sanctuary for the revelation of the authentic Being through its most raw, vulnerable, unidentified state of existence. 

The Sanctuary will be experienced as an immersive ritual that acts as an enabler for dialogues between the transcendent and the imminent life to concur. Through the unveiling of the Sanctuary we birth the Unconcealed Self- creating the opening of a world and allowing entities to unravel freely, as the things that they are beyond any preconception and contextualization. Being essentially facing itself beyond the question of what it is or is not, succumbing into no control and total embodiment.  

Santuario Tabula Rasa will be a live immersion ritual occuring at the beginning of May in London (official date to be confirmed as we are working with our current changing world). The Sanctuary will be live-streamed and a living archive (documentation) of the immersion will be produced and will live to have a life of it's own in film festivals in the upcoming year. 

This is an invitation into my world, my voice as a storyteller, and my intimate space of manifestation.

 

FUNDING

I have to begin by expressing that a big part of the production's funding and budget is coming from my own pocket, truly giving everything I have to what I believe in. I am also extremely grateful for the sponsors and collaborators that have not only believed in me but have believed in the voice of the project and would like to see it come to life. I am beyond grateful to say that most of the people that are a part of Santuario Tabula Rasa are here because they believe in the Sanctuary and what I am looking to express and formulate through and with it. 

Notwithstanding that I am an independent artist and there is still a gap between where I am and the financial means that I would need to create this ritual that I find substantial it be shared with the world. 

Funding will be used for:

  • Location
  • Materials for live casting 
  • Materials for production of displayed pieces 
  • Framing
  • Lighting Production/Light Engineer
  • Camera/Sound Equipment Rental 
  • Sound Installation/Sound Engineer  
  • Projection Prodeuction
  • Staff Catering 
  • Canvas (individuals to be traced) 
  • COVID-19 PCR Tests
  • Production Team Travel
  • Live Archive Production Fees

 

GOALS AND CHALLENGES 

I wanted to take a moment to thank you for any contributions or offerings you make on behalf of this project, they are instrumental for it to be able to become a living, breathing, organism. The Sanctuary aims to change the way we observe our experience of Being-in-the-world and how we come to understand the unanswerable, unexplainable, questions that veiled within the Self.

Not only as an artist but as a meditation and yoga practitioner I believe that things manifest how and when they need to, I also believe that we always find ourselves at the correct space and time to be able to create and manifest for a specific purpose. I believe that this Sanctuary is bigger than myself and that I can only become the vessel of its manifestation with your help. 

So that the Sanctuary can be authentic to its truth the set funding goal would have to be reached, though it is important for me to communicate that the Ritual will be produced regardless of whether the goal is met even if that means lowering production costs and working with the funds we have available at the time. 

It is my hope that my work will speak to itself.

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Above all else, I truly believe in the power of the collective energy of love, compassion, and gratitude; and I truly wish that funding were not necessary and that we could all create from a place of love and understanding towards one another and all beings in all times and spaces. Having said this financial help is only one of the many ways to aid my work. First and foremost take care of yourself, find peace within your breath and allow it to teach you the innate power of your authentic being. Secondly, if you find it in your heart, share about The Sanctuary and support the creation of this space through the power of language and conversation. 

Excerpts of the process and journey of Santuario Tabula Rasa can be seen and felt through my instagram @thespacebetweenthebreaths 

And website www.thespacebetweenthebreaths.com

story:
Above: Cover illustration for Family Style Zine.

“Family Style: An AAPI Food Anthology” is a 44-page anthology publication by Asian and Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) creators to share the lesser-known histories behind AAPI foods. Our diverse communities have created foods that serve as a record to reflect our resilience through long histories of colonialism and migration. We hope to connect our audience to the emotional and historical sides to these dishes through illustration and writings. Each illustration is accompanied by an abridged history on that dish that details its journey to what we are familiar with today. Through this collection of art and writing, we aim to serve up familiar dishes with their rich historical context to humanize our communities and deepen our relationships with food and each other.

Early February 2018, we put out a call reaching out to the greater AAPI communities in search of AAPI illustrators to interpret a dish and/or ingredient from their culture as a full-page illustration. We were so impressed by everyone’s pitches and was so grateful to have received just under 200 submissions.

We believe that this project is fuel for the soul in this age of racial and socioeconomic justice. Through artists’ interpretations of these dishes, we hope to visualize their significance and as an extension, the significance of ourselves and our people. We invite you to join us in cooking up a delicious and filling zine for our friends and communities.

 

Here is a list of the dishes that will be explored in this edition of Family Style Zine, as chosen by our artists:

  • Banchan 반 찬
  • Bánh mì
  • Bánh Xèo
  • Beef noodle soup 牛肉麵
  • Curry
  • Egg tart 蛋撻
  • Halo halo
  • Hong Kong milk tea 港式奶茶
  • Hot pot យ៉ាវហន
  • Jajangmyeon 자장면
  • Kalo
  • Kare-kare
  • Kimbap 김밥
  • Laksa
  • Ramen ラーメン
  • Taiwan Breakfast Foods
  • Tapsilog
  • Wasabi ワサビ
  • Yangzhou fried rice 揚州炒飯
  • Youtiao 油條

 

We are Cynthia and Farrah, two first-generation Taiwanese-American women artists in illustration and film respectively. As recent graduates who have experience leading and organizing within the Asian American community at the college level, we’re looking forward to expanding the scope of our projects to include a broader range of contributors and be accessible to a larger audience.

We met in our early years at an annual Buddhist summer camp, where we were taught respect for our food and its sources. These lessons followed us as we grew to consider food as an extension of our identity and a tool to understand our culture. We look forward to continuing this exploration of the intersection between our identities and food, through collaborating with other artists.

Cynthia Cheng is a Taiwanese American illustrator and cartoonist based in Oakland, CA. You can find her helping with Doodles in Google’s San Francisco office during the day and on the hunt for delicious foods in Chinatown after work. In her personal work, she focuses on creating identity-based illustrations and comics and has been excited about the intersection of food and history ever since researching for her thesis project, a series of editorial illustrations centered on Asian and Asian-American issues. With this next project, she’s looking forward to carrying on her passion for community, storytelling, and intercultural education.

You can find Cynthia's work and learn more here: (website / twitter / tumblr / instagram)

Farrah Su is a 1.5 generation Taiwanese American filmmaker and photographer born in Taiwan, raised in Long Island, NY, and currently living in LA. She recently graduated from Chapman University with a B.F.A. in Film Production, emphasizing in cinematography. Inspired by her experience in community organizing, locally and at school, and filmmaking, she works to use filmmaking and photography to uplift voices from disenfranchised communities and create visual language to empower these communities. She finds joy in meaningful relationships, good cups of tea, and watching video essays on almost everything.

You can find Farrah's work and learn more here: (website / instagram)

 

THE ARTISTS

  • Allissa Chan (website / twitter / instagram)
  • Ameena Fareeda (website / instagram)
  • Ann Ryan (website / twitter / instagram)
  • Celine Choo (website / twitter / tumblr)
  • CurryCarrots (website / twitter / instagram)
  • Gica Tam (website / twitter / instagram)
  • Ilsa Zhang (twitter / tumblr / instagram)
  • Jackie Gorman (website / instagram)
  • James Elijah Yap (tumblr / instagram)
  • Jean (website / instagram / facebook)
  • J. Mao (website / twitter)
  • Joyce Chang (website / twitter / tumblr / instagram / facebook)
  • Kevin VQ Dam (website / twitter / instagram)
  • kvebox (website / twitter)
  • Monica Nguyen-Vo (website / twitter / tumblr / instagram)
  • Sarah Jung (website / instagram)
  • Sophie Wang (twitter / instagram)
  • Tessa Lowe (website / tumblr / instagram)
  • Van Chung (instagram)
  • Yuko Okabe (岡部ゆう子) (website / twitter / instagram)

 

THE WRITERS

  • Alex Kanegawa (instagram)
  • Danielle Wu (website) 
  • Emory Johnson (instagram)
  • Frances Huynh (website / instagram)
  • Iris Jong (website / twitter / instagram)
  • Jennifer C. Wang
  • Quincy Surasmith (website)  
  • Sarahlynn Pablo (website / twitter / instagram / facebook)
  • Sonia Liao (website / tumblr) 
  • Susana Kwon 

Our contributors include our artists, artist/writers, and writers. We have 20 contributing artists for the illustrations ($150/each), 9 of them also contributing their accompanying writing pieces (an additional $50), and 11 writers ($100/each). The amount accounted for in under Artists include the payment for the Artists and Artist/Writers.

We are estimating the shipping costs, IndieGoGo platform costs (5%), Stripe fee (3% + $0.30 per transaction), and contingency to be $1,377. Thus making our fundraising goal to equal $7,500.

Once all our costs are covered, we will donate any profits made from the project to an AAPI food-related non-profit, that will be determined at later time.

 

 

In celebration of Asian Pacific Heritage Month, Family Style Zine is collaborating with San Francisco Public Libraries to host workshops for teens and adults about turning passions in art and activism into tangible projects. Through these workshops which will be free to the public, we aim to provide visible examples of turning passions into projects while also connecting to the local community.

To continue the celebrations, Family Style Zine is hosting a launch event in May 2018 called, “Grand Opening: Family Style Zine Launch Event”, at Public Knowledge at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA). With this official launch event, we plan to bring more eyes to the zine and to create more opportunities to uplift both the AAPI creatives who have contributed to our zine as well as the greater San Francisco AAPI community.

We welcome anyone to join us, if you’re in the area! You can find the Facebook event here.

Keep updated with us through our social media! We will be sharing more information on our artists, writers, and the dishes throughout the campaign!

TWITTER /  TUMBLR / INSTAGRAM

story:
My name is Nomi McLeod and I am an occult artist, illustrator and full-time mother (to a daughter and toddler twins).

My work has recently been featured in ‘Hourglass’ the Extinction Rebellion newspaper, the novel ‘Our Lady of the Dark Country’ by Sylvia Linsteadt, Wyrd and Wyse zine, and the Magpie Magazine special ‘Viriditas’.

I live in Devon in the UK.

This is a campaign to make and distribute my 23 card oracle deck, The Gate of Horn Oracle.

 

This project began as a personal one. I wanted to create an in-depth oracle deck for my own use. I’ve used traditional tarot and oracle cards since I was a teenager, as an integral part of my magical and divinatory practices. Recently I felt that I needed something new and a bit different to guide me.

Having always felt that the cards of the major arcana sequence of traditional tarot were the most powerful, I decided to create a deck using only these.

So, over the last year and a bit (drawing in between looking after my children, often late in the evening) I have been visioning and creating.   

 

I have used the names of the traditional major arcana as my initial starting point. I have changed some to make them feel more relevant to life now – for example, ‘Judgment’ has become ‘Consequence’, and speaks to our species’ environmental impact.

 

The name ‘Gate of Horn’ comes from Ancient Greece, where dreams were thought to come to us either through a gate of ivory or a gate of horn. Those that came through the gate of ivory were of no significance but those through the gate of horn were messages from the gods.

 

I have not used the traditional imagery or symbols in my drawings – I let the cards whisper to me and take me in new directions. Instead of drawing the cards in sequence, I found that I had to wait for an image to present itself to me, to arrive through the gate of horn. The vision for the ‘Moon’ appeared in a dream, others – more mundanely -  landed in my mind as I waited for the bus. This manner of arrival has led to unexpected elements in the cards – and sometimes mysterious inclusions which even I don’t fully understand. (Why is the figure in my card ‘Restraint’ holding a hag stone?).

It also meant an extra card, the twenty-third, called ‘Discord’ has snuck in.

I have been touched and excited to learn that so many of you felt that these drawings also spoke to you – it is my sincere wish that they inspire and guide you.

Thank you for wanting to make this oracle deck a reality of card and ink!

 

 

Funds

The funds for this campaign are simple – the majority of the money will be spent on printing each deck and its tuck box, and covering shipping costs.

The perks of this campaign are also straightforward – oracle decks! Some of you (those who have been following my progress online) have also asked me for prints of some of the cards, so I will have a limited number of these on offer also.

 

Without your help I do not have the funds to create the decks, so your support in this really is vital to birth these cards.

Even if you cannot help at this time, I’d be grateful if you felt moved to share my campaign with anyone you think might be excited by it.

 

Once the funds are raised I will start the process of printing with my UK based printers. This is a one-woman ship, so I may need you to all bear with me a little as I juggle twins, daughter and shipping. But I will keep everyone updated on what’s happening with your cards as we go along.   

 

 

 

A final word to thank everyone who modelled for me in this project. Each and every incredible person is an artist, activist, magician, performer or several of these…

Please take a look at the work which they do to see why I found them so inspiring:

 

Ru Callendar (High Priest)   http://www.thegreenfuneralcompany.co.uk/p/about

 

Jiordi Rosales (Justice) http://www.emergencenetwork.org/vulture/

 

Reama Airoud (Mother) https://www.instagram.com/deaddeadlovely/

 

Tarn Scully (Hanged)  https://theatrebristol.net/person/tarn-scully/

 

Andy Letcher (Hermit) www.andyletcher.co.uk

 

Bayo Akomolafe (Father) http://bayoakomolafe.net/

 

Julian Vayne (Magician) https://theblogofbaphomet.com

 

Nomita Khatri (Strength) https://nomitakhatri.com/

 

Will Secretan (Devil) http://www.psycheandsoma.org

 

Jade Moon (Priestess) http://earthsmokebonesong.co.uk/jade-moon

 

Daisy Eris Campbell (Discord) https://cosmictriggerplay.com/

 

Josh Levontine (Fool)
story_txt: My name is Nomi McLeod and I am an occult artist, illustrator and full-time mother (to a daughter and toddler twins).My work has recently been featured in ‘Hourglass’ the Extinction Rebellion newspaper, the novel ‘Our Lady of the Dark Country’ by Sylvia Linsteadt, Wyrd and Wyse zine, and the Magpie Magazine special ‘Viriditas’.I live in Devon in the UK.This is a campaign to make and distribute my 23 card oracle deck, The Gate of Horn Oracle. This project began as a personal one. I wanted to create an in-depth oracle deck for my own use. I’ve used traditional tarot and oracle cards since I was a teenager, as an integral part of my magical and divinatory practices. Recently I felt that I needed something new and a bit different to guide me.Having always felt that the cards of the major arcana sequence of traditional tarot were the most powerful, I decided to create a deck using only these.So, over the last year and a bit (drawing in between looking after my children, often late in the evening) I have been visioning and creating.    I have used the names of the traditional major arcana as my initial starting point. I have changed some to make them feel more relevant to life now – for example, ‘Judgment’ has become ‘Consequence’, and speaks to our species’ environmental impact. The name ‘Gate of Horn’ comes from Ancient Greece, where dreams were thought to come to us either through a gate of ivory or a gate of horn. Those that came through the gate of ivory were of no significance but those through the gate of horn were messages from the gods. I have not used the traditional imagery or symbols in my drawings – I let the cards whisper to me and take me in new directions. Instead of drawing the cards in sequence, I found that I had to wait for an image to present itself to me, to arrive through the gate of horn. The vision for the ‘Moon’ appeared in a dream, others – more mundanely -  landed in my mind as I waited for the bus. This manner of arrival has led to unexpected elements in the cards – and sometimes mysterious inclusions which even I don’t fully understand. (Why is the figure in my card ‘Restraint’ holding a hag stone?).It also meant an extra card, the twenty-third, called ‘Discord’ has snuck in.I have been touched and excited to learn that so many of you felt that these drawings also spoke to you – it is my sincere wish that they inspire and guide you.Thank you for wanting to make this oracle deck a reality of card and ink!  FundsThe funds for this campaign are simple – the majority of the money will be spent on printing each deck and its tuck box, and covering shipping costs.The perks of this campaign are also straightforward – oracle decks! Some of you (those who have been following my progress online) have also asked me for prints of some of the cards, so I will have a limited number of these on offer also. Without your help I do not have the funds to create the decks, so your support in this really is vital to birth these cards.Even if you cannot help at this time, I’d be grateful if you felt moved to share my campaign with anyone you think might be excited by it. Once the funds are raised I will start the process of printing with my UK based printers. This is a one-woman ship, so I may need you to all bear with me a little as I juggle twins, daughter and shipping. But I will keep everyone updated on what’s happening with your cards as we go along.      A final word to thank everyone who modelled for me in this project. Each and every incredible person is an artist, activist, magician, performer or several of these…Please take a look at the work which they do to see why I found them so inspiring: Ru Callendar (High Priest)   http://www.thegreenfuneralcompany.co.uk/p/about Jiordi Rosales (Justice) http://www.emergencenetwork.org/vulture/ Reama Airoud (Mother) https://www.instagram.com/deaddeadlovely/ Tarn Scully (Hanged)  https://theatrebristol.net/person/tarn-scully/ Andy Letcher (Hermit) www.andyletcher.co.uk Bayo Akomolafe (Father) http://bayoakomolafe.net/ Julian Vayne (Magician) https://theblogofbaphomet.com Nomita Khatri (Strength) https://nomitakhatri.com/ Will Secretan (Devil) http://www.psycheandsoma.org Jade Moon (Priestess) http://earthsmokebonesong.co.uk/jade-moon Daisy Eris Campbell (Discord) https://cosmictriggerplay.com/ Josh Levontine (Fool)

story:
About The Mosaic Trail 

For over 25 years, the Mosaic Trail, a collection of mosaics adorning the lamp poles, store fronts, and streets of the East Village have beautified and memorialized the area; however, they're falling into disrepair, and so an iconic piece of the East Village is, too. 

The mosaics are eye-catching art that provide a finessed change of scenery to the area. They pay homage to icons of New York and the greater world, as well as events important to the city, and even global peace. The Trail is a selfless work that has taken up the greater part of thirty years for artist, teacher, and war veteran Jim Power, with which he wants to "draw the anxiety out of the city with beauty".

In the mid 90's, due to destruction by an anti-graffiti task force, about 50 of the lamp posts were mistakingly destroyed, despite permits allowing for them. Only a quarter of the poles that make up the original trail remain, but those have been weathered by time. So Jim turns to you: Help him restore his life's work, pieces of art that are now ingrained in the history and culture of the East Village. Let future generations wander the Mosaic Trail, too.

What Is Needed & What You Get

Jim seeks to raise $30,000 that will go toward rebuilding approximately half of the damaged lamp poles along The Mosaic Trail. 

Not only will your contribution help support the rebuilding of a part of New York City history, but you will receive exciting and unique thank-you's related to the trail, from annotated maps and Jim's Etsy-famous mosaic belt buckles to having your image included on a pole for all to see! You can even adopt your own pole, and choose its theme as well as have your name displayed prominently -- whatever will represent you as a part of this community! Read through the perks on the right for all the details!

Proceeds will go toward supporting all facets of the rebuilding of the trail:

  • Crew: two other full-time workers who will assist Jim with all prepwork, as well as the restoration of the poles in the field.  
  • Artistic Materials: tile, salvaged dishware, glass, etc. (Material donations are welcome! Contact Jim if you have materials to offer).
  • Construction Materials & Tools: glue, grout, mesh, sealer, cutters, scrapers, sponges

Any additional money will go towards mosaic workshops, which will aim to teach the general public and schools about mosaic-making.

The Impact

In donating to the restoration project, you will be helping to save a piece of art that is thoughtful and humanitarian, a beautiful dedication to the city. Now more than ever, art and history needs your saving!

The Mosaic Trail has been recognized by various publications and media outlets including The New York Post, The New York Times, The Villager, The Etsy Blog, and even National Geographic, which named the Mosaic Trail a top downtown destination in their recently published guidebook, “Walking New York.” Mayor Bloomberg even gave an official proclamation, calling the Mosaic Trail a selfless contribution, thanking Jim.

Jim’s not out for fame. He makes his art for the community that he loves and that loves him so dearly in return. He is, most of all, thankful for the continued support from people throughout the years that have allowed him to see a vision of his come to fruition. Please help him preserve his vision!


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help speak up for the preservation of this beautiful work!

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools above to tell your friends about the project!
  • And keep up with all the latest from Jim:

On his official website http://eastvillagenews.blogspot.com/

On Facebook

story:
Who We Are

Here lies a tale of two young women, who once worked at the same salon, both unique in their own ways came together to realize a bigger dream they share of opening up their own shop.  Enter Lah, a sassy nail and loc technician with a louder than life personality and Cia, an artist who dabbles in anything she can get her hands on and together they make LahCia Studios.



What We Do!!!



What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign is to help us raise the funds to open up our own studio, free to run things they way we want to and to be ourselves, tattoos, piercings and all and to offer the same for our clients, who we like to call our extended family. The funds will be used for everything, from paint on the walls, to barber chairs, stations, hair products and inventory and all the awesome perks you will receive in exchange for your help!

We are offering some pretty rad perks if you look and scroll over to the right of the screen. We have perks ranging from $5 to $500 with pens, stickers, coffee mugs, tshirts and membership services and lets not forget the grand opening party!

Here are some perks:

The perks shown are in the lower range of perks, that even once the salon is open, we will continue to sell this merchandise in our shop to our clients. The higher end perks include a customized name wood burning, your name on our funders wall, customized drawings, tattoo drawings, service packages, ticket to the grand opening party, discount service cards, discounted memberships, and a complete makeover with a photoshoot included. Make sure to check out all our perks and pick which one is right for you!


This money will help us to create an environment that is different from the average cookie cutter salon. It is not just a salon studio where people are treated like a number, in and out of the chair with no real connection or customer service, it will be a place where a transformation will take place, when a client sits in our chair and feels like family, getting exactly what they ask for no matter how fun or classic their requests can be.

Our Vision

We want to make our motto come true “Where old school soul meets new school style”. We want to fuse the atmosphere and feel of a tattoo shop, barbershop, salon and art studio all in one, where the walls are dripping with character and stories with one of a kind artwork by various artists locally and internationally. No matter your sex, age, orientation, style, preferences; whether you are tattooed, pierced, strange, odd or a normal average joe, you can feel comfortable getting all your beauty needs met with no judgments.


Other Ways You Can Help

Here is how you can help!

With your contributions, you are not only helping 2 stylists fulfill their dreams, you are helping us to provide for our families in unimaginable ways and breaking free from a typical “job”, and in turn we can give others to be themselves, to love themselves for who they are and be able to express themselves through their style and inner and outer beauty.

Whatever you can contribute, even just $5, every penny helps! If you cannot afford that, it’s ok, all we ask is that you share our campaign with your family and friends. Share it across the universe we call the internet, on whatever social media you are on, or you can also go screaming down the street shouting it to the world, that works too- Just share it!!!

Thank you for all of your help!

story:
Dear Friends and Supporters,

Hello! We are Sweet Ditch, a group of female artists who have joined creative forces to put on an exciting and diverse show this summer, with more exhibitions to come in both London and New York.

We have artists ranging from painters and illustrators to film makers, sculptors and live performers. Our first show is about raw, original artwork. Work that is not trying to be anything other than honest and courageous. 

As Sweet Ditch, we set out to challenge and inspire one another, and hopefully our audiences too. We are proud of the work that has been born out of of this supportive multi-disciplinary environment and can't wait to show you.

We hope the uncompromising nature of our art will strike a cord with men and women who for whatever reasons are not making the art inside them. We want to inspire people to create no matter what.


A little about the Artists....

Kate Rubens-  Kate is a London and New York based artist, a painter and dancer who has spent the last few years drawing comparisons between both forms of art. In her practice she focuses predominantly on the female form creating work which draws on her environment and the changeable relationship she has with her body.  www.katerubens.tumblr.com

                                            


Nicole Cataldo-Davies- Nicole has in this instance put aside her artistic direction, choreography and live action in order to delve a little more selfishly into her own trials and tribulations of being in the world. Trained in traditional arts, social sculpture and drinking cups of hot water, she is returning to the realm of sculptural installation in an attempt to marriage her performance and participatory work with a tongue and cheek exploration into 'immanence'. 
www.nicolecataldo-davies.com 

                  


Christina Hardinge- Christina is an artist and filmmaker  based in London. Christina's work bears a powerful personal imprint. Marked by a fascination with both children and the elderly, her films are low on dialogue and explicit story exposition. Instead, they look to bold, unusual images, vivid details and an acute use of sound design to create their unsettling worlds.  www.christinahardinge.com  

                  


Laura Adamson- Laura is a fine artist and teacher living and working in North London. For the forthcoming Sweet Ditch show Laura will be exhibiting a series of paintings of the important men in her life past and present. Laura is also devising a performance piece that will be shown alongside the paintings.

               

India Banks- India is an artist, designer and director for theatre and film in addition to devising and performing with CRANK Theatre. The performance art and theatre she creates is rooted in satire, fusing dark humour with commentary on social issues. She has also worked with young people and vulnerable adults in the fields of devised theatre and design. She has recently started working in the fields of documentary film and music videos. She is currently doing a part-time MA at SOAS which combines filmmaking with development studies, ethnomusicology and study of the global arts industries.

               


Maria Bird- Maria’s artwork sits somewhere between drawing, collage and sculpture. Her work is often tangled and hard to see all at once, asking for a more self-conscious form of looking from the viewer. The moving surface drags the eye through different channels and pathways, forcing the viewer to re-enact the making process to grasp the full picture. Maria Bird wants the viewer to share in the choices, focus and stamina the piece required, and to get a clear feeling for the energy and emotion behind it as well.

                                    


Anthea Clarke- Anthea is a singer, songwriter, fashion designer and artist based in London. Currently working on projects that explore desire, how it makes us feel and the positive and negative impact it has on our lives.   www.facebook.com/iamfya - http://www.mytribefashion.co.uk  

                                      


Martina Ziewe- Martina is a London based artist. She predominantly paints, more recent work has crossed over into installation and performance. Martina is presently exploring the line between the physical and spiritual, making visceral work that comes from the gut. She is curious about the creative impulse and process of art and life continually feeding back and informing one another on what it is to be alive.

                                           


Heather Nelson- Heather is an artist based in Hackney, London. She studied a degree in Sculpture at Camberwell School of Arts, but since leaving she has focused mainly on painting. Using oil paints, she conveys her thoughts and interactions through metaphorical imagery. The actual imagery used always has personal meaning to her life but is redefined to represent something else.  http://mixedcomposition.blogspot.co.uk/

                                          


Carrie Topley-  Carrie is an artist that uses both her background in music and dance to inform her practice. Previous work has involved taking visual data and turning this into musical scores, often using violin, vocals and the use of loops and effects pedals. The line where music/rhythm meets the body as a performance tool is where most of her exploration into live work stems from.

                            


Eddie Hecht- Eddie usually works in TV and film in the art department, however prefers to identify herself as a 'maker' whose goal is to collect as many creative skills across as many mediums as she can. She always has had a sketchbook on the go in which she express' her different understandings of sexuality, beauty and biro lines.  In this exhibition she will draw together a collection of these images that flow on their own accord from her head to her hand. In particular exploring the human body as an empty vessel and the relationship between the positive and negative spaces it can create.

                                         


How You Can Help...

We are very excited to have confirmed a rare and beautiful space to exhibit our show, The Safehouse which is located in Peckham, South London. Unfortunately the space and all other things needed for the show such as promotion, equipment and materials does not come cheap. So this is where you come in, we need to help cover some costs:

500 - Hire of Space

350 - Promotional Material

200 - Exhibition Catalogue

300 - Equipment Hire

150 - Alcohol for Opening Night/ Licence

500 - Materials

Alas we cannot achieve what we dream to do without the financial support of the public. Our city, London, is an expensive one. We simply can't afford to do this exhibition on our own. Trust that we will use the experience and leverage generated from this show to go on and continue making work that will benefit not just ourselves, but other collaborators, students, projects and communities as well.

Our show 'Sweet Ditch' will be taking place on the 4th till the 8th of June. We are excited to be hosting events during the show including a Opening Private View and a very special Live Arts Performance Night.

All the artists involved are dedicated to making this show a reality and to have the opportunity to create an exhibition which is truly to its highest standard. We appreciate all your time and support and every donation big or small helps us on this creative journey.

A huge THANK YOU! from all the artists at Sweet Ditch

Follow us…

on Facebook- facebook.com/sweetditch

on Twitter - @thesweetditch

story:
After many years of being discouraged as an artist, I began abstract painting one decade ago! And while I may not be Picasso or Money (yet!) the journey has been amazing.

I am returning to one of my favourite cities, Istanbul, to create a body of work starting Christmas Day. And I want to share that work.

The collection will be available by pre-sale at affordable pricing so you can own a piece of the Istanbul collection of abstracts and landscapes. I will show the entire grouping in Spring 2019 and then send yours off to you anywhere in the world! 

This is my very first sabbatical to create a body of work so it's pretty exciting! 

I am creating 3 distinct groupings:

8 small works on paper (regular $75 / pre-sale $40)

8 small works framed (regular $125 / pre-sale $75)

1 large work ( regular $795 / pre-sale $350)

Included is shipping to you!

Plus, I am offering "Postcards from Istanbul" which I will alter and mail off to you as a souvenir of the journey with my thanks!

And, you can share this with friends, relatives - well anyone really - as long as they love art!

IF WE DOUBLE THE FUND EVERYONE WILL BE GETTING A RED DECK OF CHARLIER PLAYING CARDS!!!!!!! ORDERS OUTSIDE OF CANADA MUST ADD 8 $  

  • My name is Jozef Amiri I was born in Iran But now live in Canada
  • I Have loved design and magic but now I took the leap to combine the 2
  • I need your help for this deck of playing cards in 60 days i have faith in you all that you can aide my dream

 

I need $10000 to make these playing cards. Your money will be going towards the printing and finishing and design aspects.

The perks are : the more you buy the more you save 

If i do not reach my goal the money will go toward the finishing of the project

The Impact

Everytime you contribute

- Cards will come with 2 custom cards : blank and double backer

- Box will have the vintage holdout.

- Thin Boarders with one way design

- Elegant Ace of Spades, Back Design , Matching Chort cards, And Jokers

If You can't help financially don't worry

- Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
We

Progressive Theatre Workshop is a company that follows a concept through to its death. We have spent years cultivating the same works to get it just right or very wrong. This is theatre of politics and purpose with little to gain and everything to lose. Contribute fast.


Why

We need time to develop this piece. We need several workshops to get this up. We need time to make you proud of us.


What

A slightly-staged reading featuring the musings and vocal stylings of Shirley Phelps-Roper as she plays the cabaret rooms of hell


featuring Erin Markey as Shirley Phelps-Roper


written and directed by John J. Caswell, Jr.


an extension of Progressive Theatre Workshop's CLOSET.DRAMA. work in progress. 


When: 08/24/11 @ 8PM


Where: Hell... but simultaneously broadcast somewhere cool in NYC. TBA.


Cost: FREE.... BUT.... feel free to tithe. The donation plate will be passed.


Disclaimer: This is a parody of a public figure. While Shirley does everything in her power to make reasonable people believe that the content of this piece could be true... it isn't?

story:
Blades made with character by characters.

We’re Chris and Lynden, and we make pretty steel things in Austin, Texas. We also like burning stuff, which we happen to do a lot in making those things. Our approach to bladesmithing has evolved as a natural progression from our interests in martial arts, military history, and metallurgy, which we combined with our love of hitting things and playing with fire. Eventually, we discovered that working with steel to create blades and other pieces of art was our spiritual calling--we couldn’t stop shaping metal if we tried.

Unlike your typical department store knife, every piece we create is done by hand, without the use of a CNC machine (we, for a change, will not welcome our robot overlords). While we’ll occasionally use a grinder here and there, we try our best to use the same methods medieval bladesmiths did back a few centuries ago. What this means is that along with being prettier and more personalized, our blades are more durable and hold an edge for far longer than your average $20 stainless steel knife.

Why we need your help

As you can see in the video, our setup is pretty quaint. Don’t get us wrong, we’re not complaining, we love our little hovel, but we could use some tools to help expedite our process. Right now, we’re looking to add a digital kiln, which allows us to experiment mad scientist-style with really precise processes we couldn’t do otherwise.Like making pocket and kitchen knives. The railroad track is cool and all, but we’re also looking to pick up a better anvil which will make forging easier and more precise. A more precise grinder would also speed up our turnaround exponentially. Now, this doesn’t mean we’ll start cutting corners, or that we’ll let quality slip: we take too much pride in our work to allow that to happen. It does mean we’ll be able to produce knives more quickly and charge less for them, which seems like a win-win to us.

If we have money left over from buying tools, we’ll start applying that to bright shiny new steel, pretty woods, and other assorted materials. We’ll also start expanding out the shop, so the both of us can work in there at the same time without tripping over Chris’ hair getting in each other’s way.

Lastly, your funds will help us continue to do what we do. We both have other side jobs along with bladesmithing so we can pay the bills, but both of us would love to focus more on creating our art and less on how to make ends meet. The ultimate goal is to be able to make knives and other pieces of steel art full time. We’re not looking to get rich, we just wanna be able to live off of what we do.


Updates/Webisodes

Instead of traditional written updates, our friends at North Loop Films are going to be cutting together a series of “webisodes” that we’ll post on here. These webisodes will follow us around, catching our antics and tomfoolery for all the world to see, and hopefully keep you up to speed in the process. You’ll get to watch us work in the shop while we explain the processes behind making these blades, and see us try not to make fools of ourselves as we take part in panel discussions at different conventions. Chances are, you’ll probably even see your knife or bottle opener being made. Let us know if there’s anything you’d like to see specifically, and we’ll do our best to make it happen!

story:
Hi Indegogoers! 

My name is Julian Scalia and I am Sculptor and Video Artist.  I have started this campaign to raise funds for The Throne Of Visions my newest sculpture for Burning Man 2013.

WHAT IS THE THRONE OF VISIONS?

It is a multimedia interactive experience designed specifically for Burning Man’s 2013 theme; Cargo Cult.  The Throne of Visions is a trans-dimensional device that allows the user to view sights in the etheric realm.  It takes the form of a regal chair with a strange dystopian viewing apparatus attached at its crown.  Housed in the epicenter of Burning Man, this piece of Homegrown Technology will be on display for 50,000 people to interact with.  It is the philosopher’s alchemical throne, a gift of modern technology for the mystics and diviners.

WAIT?  WHAT THE HELL IS A ETHERIC VISION DEVICE?!

I am building the Throne of Visions to remind people of a perception just outside our own reality.  Using the old occult language of Paracelsus and the elementals, the Throne of Visions will enable viewers to interact with the unseen world of fantasy.    I am repurposing old turn of the century theater tricks to create what I call Analog Augmented Reality.  A magical miracle that will remind us of our societies roots in this age of Google Glass.  I hope the Throne of Visions will offer a refreshing glimpse into the fantasy of our psyche, igniting curiosity in the wonders of our physical realm.  I would love to tell you more about how it works but I can’t reveal all my secrets! 

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP?

I am a young artist who has always dreamt of bringing a large piece of artwork to the playa.  This year the Burning Man organization has approved my proposal for the Throne of Visions!  But I need your help to give my project that extra oomph. Unlike many of the large-scale, high budget projects at Burning Man, the Throne of Visions is unfortunately not partially funded by an art grant.  Nor do I have the support system of veteran theme camps and high tech wizards.  Instead she is a modest project with big dreams; lovingly hand crafted by a small group of volunteers and myself the artist.  It is with your help that this project will truly manifest and become alive.  Help us with our Promethean task and breathe life into a visionary dream.

HOW I’ll SPEND YOUR DONATIONS… 

The Funds raised will go towards cutting the costs of all my materials.  I will spend your dime on every inch of my materials.  Your money will be used: 

  • On lumber, resin, glass and box of women’s panty hos  
  • On each and every screw, nail, bolt and washer
  • to help afford expensive electronics like LED lights, LCD monitors and batteries used to power the interactive portion of Throne of Visions 
  • On transportation:  your funds will help transport this tiny beast into the middle of the barren Black Rock Desert. 

Even if my $2500 goal is not reached your money will be put to good use.  Equally allotted to all my different needs each dime will help lift the financial burden of this titanic endeavor.

Thanks for taking a look at my campaign!

Every donation made will be massively appreciated. 

I have spent a lot of time putting together amazing gifts for those of you who donate.  Each tier will receive a personalized thank you postcard and there are many other amazing hand crafted gifts that I hope will make you feel a part of our family.

Please check back often for updates about the Throne Of Visions and take a second to like my project at Facebook.  Even if you can’t donate please spread the word and share the love.

 All my gratitude,  Julian Scalia

story:
My name is Kevin Jesuino. I am a digital media and performance based artist. In May 2013 I will produce a site-specific projection/performance art piece in Tondela, Portugal as part of an artist residnecy with ARTerra Artist Residency. 

Inspired by community, along with my connection a sense of displacement as a Portuguese citizen who grew up most of his life in Canada but who still feels culturally Portuguese, I hope to create a public projection art performance. The piece will evolve out of experience in returning to the country of my ancestors and investigating what it means to be part of the Tondela community. Research will be undertaken regarding  particular community based issues specific to the people of that municipality. In past projects in which I involve myself in the community in this manner I have produced projects that question notions of the effects of gentrification, cultural identity, post-humanism, environmental concerns, and humans relationship to technology.

The projection will be created using 3D mapping software, my laptop and a projector. All of these tools will accompany me from Canada to this residency. I speak Portuguese quite fluently and am prepared to do my own investigation of the community and it’s current issues -- politically, socially and economically. 

With your donation I will be able to cover transporation costs for myself and my equipment along with artist fees. 

If you are unable to donate please help by passing on a link to this fundraising campaign. 

For more imformation about my work please visit my website: www.kevinjesuino.com

Thank you

story:
Summary

The Grand River Creative Corridor, also known as “GRCC Detroit”, is an art corridor and neighborhood revitalization project concentrated on Grand River Avenue between Rosa Parks Boulevard and Warren Avenue in Detroit, Michigan.

Launched on July 15, 2012 by real estate executive and managing director of “4731”, Derek Weaver, the project features over 100 murals on 15 buildings; an outdoor fine-art gallery at a bus stop; free-standing art installations; a clean-up of overgrown vegetation, trash, and vandalism; and an economic stimulus project for local businesses.  The project involves over 45 volunteer-artists from Detroit, Ohio, California, Germany, France, and New Zealand and is an ongoing effort to transform Detroit’s infamous Grand River Avenue into a creative hub that attracts: tourists, artists, small businesses, entrepreneurs, and investors alike.  The Grand River Creative Corridor is a designated project of P.A.S.S.E.S., a Michigan-based 501C(3) non-profit organization.

 

 

What We Need

We need funding for the following:

  • Artist's paint and supplies
  • Building materials for art structures to be installed in Spring 2013 (see photos in "gallery" section for example)
  • Exterior paint to paint buildings and art structures
  • Clean-up supplies such as: weed killer, garbage bags, work-gloves, dumpster rentals, etc...

If we successfully raise $2,500 then we will be able to purchase all the supplies we need!

If we successfully raise over $5,000 the we can provide each artist a small commission to participate in the project!!!  It would be phenomenal to be able to provide the artists a small token of appreciation for the their committment to the project!

 

 

What You Get

We are not only asking you to support our project through donations but we are offering you a piece of it!  Please check out the "rewards" you can receive from your donation.

 

 

The Impact

By donating to this project you can become part of the revitalization of Detroit!  Detroit was once the "capital of the world" which built the United States and World's economy through the automotive industry.  

After the 1967 Detroit riots and the bankruptcy of General Motors and Crysler, it's time to REBUILD!

Our mission is to revitalize this city: 1 house, 1 building, 1 block, 1 neighboorhod at at time through a creative approach that empowers and showcases Detroit artists!
 
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? That's okay!  You can help us by:

  • Sharing this campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, and everyone else!
  • Share our website!
  • Share our facebook!
  • Most importantly you can come visit the project!  This a public-art project and we are open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week!
