story:
THANK YOU FOR VISITNG BUT THE CAMPAIGN ON INDIEGOGO HAS NOW FINISHED. YOU CAN STILL PURCHASE YOUR RIVER OF LIGHT RAIN BARREL FROM WWW.REDDEER2013.CA FOR LOCAL PICK UP IN RED DEER, ALBERTA, CANADA.

 

The River of Light is a world touring art installation that combines floating light objects, sound and new technologies to celebrate the rivers of the world through public art.

Today, through our River of Light campaign, we are asking for your help to bring the River of Light to Red Deer in Alberta, Canada in a one-off spectacular event on the 30th June 2013. 

With the aim of shining a light on the growing concerns around river preservation and water conversation worldwide, the River of Light Campaign takes public art as it’s platform to give you the opportunity to contribute directly to sustainable water preservation. 

The River of Light has been commissioned by Central Alberta Historical Society as part of the Red Deer Centennial 2013.  

What is the River of Light?

The River of Light is floating light installation designed to illuminate the rivers of the world. 

Created by artistic studio Creatmosphere in 2008 as a community engagement project for the River Thames in London, UK, the River of Light has gone on to receive local and international recognition through its ability to not only engage communities to participate in the work but also to highlight the importance of river preservation and water conversation on a global scale. 

Shifting and evolving as it travels to rivers throughout the world, the River of Light will now be travelling to Red Deer in Alberta, Canada. 

Commissioned by the Central Alberta Historical Society as part of the cities 100th birthday celebrations, this spectacular event will illuminate the Red Deer River for the 100,000 Red Deer citizens on the 30th June 2013. 

Find out more about the River of Light here.

Who are Creatmosphere?

As an internationally acclaimed artistic studio we have created installations and interventions around the world for the last 10 years that use light as a medium to communicate meaning about the spaces we inhabit. 

Founded in 2003 by French light artist Laurent Louyer, our work places the experience of the viewer at the heart of the process by giving them the opportunity to see the environments they live in in a new light. 

With a portfolio that encompasses all aspects of light art including; permanent installations, temporary interventions, interactive projects, public art, light sculptures and bespoke fabrications, the River of Light is one of our most renowned projects. 

In 2010 it was recognised as one of the top 50 public arts projects during the Public Art Network Year for 2010, after 10,000 people witnessed the work on the Bow River, Calgary, Canada. 

To find out more about our work visit the Creatmosphere website.   

What is the River of Light campaign?

At the centre of the River of Light is the floating light object that makes up the installation. 

For Red Deer this is the Light Barrel. 

Since our first visit to the city we have been exploring how the rain barrel can become a symbolic, visual, structural-sculptural, modular ‘object’ by transforming it through light, into a light barrel.

Mapping the historical, social and scientific context of the Red Deer river, the light barrel represents and responds to the ‘water use’ as a global issue through the local perspective by becoming the basis for this one off-event whilst illuminating issues surrounding water preservation.

The River of Light campaign therefore aims to engage anyone, whether a Red Deer citizen, a water conversation expert or a public art enthusiast, in supporting river conversation and water preservation by helping us to illuminate those issues.  

Today we are asking for your support to help us create the light barrels that will make up the River of Light and continue to spread this message. 

Why support the River of Light Campaign?

With your help we can make this River of Light bigger, more spectacular and more far-reaching than ever. 

Our goal is to raise $CD 50,000 to produce the light barrels that will travel down the Red Deer River on the 30th June 2013 and will then be given to the Red Deer community as a gift and as a commitment to sustainable water preservation. 

Our great list of perks has something for everyone, whether you are an individual, organsiation or businesses from Red Deer, from Canada or from somewhere else in the world, there is a perk for you.  

To show the investment you have made to the future of the town and water conversation, everyone who donates will be added to the River of Light World Water Supporter's Map.  

With the aim of shining a light on water preservation on a global scale the map shows the name's and locations of everyone that has contributed to the River of Light.  

On top of that, to mark the International Year of Water Co-operation, 5% of your contribution will be donated to UN Water, meaning that in supporting the River of Light campaign you will not only be creating a unique event for Red Deer you will also be directly supporting a global campaign for water preservation. 

The more money we can raise, the larger the installation, the greater the investment for the community and the more far-reaching the message can be.

How will we use your contribution?

The River of Light has been commissioned by Central Alberta Historical Society, from whom we have secured a proportion of funding to deliver this project alongside a series of citywide installations and interventions. 

To deliver the River of Light element of our citywide light festival we need to raise $CD 50,000 to produce the light barrels. 

We have calculated that each light barrel will cost $CD 95 to purchase, modify with a lighting component and assemble. 

Your contribution will therefore go directly to transformation and gifting of 500 light barrels.  

Why we believe the River of Light will be a success?

What has really stood out to us about the River of Light is the impact it has on the communities it travels to. 

In the 1st River of Light for the River Thames in London, UK in 2008, 50 spheres were personalised by children from two local schools to connect communities from both sides of the River. 

In Calgary, Canada, the River of Light was witnessed by over 10,000 people, but was also created by over 100 volunteers who helped make the light spheres and launch them on the Bow River. As writer Linda Hawkins said about this event:

“...the universal appeal of this event was clear. The pathways and riverbanks were full of people. Some settled in on lawn chairs with refreshments, as if at a sporting event. Others pedaled bicycles or abandoned them to perch right at the water’s edge. There was conversation but mostly there was stillness. A sense of wonder pervaded as, silently, the multicoloured constellation emerged from the surrounding blackness. The spheres converged and dispersed, mapping the river’s topography as they disappeared around islands and materialized back into view. Illuminating the river’s flow patterns, the spheres symbolized water molecules on their journey from source to city. Part performance piece, part installation, this artwork cast the river as both setting and lead performer.”

Because we place community at the heart of the River of Light, we know that local people will come together to share in this experience.  

What is unique about the River of Light campaign however is now people from all over the world can come together to celebrate the worlds rivers.  

How else can you support the River of Light Campaign?

The River of Light is a celebration and we are urging you to join in this celebration by helping us to spread campaign and the message globally.

Follow us on twitter and tweet about the campaign through #riveroflight

Like us on Facebook and share the River of Light with your friends.

Join our mailing list and be the first to hear about opportunities to get involved with the River of Light. 

We are always looking for volunteers, donors and supporters to help make our work a reality.  If you want to find out more about the other ways you can support the River of Light, visit our Get Involved page on the River of Light website.

A big thank you from all the team at Creatmosphere for your support in bringing the River of Light to Red Deer, Alberta, Canada.
story_txt:
THANK YOU FOR VISITNG BUT THE CAMPAIGN ON INDIEGOGO HAS NOW FINISHED. YOU CAN STILL PURCHASE YOUR RIVER OF LIGHT RAIN BARREL FROM WWW.REDDEER2013.CA FOR LOCAL PICK UP IN RED DEER, ALBERTA, CANADA.
 
The River of Light is a world touring art installation that combines floating light objects, sound and new technologies to celebrate the rivers of the world through public art.
Today, through our River of Light campaign, we are asking for your help to bring the River of Light to Red Deer in Alberta, Canada in a one-off spectacular event on the 30th June 2013. 
With the aim of shining a light on the growing concerns around river preservation and water conversation worldwide, the River of Light Campaign takes public art as it’s platform to give you the opportunity to contribute directly to sustainable water preservation. 

The River of Light has been commissioned by Central Alberta Historical Society as part of the Red Deer Centennial 2013.  
What is the River of Light?
The River of Light is floating light installation designed to illuminate the rivers of the world. 
Created by artistic studio Creatmosphere in 2008 as a community engagement project for the River Thames in London, UK, the River of Light has gone on to receive local and international recognition through its ability to not only engage communities to participate in the work but also to highlight the importance of river preservation and water conversation on a global scale. 

Shifting and evolving as it travels to rivers throughout the world, the River of Light will now be travelling to Red Deer in Alberta, Canada. 
Commissioned by the Central Alberta Historical Society as part of the cities 100th birthday celebrations, this spectacular event will illuminate the Red Deer River for the 100,000 Red Deer citizens on the 30th June 2013. 
Find out more about the River of Light here.
Who are Creatmosphere?
As an internationally acclaimed artistic studio we have created installations and interventions around the world for the last 10 years that use light as a medium to communicate meaning about the spaces we inhabit. 

Founded in 2003 by French light artist Laurent Louyer, our work places the experience of the viewer at the heart of the process by giving them the opportunity to see the environments they live in in a new light. 
With a portfolio that encompasses all aspects of light art including; permanent installations, temporary interventions, interactive projects, public art, light sculptures and bespoke fabrications, the River of Light is one of our most renowned projects. 
In 2010 it was recognised as one of the top 50 public arts projects during the Public Art Network Year for 2010, after 10,000 people witnessed the work on the Bow River, Calgary, Canada. 
To find out more about our work visit the Creatmosphere website.   
What is the River of Light campaign? 
At the centre of the River of Light is the floating light object that makes up the installation. 
For Red Deer this is the Light Barrel. 

Since our first visit to the city we have been exploring how the rain barrel can become a symbolic, visual, structural-sculptural, modular ‘object’ by transforming it through light, into a light barrel.
Mapping the historical, social and scientific context of the Red Deer river, the light barrel represents and responds to the ‘water use’ as a global issue through the local perspective by becoming the basis for this one off-event whilst illuminating issues surrounding water preservation.
The River of Light campaign therefore aims to engage anyone, whether a Red Deer citizen, a water conversation expert or a public art enthusiast, in supporting river conversation and water preservation by helping us to illuminate those issues.  
Today we are asking for your support to help us create the light barrels that will make up the River of Light and continue to spread this message. 
Why support the River of Light Campaign?
With your help we can make this River of Light bigger, more spectacular and more far-reaching than ever.  
Our goal is to raise $CD 50,000 to produce the light barrels that will travel down the Red Deer River on the 30th June 2013 and will then be given to the Red Deer community as a gift and as a commitment to sustainable water preservation. 

Our great list of perks has something for everyone, whether you are an individual, organsiation or businesses from Red Deer, from Canada or from somewhere else in the world, there is a perk for you.  
To show the investment you have made to the future of the town and water conversation, everyone who donates will be added to the River of Light World Water Supporter's Map.  
With the aim of shining a light on water preservation on a global scale the map shows the name's and locations of everyone that has contributed to the River of Light.  

On top of that, to mark the International Year of Water Co-operation, 5% of your contribution will be donated to UN Water, meaning that in supporting the River of Light campaign you will not only be creating a unique event for Red Deer you will also be directly supporting a global campaign for water preservation. 
The more money we can raise, the larger the installation, the greater the investment for the community and the more far-reaching the message can be.
How will we use your contribution?
The River of Light has been commissioned by Central Alberta Historical Society, from whom we have secured a proportion of funding to deliver this project alongside a series of citywide installations and interventions. 
To deliver the River of Light element of our citywide light festival we need to raise $CD 50,000 to produce the light barrels. 
We have calculated that each light barrel will cost $CD 95 to purchase, modify with a lighting component and assemble. 
Your contribution will therefore go directly to transformation and gifting of 500 light barrels.  

Why we believe the River of Light will be a success?
What has really stood out to us about the River of Light is the impact it has on the communities it travels to. 

In the 1st River of Light for the River Thames in London, UK in 2008, 50 spheres were personalised by children from two local schools to connect communities from both sides of the River. 
In Calgary, Canada, the River of Light was witnessed by over 10,000 people, but was also created by over 100 volunteers who helped make the light spheres and launch them on the Bow River. As writer Linda Hawkins said about this event:
“...the universal appeal of this event was clear. The pathways and riverbanks were full of people. Some settled in on lawn chairs with refreshments, as if at a sporting event. Others pedaled bicycles or abandoned them to perch right at the water’s edge. There was conversation but mostly there was stillness. A sense of wonder pervaded as, silently, the multicoloured constellation emerged from the surrounding blackness. The spheres converged and dispersed, mapping the river’s topography as they disappeared around islands and materialized back into view. Illuminating the river’s flow patterns, the spheres symbolized water molecules on their journey from source to city. Part performance piece, part installation, this artwork cast the river as both setting and lead performer.”
Because we place community at the heart of the River of Light, we know that local people will come together to share in this experience.  
What is unique about the River of Light campaign however is now people from all over the world can come together to celebrate the worlds rivers.  
How else can you support the River of Light Campaign?
The River of Light is a celebration and we are urging you to join in this celebration by helping us to spread campaign and the message globally.
Follow us on twitter and tweet about the campaign through #riveroflight
Like us on Facebook and share the River of Light with your friends.
Join our mailing list and be the first to hear about opportunities to get involved with the River of Light. 
We are always looking for volunteers, donors and supporters to help make our work a reality.  If you want to find out more about the other ways you can support the River of Light, visit our Get Involved page on the River of Light website.

A big thank you from all the team at Creatmosphere for your support in bringing the River of Light to Red Deer, Alberta, Canada.

story:
Our Story

A LIGHT HAZING is a Burning Man 2011 Honorarium art installation created by Los Angeles-based design group, Future Bright Collective.

A LIGHT HAZING is a pavilion installation comprised of a wooden spiral tunnel with wooden steps—40 ft in diameter and nearly 20 ft tall—encased by photoluminescent canvas panels that glow in the dark in response to UV light. Visitors paint and draw with light on the canvas walls and ceiling with ultraviolet light pens, which slowly fades—giving renewed space or adding layers to playful whims of collaborative creativity.

The Impact

A LIGHT HAZING is an exploratory cavern, allowing visitors to discover new forms of expression, thought, collaboration and play.

A LIGHT HAZING has been exhibited locally at art gatherings in LA, as well as Burning Man 2011 in Black Rock City, NV. We hope to exhibit and share A LIGHT HAZING at other events, including the various Decompressions.

What We Need

We still need to raise additional funds to cover our costs in project completion. Without proper funding, Future Bright Collective cannot fully share the true potential and experience of A LIGHT HAZING. We depend on your interest and support to realize our project. Future Bright Collective will use 100% of funds for supplies, building, transporting, and project reimbursement for A Light Hazing.

---

Previous installation work from Future Bright Collective include: Naked Edges, an art installation for Burning Man 2009, in affiliation with UCLA and Mark Mack Architecture; Soft Underbelly, a light installation for Santa Monica GLOW 2010; Venice Art Crawl; NELAart gallery night (northeast LA).

story:
Ok, now that you have wiped the tears away, let's talk about what is going on.  This message is going to be directed specifically to the friends and family of Relapse Theatre as well as their friends and family.  Anyone else who is inspired to donate,  you will then be considered part of the family.  We are directing it at you because we want to rally those of us that have been to battle together, that know the importance of this theatre, and that refuse to allow an emptiness take over where greatness should stand.

Friends And Family Of Relapse, We Need You, More Than We Ever Have Before.

Most of you already know that as of now, our beloved theatre that is like a home to all of us, has been shut down.   Unless we unite to do something about it, it will stay that way....forever.  Here is the thing about when you lose something important.  It sucks.  It sucks really bad.  But it isn't until much later when you look back, and remember that amazing thing that you once had and took for granted, that you truly feel the impact of what you really lost.

Our loss is fresh, and it is sad.  But if you think it is sad now, wait until a year from now, five years from now, even ten years from now, when that old, dirty church that you once occupied for the purposes of improving the lives of others through laughter, still sits empty.  It is then, when it is too late, that the impact of what you really lost will hit you like a ton of bricks.   

There is a reason that we all come together at Relapse.  It is unlike any other place in the world.  It is a comedy community like no other.  It is revolutionary, and it is ground breaking.  And in order to accomplish something that changes the world for the better, you are going to face massive obstacles.  That is why revolutions aren't easy.  But we have something that most people who attempt revolutions don't have.  We have Bob Wood.  If Bob Wood were alive during the American Revolution, he would be the face we all see on our dollar bills.  And when you have a man like that on YOUR side, you pick him up when he is down.  God knows he has picked every single one of us up a million times over.  In fact, in keeping Relapse open the past 8 or so years, Bob has thrown us all on his back and carried us over obstacles more difficult than any of us could really imagine.  And what has Bob asked for in return?  Only one thing.....that we continue chasing our dream.  That we NEVER let those outside forces that do nothing but tell us that we can never succeed as performers, break our spirit and cause us to quit.  

Since the day I met Bob, he has been been absolutely determined to change the entire world for the better through comedy.  And some, who are not in this industry, who have a "safe" regular job, might smirk and call that dream silly.  Well, to anyone who has ever thought that, I challenge you.  I challenge you to provide evidence, hard evidence, not an opinion you formed based on a misconception, that proves to us that laughter is bad for you, that laughter does not bring people together, that laughter does not make us feel better in our darkest hour.  Prove that to me, and I'll quit.  But that is not going to happen, because in this world that we live in, we have to laugh, we have to love, we have to see light through the darkness.  If we don't...What else is there?  

Bob Wood is a rare person who not only understands the importance of this, but also has the ability to use this to affect a positive influence across a nation.  Imagine if all of us helped Bob just a little bit.

Imagine if we removed some of that burden that Bob so often faces, and we shouldered some of those difficulties ourselves, allowing him to focus on using his amazing talents to move us forward, beyond limits any of us could ever imagine.  Imagine if this theatre that, despite it's struggles, has already created a ripple affect across the country, were able to reach it's true potential.  For me, that is a much more desirable thing to imagine, than an old, broke down building, filled with nothing but squandered dreams.

We must not allow all of ours and Bob's effort to be rendered moot.  If we can accomplish this, then we will have proven that when we really work together, we can do anything, especially live our dreams.  The organizational structure to push Relapse to the next level was set in motion before this all happened.  We aren't far away, but in order to get over this mountain, it is going to have to be us who lifts Bob, the man who has carried us all for so long, up onto our shoulders, and carries him.  I don't know about you, but I'm honored to do it.  

Bob did not ask us to do this.  He refuses to accept handouts.  The only way we were able to get him to not stop us from doing this was by convincing him that not one cent of this is a handout, because it isn't.  Bob has given us all enough free classes, free rehearsal space, free stage use, and a million other things that everyone else in the world would charge us money for.  This is not a handout.  This is simply us paying him back for everything he has ever done.  

The Amount We Need And Why 

From the details I know of why Relapse was shut down, it was because of a perfect storm of circumstances. All at once, an outstanding water bill that we were unaware of, an increased building tax bill, the building insurance bill, and the bill for our necessary renewal of all of our permits, including the liquor license, slammed into Relapse unexpectedly.  

Yes, poor planning was a factor, but the irony is that some of the confusion was caused by some really exciting behind the scenes steps that were being put into place to catapult Relapse to new levels that would prevent this very thing from happening.   

Our target goal is $80,000.  

The first $50,000 is to cover all of those bills that came in. 

The other $30,000 is for a buffer while we implement those theatre wide strategies that will ensure a consistent cash flow that gives us long term stability.     

Any donation, no matter how large or small will be greatly appreciated.  And it will give you the ability to smile, and look back years from now, when Relapse is a household name all over the world, and say, "I played a part in the Relapse Comedy Revolution."

Thank you for reading, and I look forward to working with you all for years to come.

Best Regards,

Your Friends.

Thank you for reading, and I look forward to working with you all for years to come.
Best Regards,

story:
Brandon Pass is a licensed architect with his own practice. Libby O’Bryan is an artist and owner of Sew Co., a sewing manufacturing and product development studio. We are married. Our collaborative process seeks to challenge the boundaries that formally define our methods of making - structure, form, space, order; and exploit the utility common to both - protection, shelter, warmth, community. The essence of both practices align. Both require effective materials and constructions to serve their purpose. Both disciplines have analogous forms – i.e. armor, Bedouin tents, pneumatic structures, umbrellas. In further exploration of these intersections between the built environment and the woven/stitched object, we will create a habitable structure that requires the use of tensile and solid mass structure for the Black Mountain College Museum + Arts Center and Media Arts Project {Re}Happening event.

 

Inspired by the Abelam Spirit Houses of Papau New Guinea, which are ceremonial structures housing the tribe's ancestral souls and central to tribal cultural life, our Spirit House will be a similar beacon on the island of Lake Eden. Our community reveres the site of Black Mountain College for the creative energy it experienced. Our purpose for the structure is to commemorate and communicate with BMC’s ancestral legacy such as Buckminster Fuller, Walter Gropius, Ruth Asawa and Anni Albers who continue to guide us. We strive to spark dialogue for a more interdisciplinary approach to architecture and textiles.

 

The Spirit House pavilion uses a basic triangulated modular form, nested in a concentric pattern to build an arching canopy, much like nature structures itself. Each tetrahedral section provides an intimate space for contemplation; the central intersections of the units rise to provide a place for shared, communal interactions. Reflective expanded aluminum shade cloth, typically used in greenhouse, will cover the Spirit House to give a reflective surface. Light from a small campfire will be reflected in the interior, while the exterior will reflect the light of the full moon occurring that night.

 

Each tetrahedral unit requires approximately 150 linear feet of 2x6 lumber; a 60 foot x 20 foot panel of reflective cloth; 40 bolts, nuts and washers; brackets; rope; and other miscellaneous hardware. We are estimating each unit having a $300 cost. Seven tetrahedral units create the intended design for the inhabitable Spirit House, coming to $2100. However, we will construct as many units as funding allows.  We added an additional $400 for truck rental and other surprise expenses.

For a higher resolution view please go HERE.

And to track the project development, HERE.

 

If the spirit moves you to support the Spirit House at the {Re}Happening, THANK YOU!!! Please let your friends and family know of your contribution to the arts by sharing our campaign.

If you have any resources that might offer us materials at a lower rate or possible donation, that would be amazing.  Please let us know 

If you are unable to support us financially, but want to help 'in spirit', please share our campaign with your friends and family.

And everyone who can please come experience the entire {Re}Happening event at Black Mountain College on April 6, 2012.

rehappening.com

 

_______________________________________________________________________

 

BIOS:

 

Brandon Pass Architect is an architecture practice located in Asheville, North Carolina that strives to merge modern sensibilities and detailing with the vernacular influences of the region. Brandon Pass Architect is a small multidisciplinary practice pursuing an architecture that recognizes the responsibilities of the built form where environmental, social and contextual factors shape each insertion into a given landscape. Architecture should seek to express a given function through a strong clarity of space and form where the details become expressive and exploratory, respecting the hand of the maker while expressing a connection to a greater whole. The responsibility of the architect, in part, is to be aware of all factors of a given context that may inform the design process. It requires an extensive knowledge of and desire to learn new methodologies creating architecture of the highest quality respectful of both time and place.

brandonpassarchitect.com

 

Informed by a former career in New York City’s apparel industry, Libby O’Bryan creates environments for the contemplation of every­day decisions and cultural norms that function outside the commodity driven marketplace. Although asserting a politicized agenda, the aestheticized temporality of her performative/interactive installations provides incentive for its provocative nature. Drawing parallels between craft, the new art economy, and mass-production, she explores the relationships and of maker, machine, and consumer.

libbyobryan.com

wcsewco.com

Reflective expanded aluminum shade cloth, typically used in greenhouse, will cover the Spirit House to give a reflective surface. Light from a small campfire will be reflected in the interior, while the exterior will reflect the light of the full moon occurring that night.
 
Each tetrahedral unit requires approximately 150 linear feet of 2x6 lumber; a 60 foot x 20 foot panel of reflective cloth; 40 bolts, nuts and washers; brackets; rope; and other miscellaneous hardware. We are estimating each unit having a $300 cost. Seven tetrahedral units create the intended design for the inhabitable Spirit House, coming to $2100. However, we will construct as many units as funding allows.  We added an additional $400 for truck rental and other surprise expenses.
For a higher resolution view please go HERE.
And to track the project development, HERE.
 
If the spirit moves you to support the Spirit House at the {Re}Happening, THANK YOU!!! Please let your friends and family know of your contribution to the arts by sharing our campaign.
If you have any resources that might offer us materials at a lower rate or possible donation, that would be amazing.  Please let us know  
If you are unable to support us financially, but want to help 'in spirit', please share our campaign with your friends and family. 
And everyone who can please come experience the entire {Re}Happening event at Black Mountain College on April 6, 2012.
rehappening.com
 
_______________________________________________________________________
 
BIOS:
 
Brandon Pass Architect is an architecture practice located in Asheville, North Carolina that strives to merge modern sensibilities and detailing with the vernacular influences of the region. Brandon Pass Architect is a small multidisciplinary practice pursuing an architecture that recognizes the responsibilities of the built form where environmental, social and contextual factors shape each insertion into a given landscape. Architecture should seek to express a given function through a strong clarity of space and form where the details become expressive and exploratory, respecting the hand of the maker while expressing a connection to a greater whole. The responsibility of the architect, in part, is to be aware of all factors of a given context that may inform the design process. It requires an extensive knowledge of and desire to learn new methodologies creating architecture of the highest quality respectful of both time and place.
brandonpassarchitect.com
 
Informed by a former career in New York City’s apparel industry, Libby O’Bryan creates environments for the contemplation of every­day decisions and cultural norms that function outside the commodity driven marketplace. Although asserting a politicized agenda, the aestheticized temporality of her performative/interactive installations provides incentive for its provocative nature. Drawing parallels between craft, the new art economy, and mass-production, she explores the relationships and of maker, machine, and consumer.
libbyobryan.com
wcsewco.com

story:
Artistic Intent

My name is Michael Luchtan, I am a 34 year old American Composer.  I am creating a prepared piano piece for the Black Mountain College {Re}Happening 2013.  During it's existence, Black Mountain College hosted many influential thinkers, teachers, and students, one of which was the avant garde composer John Cage.  Many of his works were focused on pushing the limits of modern compositional language, and pieces like his Sonatas and Interludes  have the performer 'prepare' the piano, inserting pieces of metal and plastic between the strings, requiring them to treat the piano in a non-standard way.  

As a contributer to the Black Mountain College {Re}Happening, I am planning on installing the gutted harp of a piano on a dock on Lake Eden, in the heart of the old Black Mountain College Campus, and further preparing it over the course of the evening by incorporating feedback from the surrounding environment.  I also plan on installing an information panel explaining the specifics of the evening for the attendees.

 

The piano can be seen as a ready labratory for experiments in sound.  In preparing the Lake Eden piano, I will divide the sound spectrum using input from the evenings environment.  After the instrument has been "tuned" to Lake Eden, the prepared piano will become, at least for the evening, an interactive sonic sculpture.  

We will use experimental methods to discover the resonant frequency, F, of Lake Eden, and will tune the strings of the piano harp to the overtones and undertones of F, arranging the tones in a fractal pattern.  

 

Budget:

* Locating and prepping appropriate piano - $200

* Three assistants to transport and install piano - $300

* Lighting - $150

Experimental Goals

This experiment in sound continues the work of John Cage in expanding the vocabulary of sound for artistic composition by exploring the interaction of overtones between the instrument and the environment  I hope to contribute to the ever evolving palette of sound that modern composers have at their disposal.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute but find the goals of this project interesting, please use the Indiegogo tools to share the word about this campaign to your friends and networks.

story:
After you donate please send photo to spencer.tracy.100@gmail.com

Short Summary

Some of you guys know, some of you do not, I sold my shop in Noble OK in December and everything in it. Sold most of what I owned and bought a RV to hit the road. Well I loaded that RV up with my paintings, art supplies, my favorite records, books, tapes, family pictures, art my friends made for me, a little piano, my ceramic deer collection, and everything else I gave a damn about. Set out and broke down out of state. I had to abandon the vehicle couldn't get anything out and came back here broke. Its now June I have some prang watercolors and a set of brushes I found in a mobile home. Id like to open another shop I found a building with an apartment in the back for 575 a month in OKC enough for a small thrift store art studio space and a back room to put on art shows and concerts. I need to buy stock and secure the building. I got to thinking people are always asking me to draw portraits of them. It's always a bit hard to get together with money and time and such. What if it only cost a few bucks to do a portrait of you? What if al my friends on FB gave me a dollar and I got to get started on a shop?  

What We Need & What You Get

I need about 1600 bucks to open the shop that is rent deposit permits and stock. That not too much between me working at American Eagle and doing commissions. I could open up and be rocking and rolling in no time. What you'll get is being painted into a watercolor portrait with everyone that is donating. I don't know whether it'll be a big or a small painting depending how many of you get into this. However whether its one or 1000 it'll be fun and cool and you'll get a copy and say hey Spencer finally drew me thats cool. Plus whoever donates the most money will get to have the original painting and hey, thats kick ass bragging rights.  

 Other Ways You Can Help

If you cant donate money you could still tell other people to and yell at all your friends and family so they can get in on it. Kick ass. Take names.

story:
The Hokey Pokey (that’s what it’s all about)

Hello! My name is Dmitrious. I’m your average 6’7” giant and this August I’m moving to Montreal, Canada to pursue my dream of becoming a professional circus performer. I’ve been accepted into the BEST circus school in the world: École Nationale de Cirque. I’ve climbed over every obstacle in my path (yes, even couches), and though I am undertrained, I was selected to attend because what I lacked in skill, I made up for in charisma, hard work, and vast potential.

Growing up I was always much bigger than everyone else around me, which was a blessing, but also a curse. More commonly than “Hello” or “How are you?” I was told that I was too big to do all the things that I wanted to do. At 21 I auditioned for the Competitive Dance Reality TV series “So You Think You Can Dance” as a result of a dare from a friend. The result? I appeared on TV and nationally humiliated myself attempting to breakdance. But all was not lost. Something actually clicked that day; rather than giving into the idea that I was “too big” and giving up, I steered completely into the opposite direction and started to train even harder than I had trained before.

After two years of intense training, I was able to control my body and bboy (the right way this time), so I packed up and moved myself to Los Angeles with the idea that I would be dancing there to sustain myself. In Los Angeles, however, I met an amazing woman and mentor who opened my eyes to the idea of training circus. I kind of laughed at the idea at first, I’ll admit. Me? In the circus? That’s crazy!  But it wasn’t long until I knew that I had found my passion—the this was the what I had been searching for all along—a fusion of all of the theatrical, dance, and acrobatic experience I picked up over the years; but above all else, I knew that I had finally found something that I fit into perfectly, a place where I truly belonged, a place where “too big” became “you’re just what we need” and “we’re so glad you’re here”. Needless to say, I fell in love with circus, and now that’s translated through the love I feel as I’m entertaining people and bringing joy to their lives

I love bringing joy and inspiration to people—especially to the kids that I coach. I want to become a professional circus performer. I train roughly 20 – 25 hours a week; this is my life and I love it. Please help my dreams come true. I need 14,000$ to pay for my tuition and the cost of living in Montreal, Canada. The school is closely tied with Cirque du Soleil and working for them is my ultimate goal.

I’m not a freak. What can I do to help?

Please help me train at ENC. I’m a hard worker, I’ve done everything I possibly could to get into this school, but with my current means, paying for the tuition just isn’t possible. I currently work as a circus instructor, teaching circus techniques and performance to my young students, and then perform locally in Los Angeles area (Which all together still means that I barely scrape by L).

Here is the financial damage that I’m currently facing:

The tuition is $7,000 for the entire year. A very reasonable price considering that it’s currently the best circus school in the world and that the Canadian government subsidizes 96% of costs for the school. Thank you, Canada!

But even so, the cost of living will be roughly $700 a month: $500 for rent and then $200 for my food and transportation.

Please sponsor, follow, and support me throughout my incredible journey. Unfortunately I do not have much of a budget for fancy incentives as you can imagine, but I will make you origami (mostly paper animals), send you postcards and headshots, make you videos of my progress, teach you circus, give you hugs, and will eternally be grateful for your kindness. I will make a poster featuring the name of every sponsor and they will be the inspiration to always give it my 150% every day.

If the $1400 is not met, I will still go to Montreal somehow. Quitting is just not in my nature. I am passionate about what I do and giving up is simply not an option. Even if it means that I will be homeless when I get to Montreal; I’m willing to do it. But I really hope it doesn’t have to come down to that.

Giants get old too.

Training at ENC would mean the world to me. They have a strict list of criteria in terms of who gets to attend the school. Besides acrobatics, acting, dance-ability, strength, and coordination, the maximum age to audition is 25 years of age. Since I’m 24, this is actually my one and only chance to achieve this dream of mine; but the good news is that your support can make it happen.

I plan to take the knowledge that I’ll gain better myself as both a coach and a role model to the kids that I teach. I try my best to inspire and to be a constant positive influence to all the children I teach and work with, and this is my chance to prove to them, if not myself, that dreams do come true, and that dreams come true when you reach for something even if it seems “too big” to grasp, or the chance of success “too big” to achieve. I can’t wait to make people smile and spread my love for what I do through performance.

Please donate anything you can, every penny counts. I understand that these times are tough for everybody and that not everybody is in a condition to give themselves. If you don’t have anything to donate, I understand, and I will gladly accept your gift encouragement. If you find yourself in that category, please just pass this along and share it, so that it might find somebody that can. Thank you for reading this!

*GIANT HUG*

(Now I hope that wasn’t “too big” for you).

Sincerely,

Dmitrious Bistrevsky.

story:
At VOX Press, we believe that all artists deserve support, encouragement and, most importantly, a platform from which their voices can be heard. But we don’t just believe; we act.

 

Publishing: Since 2004, VOX Press has worked tirelessly to publish avant-garde writers from around the corner, around the world.  What began as an effort to publish a journal featuring the most innovative artists among us has grown into a full publishing house that produces complete books of poetry and essays, like our upcoming collection of essays about the work and life of Barry Hannah. Your tax-deductible donation of $1,000, less than the cost of one family dinner outing a month, will help us publish one new title, giving voice to an underserved or marginalized writer.

 

Performing: In 2009, we added event programming to our mission – bringing artists together to read, perform, enlighten and enthrall the Oxford community.  The VOX Artist Series has held events featuring the likes of Ravi Shankar, Scott Barretta, John Brandon, and Neil White. With your tax-deductible donation of $250, just $21 a month, you can sponsor a VOX Artist Series Event and bring an artist to Oxford for a reading or performance that is, like all VOX events, made available free to the community.

 

Preparing: This year, we are proud to announce that VOX Press is taking the next step in community outreach by adding an educational outreach program that offers after-school programming and writing workshops at the North Mississippi Regional Center. For as little as $20, you can help purchase notebooks and supplies for VOX after-school programming; programming that prepares children for creative and critical thinking and helps give a voice to those with special needs.

 

We need your help to raise the $10,000 required to fully fund our programs this year. Become a proud sponsor of VOX Press now. Your generosity today will help the avant-garde arts thrive tomorrow.

story:
Athens 10/07/2012

The Eternal Internet Brotherhood is an initiative for a 5 day collaborative camp. It is a program of holidays featuring activities and events  that will take place between the 9th to the 15th of August 2012 on the greek island of Anafi. This aegean island is located on the south-east edge of the Cycladic cluster and can be reached only by boat.

  This initiative will host artists, curators, writers and friends working on or dealing with the vast landscape of internet culture. This is an international group, coming from different parts of the world but collectively part of a compact online community who believe that the creative integration of the offline and online modes of well-being can spark a liberated intellectual evolution and reveal an all-union of disciplines. I invited people whose work expands notions of communication, distribution, dissemination, compression and simultaneity.

  The participants will evaluate and activate ideas of deeper spiritual virtuality, explore and invent new visual codes and behavoural modes, using the island itself as an interface: a new consciousness of time and space. We aspire also to compare Internet social conventions to actual space, minimizing or maximizing the intervention of technology.  

Participants are free to realize their projects in any medium: from a workshop to a lecture to a performance to an installation to a video to a website to an mp3, anywhere on the island: by the beach, by the bar, underwater, in the monastery.  

The Eternal Internet Brotherhood will provide a “space” of total intellectual liberty and will act as a post-privacy outpost. We will escape from the visual provincialism of technology within which we now live in a meta-internet corporeal idyllic context


Angelo Plessas, 2012

more info here

About This Campaign

The Eternal Internet Brotherhood is an artist-run initiative. This means that we are doing this without the support of an institution or any state funding. This has to do with the specifics of the context [Greece in crisis as a microcosm or natural exemplar for the precarity of global hypercapitalism in liquid modernity] but also to do with a shared conviction that funding bodies carry their own agenda which often ends up curtailing artistic autonomy. Most of the artists taking part are not part of the object art economy, preferring to practice in more distributed ways: using our bodies or furnishing spaces or experimenting with new forms of image-making online. We build our community in the mould of Web 2.0; open source sharing, wikiesque knowledge distribution, an economy of affect; in this spirit, we seek assistance from our friends, peers and critics in helping us build an IRL model of the gift economy. 

The money is going towards food and accommodation for the artists while in Anafi. We are partially funding ourselves, as we see this as an important part of setting up an initiative - covering our own travel and a portion of our expenses. But to make it possible for this to work well, we need your help! Please donate generously for the good of post-internet generations to come. 

List of participants (list under construction)

Amalia Ulman  (ES)

Amateur Boyz (GR)

Andreas Angelidakis  (GR/NO)

Angelo Plessas  (GR/IT)

Billy Rennenkamp  (US)

Dora Maja DM (DE) 

Georges Jacotey (GR)

Harry Burke  (UK)

Jesse Darling (UK)

Katerina Kana (CY)

Maria Hassabi (US)

Miltos Manetas  (GR/IT)

Mona Mahall and Asli Serbest (Junk Jet magazine ) (TR/DE)

Paolo di Landro (IT)

Pegy Zali  (GR)

Petros Moris (GR)

Priscilla Tea (IT)

Rafael Rozendaal (NL)

Rozsa Farkas (UK)

Travess Smalley (US)

Vincent Charlebois (CA)

story:
En cette période difficile, plusieurs artistes de nos communautés ne peuvent exercer leur métier.

Nous comprenons et respectons cette nécessité imposée par notre gouvernement et sommes de tout coeur avec les victimes et l'entourage des personnes touchées directement par le COVID19.

Cette collecte de fonds a pour but de soutenir les artistes drags de Québec qui doivent faire face a la fermeture de leurs lieux de travail. 

Une partie importante de la communauté drag n'a pas d'emploi de jour et est confrontée de façon soudaine a cette réalité.

Suite au succès des dernières éditions nous vous proposons donc un deuxième spectacle virtuel ce mardi, 5 mai, 2020  20H sur Youtube et possiblement, d'autres événements.  Nous ne manquons pas d'imagination!

Les artistes se sépareront les recettes de cette collecte de fonds. 

L'animation et la technique se feront de manière bénévole.

Merci de votre support! C'est grandement apprécié.

C'est grandement apprécié.

story:
Our Team  

The Puzzle Factory Collective is made up a fluid and growing number of volunteers who handle things from social media promotion, event organizing, stage management, gallery curation, and more. Some of these people include, 

  • Justin Arena - Printmaker, Musician, and Show Organizer
  • Ian Garland - Music Promotion, Podcasting, and Show Organizer
  • Brian Fitzgerald - Stop motion Animation, Musician, Music Promotion
  • Devri Goodspeed - Fiber Arts, Workshop Organizer 
  • Brian Huntress - Multi Disciplinary Arts, Show Organizer, Music Promotion 

This represents some of the core group but in no way reflects the extent of our ever growing and irreplaceable number of show goers, volunteers, artists, and musicians. 

What We're Asking 

Here is our goal in more detail:

  • We are asking for $1,500 in donations to get this project off of the ground. This is a flexible goal but this is the optimal number. This money will contribute to the first and last month's rent, and security deposits for the new store front. It will not pay for our time, resources, or personal compensation. This space will be artist owned and operated and funded completely out of pocket by its residents. 
  • Your reward for donations are listed in the options below. These will include all types of options like handmade art, fibers, and/or other band or collective merch. See below for the detailed list. 
  • If we don't reach this goal, the collective will be paying out of pocket for the remaining expenses. This campaign's success will be a massive victory not just for us as a collective but for the Rockland art community as a whole. We plan to welcome artists of all kinds to participate in our future shows, workshops, and events. Regardless of how this goes, we eternally grateful for any help we receive. 

The Puzzle Factory's End  

We existed as a DIY venue, community art space, and an unofficial gallery before this current project began. We are SO grateful for all of the opportunities our former location gave us but we've felt for a while thats its time to bring our operation into a more public and accessible place. We cannot yet reveal the exact location of the new space as we're still dotting our I's, but we will soon be operating in a beautiful 1,250 sq ft. store front in Rockland. We are SO excited for all of you to see the new space and to take part in the amazing things we will soon build.

Risks & Challenges

As stated before, this art space will be artist owned and operated, which means that we will rely heavily on the community's generosity for our long term sustainability. Many of us know all too well that an artist's income is not always consistent and hard times may come. With your help, we will be doing our absolute best to keep this place open and operating for as long as we possibly can. We will open this space despite any financial setbacks or the success of this campaign. 

  • We believe wholeheartedly that we can fulfill these goals and open a beautiful, community oriented space. 
  • We believe that our community needs a place where its wayward artists and oddballs can flourish without judgement and with total peer support. 
  • We believe that our community will benefit from our presence and we will provide a safe, productive, and unique art space. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this campaign link to your social media pages.
  • Encourage your friends and family to contribute.
  • Join the fun in person once we launch! 

Thank you SO much. 

(written by Brian Huntress)

story:
The Milk Crate

I didn't know what to do when I received a milk crate that contained most if not all of Jonathan's sketchbooks, but on top of that there was a small external hard drive. Most of it was unsorted but after some exploration, it became clear that I had nearly all of Jonathan's artwork, in high resolution. I also had a terrible sense of guilt. I transformed it into a project, as is my traditional way of grieving. This guilt was that I had something that needed to be shared. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the basics.

I have compiled and curated a large art book that not only spans sketches and paintings, but also seeks to, in what limited capacity I have, publish a small amount of an art book that Jonathan had already started work on. This book is being edited by myself and three others close to him in order to bring you the best that we can provide.

The bulk of the work is done. all we need to do is get it published, and an on-demand printer has already been selected. 

The only problem is that the project estimate got more expensive as it expanded. 

We are not selling this book for any profit. What we are asking for is a contribution toward the cost of having it printed and shipping. We are offering multiple ways for you to contribute in a communal sense. Not only can you buy yourself as many copies as you care to, you can also buy pieces of books or shipping for others that may be unable to contribute what they want because of this awful hellscape of a year, or perhaps someone finds this too late that was forgotten.

The End Product

 

Rather than a standard crowdfunding campaign, we are not offering tiered perks. The price is what the price of each book costs to produce and ship in bulk to us. That price point will not change. If we exceed what we are seeking, excess money will be handled in the following steps:

  1. Overall quality improvements to the base book for everyone. Be that better paper, A fancy dust jacket, etc. This will be automatic and you need not do anything to receive a fancier, better quality book.
  2. Creating a small surplus of printed books for latecomers or for emergency replacement.
  3. Anything past what I can get that is suitably fancy and not over the top will be used toward any and all shipping costs to you, where applicable.
  4. Anything past that will buy the editors a bottle of Balvenie DoubleWood 12 year (as is only appropriate).
  5. Anything past that will be donated in memory of Jonathan to a suitable charity, whether it is art or animals.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge is that we do not raise the totality of what we need to publish this. If this occurs, the only hurdle you will face is having to wait longer for a finished product. If we fall short of our goal, the money will still be collected, set aside, and I will continue to contribute until it is met while offering any pertinent updates. 

The finish line of how much this will cost will be in flux until I get the number of books I need to have published, and that idea should form pretty quickly. The initial estimate as I write this is going to be somewhere in the 1800 to 2300 dollar range. When a more concrete figure is known, we will be capping contributions if possible.

I cannot stress enough that there is no profit to be had in this. This is purely a labor of love, grief, and very possibly guilt.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Reach out to people that Jonathan knew that may be interested in this project.

If you can't contribute or need to do so in a different way, email us at Jnthnbook@gmail.com so that we can count you towards the total needed to publish.

story:
Overview

Hello my name is Dave Kang and I am a concept artist living in Toronto. This is the pre-sale campaign for my creation ‘Brush and Blood’. The artwork for this book was a labour of passion completed over the past three years. This campaign seeks to raise funds to pay for the printing of a first edition of 100 hardback full-color picture book.

 

 

The Horror Art Book

I have been a horror fan all my life and I’ve always wanted to create a terrifying horror world of my own. A simple sketch became a full creature, a page of ideas became dozens of bloody paintings...the moment I thought I was done with everything, a new idea had me opening my sketchbook again. After so many sketchbooks and bottles of wine, I've decided to make a new horror art book out of them. BRUSH AND BLOOD omits a few things  but it holds large amount of visions I had for the world of terror. With your love and support, it is my sincere belief that we can finish this book. I'm having so much fun working on it, and I hope that you will love the book as much as I do. 

 

What's the reason for this campaign?

For the past two years I've received a lot of messages from the folks who missed the book sale of Year of the Ladybug. Originally I was just going to print more copies and relaunch the campaign but it was just not as exciting to me. Instead I started working on a new book called Brush and Blood and it will be completed by coming December. Please do note that some of the contents come from Year of the Ladybug if you have a copy of the first book from 2018. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The nightmarish experience I had with the shipping of the first book back in 2018 taught me a big lesson. Instead of copying and pasting the address registered by the backers I must contact each backer individually to confirm the correct address IN ENGLISH.  It will be tedious but it is absolutely necessary in order to do this right. The sheer amount of returned items and reshipping cost made me hesitant to start a new book but my will to create is simply unstoppable. I'm going to treat each shipment as if I'm sending a gift to my aunt oversea. Other risks and challenges? I want myself and everyone to stay healthy and safe.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, you can still help by sharing our campaign through social media. Please help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Thanks in advance for your support!

 

過去2年間、てんとう虫の年の本の販売を逃した人々からたくさんのメッセージを受け取りました。もともと私はもっと多くのコピーを印刷してキャンペーンを再開するつもりでしたが、それは私にとってそれほどエキサイティングではありませんでした。代わりに、Brush and Bloodという新しい本の作成を開始し、12月までに完成する予定です。 2018年の最初の本のコピーをお持ちの場合、一部のコンテンツはてんとう虫の年のものであることに注意してください。どうもありがとうございます:)

안녕하세요 강대웅입니다. 2018년에 판매하였던 이어오브더레이디버그 아트북에 대해서 문의하셨던 분들 생각하며 같은 책으로 다시 런칭하려고 했습니다. 하지만 그러기에는 뭔가…. 재미 없더라고요. 기왕 하는 거 더 좋은 책을 다시 만들자는 결심을 하게 되었고 지난 2년 동안의 새로운 작품들과 이어오브더레이디버그 그림들을 업그레이드시켜서 브러시엔 블러드를 런칭하게 되었습니다. 지금 진행되고 있는 게임 소식은 유튜브로 계속해서 전해 드리고 저는 그림쟁이로서 작품 활동에 집중하겠습니다. 늘 응원해 주시는 여러분들 진심으로 감사드립니다. 책 멋지게 만들어서 곱게 보내드리겠습니다. 스페셜 패키지에 그림을 드린다는 건 프린트가 아니고 오리지날 연필그림임을 알려드립니다!:)

story:
UPDATE: Any Funds raised over the cost of airfare will be given to Nicole and Jonas as a Speaker Honorarium.

Nicole and Jonas became nationally known in 2015 when the book, Becoming Nicole, about Nicole's transition as a transgender teen was published. Soon after, artist, Robert Shetterly, chose to paint their portrait as part of his Americans Who Tell the Truth series. The exhibit at ArtRage Gallery will be the first time the portrait is exhibited.

Nicole and Jonas have become powerful role models for transgender teens and ArtRage would like to bring them to Syracuse to share their story with our community. They will share their empowering story of finding the courage to be their true selves. They are busy college freshmen but would like to come to Syracuse and speak at ArtRage on a Friday in October. All they are asking for is roundtrip airfare from Portland, Maine to Syracuse, NY. Can you help make this happen?

THE STORY
Wayne and Kelly Maines adopted identical twin baby boys, Wyatt and Jonas, in 1997. From a very young age, Wyatt identified as a girl. When he was two years old he asked his mom and dad when he would get to be a girl. The journey for Wayne and Kelly to become supportive of their transgender child wasn’t always easy. At first Wayne, a Republican, Air Force veteran pushed back. Jonas recalled saying at age 9, “Face it, Dad, you have a son and a daughter.” In fifth grade, Wyatt officially took the name Nicole. More complications arose when the family felt forced to file a lawsuit against the twins’ elementary school for prohibiting Nicole from using the girl's bathroom. Nicole's family relocated and sued the school district for discrimination and eventually won.

Always certain she was a girl, she began treatment to suppress male puberty at 12, took female hormones as a young teen and had gender reassignment surgery last summer. She is now a 19 year-old college student who is speaking all over the country about her journey and helping others find their voice in the process. She credits her brother for helping her have the courage to be herself.

In October 2015, Pulitzer Prize winner Amy Ellis Nutt’s book about this family's journey, Becoming Nicole: The Transformation of an American Family was released and became a New York Times bestseller. The book follows the Maineses as they learn to understand their transgender child — and to support each other during the process. In Ellis’ telling, the family’s greatest teacher is Nicole. She knows who she is; it is up to her family to listen. The narrative, which takes readers from a rural town in Maine all the way to the White House, includes bullying, family strife and a landmark court case on transgender rights.

THE PORTRAIT

At Robert Shetterly’s recent unveiling of his portrait of Nicole and Jonas Maines he remarked that “Nicole and Jonas’ courage, commitment, and outspokenness made them perfect models for the kind of people—especially young people—that I want to paint and present as models of courageous citizenship.” “The opposite of courage is not cowardice—it is conformity,” said Robert, quoting Texas writer Jim Hightower in closing. “One of the most important roles that educators can play is to help young people become their true selves and not be afraid to go wherever that might lead.”

Following the exhibition at ArtRage Gallery, the portrait will travel to North Carolina where it will be on exhibit as a way to push back against the state’s discriminating anti-transgender law, HB2.


Watch the unveiling:  https://vimeo.com/178651821

ABOUT ARTRAGE GALLERY

ArtRage Gallery is a the sole project of The CORA Foundation, a 501(c) 3 non-profit arts organization based in Syracuse, NY. Our mission is to exhibit progressive art that inspires resistance and promotes social awareness; supports social justice, challenges preconceptions and encourages cultural change. Our goal is to provide ArtRage visitors with an experience that encourages the breakdown of boundaries so that people can see themselves in the work and then in one another. And that, we believe, is the seed of a movement for cultural and social change.

Wyatt and Jonas, in 1997. From a very young age, Wyatt identified as a girl.
When he was two years old he asked his mom and dad
when he would get to be a girl. The journey for Wayne and Kelly to become supportive
of their transgender child wasn’t always easy. At first Wayne, a Republican, Air Force veteran pushed back. Jonas recalled saying at age 9, “Face it, Dad, you
have a son and a daughter.” In fifth grade, Wyatt officially took the name
Nicole. More complications arose when the family felt forced to file a lawsuit against the twins’
elementary school for prohibiting
Nicole from using the girl's bathroom. Nicole's family relocated and sued the
school district for discrimination and eventually won. 

Always certain she was a
girl, she began treatment to suppress male puberty at 12, took female hormones
as a young teen and had gender reassignment surgery last summer. She is now a
19 year-old college student who is speaking all over the country about her
journey and helping others find their voice in the process. She credits her
brother for helping her have the courage to be herself.
In
October 2015, Pulitzer Prize winner Amy Ellis Nutt’s book about this family's
journey, Becoming Nicole: The Transformation of an American Family was
released and became a New York Times bestseller. The book follows the Maineses
as they learn to understand their transgender child — and to support each other
during the process. In Ellis’ telling, the family’s greatest teacher is Nicole.
She knows who she is; it is up to her family to listen. The narrative, which
takes readers from a rural town in Maine all the way to the White House,
includes bullying, family strife and a landmark court case on transgender
rights.
THE PORTRAIT
At Robert Shetterly’s recent unveiling of his portrait of Nicole and Jonas
Maines he remarked that “Nicole and Jonas’ courage, commitment, and
outspokenness made them perfect models for the kind of people—especially young
people—that I want to paint and present as models of courageous citizenship.” “The
opposite of courage is not cowardice—it is conformity,” said Robert, quoting
Texas writer Jim Hightower in closing. “One of the most important roles that
educators can play is to help young people become their true selves and not be
afraid to go wherever that might lead.”

Following the exhibition at ArtRage Gallery, the portrait will travel to North
Carolina where it will be on exhibit as a way to push back against the state’s discriminating
anti-transgender law, HB2. Watch the unveiling:  https://vimeo.com/178651821
ABOUT ARTRAGE GALLERY
ArtRage Gallery is a the sole project of The CORA Foundation, a 501(c) 3 non-profit arts organization based in
Syracuse, NY. Our mission is to exhibit progressive art that inspires
resistance and promotes social awareness; supports social justice, challenges
preconceptions and encourages cultural change. Our goal is to provide
ArtRage visitors with an experience that encourages the breakdown of boundaries
so that people can see themselves in the work and then in one another. And
that, we believe, is the seed of a movement for cultural and social change.

story:
RECENT WORK:

Here is some of my recent work to give you a better idea of what I am creating:

For more recent work visit my WEBSITE or my INSTAGRAM Profile.

ABOUT:

ABOUT ME
Hello, my name is Valentin Hirsch, an artist based in Berlin. I studied fine arts in Vienna and have been working on skin for 4 years now with the  goal of constantly creating something new.

When I look back now I realize that tattooing was a logical step in my artistic career. Even during my studies, I remember feeling like I was tattooing paper, even before I started to work on skin.


I see myself more as an artist than a tattooist because I am constantly developing my visual voice and the only thing that changed since my studies has been the medium. 


ABOUT SYMMETRIES
In my book Symmetries my goal is to display a series of drawings and etchings that give a significant insight into the artwork I was working on in Vienna. However, the main part of the book is dedicated to my tattoo art.

We wanted to present the tattoos like in a gallery, drawing a connection between tattooing and fine art. As a result, the book’s minimalist design gives the reader space to experience my artwork in a way it has not been displayed before.

Over the last six months my wonderful team and I have been collecting, screening and curating my artistic material from the past few years. Our plan was to document my development as a tattoo artist in an elaborately designed art book that expresses my passion for tattooing along with my large-scale images of my work, my picture language, which I was able to express in your tattoos.

Now we need your help, to bring SYMMETRIES to life. I am offering copies of the book, stickers, and even some super limited-edition prints in exchange for your support, and I will be adding more exclusive perks over the next few weeks. 

Every donation, every pre-order of the book and even every share helps us to spread the word about the project and to cover the costs of printing.


THE SMMTRS TEAM

Hilf mit Valentin Hirsch’s erstes Buch Symmetries zum Leben zu erwecken!


AKTUELLE ARBEITEN:

Hier ein paar meiner aktuellen Arbeiten, um euch einen Einblick zu geben was ich zurzeit tue.

Für mehr akutelle Arbeiten besuche meine WEBSITE oder mein INSTAGRAM Profil.

ÜBER:

ÜBER MICH

Hi, mein Name ist Valentin Hirsch. Ich bin Künstler und arbeite in Berlin. Ich habe in Wien bildende Kunst studiert und arbeite seit den letzten vier Jahren auf dem Medium Haut mit dem Ziel ständig etwas neues zu entwickeln.

Wenn ich jetzt zurückblicke realisiere ich, dass das Tätowieren ein logischer Schritt in meiner künstlerischen Karriere war. Schon während meines Studiums hatte ich das Gefühl das Papier zu tätowieren und das lange bevor ich anfing auf Haut zu arbeiten.

Ich sehe mich selbst mehr als Künstler und nicht als Tätowierer, da ich ständig meine Bildsprache weiterentwickle und das schon seit meinem Studium. Das einzige was sich geändert hat, ist das Medium. 



ÜBER SYMMETRIES
Das Ziel in meinem Buch Symmetries ist es eine Serie von Zeichnungen und Radierungen zu zeigen, die einen signifikanten Einblick in die Arbeiten aus meiner Zeit in Wien, geben. Der Hauptteil des Buches widmet sich meinen Arbeiten auf Haut, den Tattoos.

Wir wollten die Tattoos wie in einer Ausstellung präsentieren und damit eine Verbindung zwischen dem Tätowieren und der bildenden Kunst herstellen. Das minimalistische Design gibt dem Betrachter Platz die Werke in einer Art und Weise zu erfahren, die so noch nicht gezeigt wurde.

Während der letzten 6 Monate haben mein wundervolles Team und ich das Material der letzten Jahre zusammengetragen, gesichtet und kuratiert. Herausgekommen ist ein aufwändig und mit viel Herzblut designtes Kunstbuch über meine Arbeit und meine Bildsprache, die ich in Euren Tätowierungen zum Ausdruck bringen durfte.

Nun brauchen wir Eure Hilfe, um SYMMETRIES zum Leben zu erwecken. Als Gegenzug für eure Unterstützung könnt ihr das Buch, Aufkleber und sogar einige limitierte Drucke erstehen. Über die kommenden Wochen werde ich noch einige exklusive Angebote veröffentlichen.

Jede Spende, jede Vorbestellung und jeder einzelne Share hilft uns, das Projekt bekannt zu machen und die Druckkosten zu decken.


DAS SMMTRS TEAM

AUFKLEBER SET

Inkludiert sind 4 Sticker, unterschiedliche größen von 5 bis 15 cm.
Hinzu kommt unsere ewige Dankbarkeit und dein Name als Unterstützer im Buch.

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

Erhalte eine signierte Ausgabe von Valentin Hirsch’s Buch Symmetries.

Das Buch zeigt Valentins Medienwechsel von Papier zu Haut
und präsentiert seine Tattoos im Kontext der Kunst auf über 200 Seiten.
Gebundene Ausgabe. 25cm x 20 cm. € 40

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

.

21 cm x 29 cm  € 45.

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

+ den exklusiven SMMTRS Siebdruck limitierte Auflage: 50 Stück.

Signierter Druck. 21 cm x 29 cm € 75

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

+ den exklusiven SMMTRS Siebdruck limitierte Auflage: 100 Stück.

Signierter Druck. 21 cm x 29 cm € 79.

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

SYMMETRIES BUCH + SIEBDRUCK II

+ den exklusiven SMMTRS Siebdruck II limitierte Auflage: 50 Stück.

+ den lasergravierten Fuchs auf Holz.

Limitiert auf 8 Stück.

30 cm x 40 cm € 149

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

FUCHS + SCHÄDEL (LASERGRAVIERT) + BUCH

Limitiert auf 8 Stück. 

Lasergraviert in Holz. Gerahmt.
30 cm x 40 cm € 149

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

SYMMETRIES ORIGINAL STENCIL COLLAGE I

Erhalte eine signierte Ausgabe von Valentin Hirsch’s Buch Symmetries.
+ die exklusive ORIGINAL STENCIL COLLAGE I

Signiert und gerahmt. Limitiert auf 1 Stück! 

(30 cm x 40 cm) € 229. 

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

SYMMETRIES ORIGINAL STENCIL COLLAGE II

+ die exklusive ORIGINAL STENCIL COLLAGE II

(30 cm x 40 cm) € 229.

+ die exklusive ORIGINAL STENCIL COLLAGE III

Signiert und gerahmt. Limitiert auf 1 Stück!

(30 cm x 40 cm) € 229. 

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.


RADIERUNG (DRUCK) + BUCH


Erhalte 1 von 6 exklusiven Drucken von Valentin Hirsch + Buch.
Radierung (Druck), signiert. E.A. (Épreuve d’artiste)
Druckbereich: 30 cm x 30 cm.

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

RADIERUNG (SERIE) + BUCH

Erhalte 1 von 2 exklusiven Radierungs Serien + Buch.
Beinhaltet alle 3 Radierungs-Drucke von Valentin Hirsch.

Radierung (Druck), signiert. E.A. (Épreuve d’artiste)
Druckbereich: 30 cm x 30 cm.

Weltweiter Versand inkludiert.

PROJEKT STATUS & WEITERE SCHRITTE

Wir haben die letzten 6 Monate das gesammelte Material gesichtet und das Buch gestaltet. Jetzt sind wir bereit die Produktion zu starten, aber wir brauchen Eure Hilfe.

Eure Unterstützung wird uns ermöglichen:

  • Das Buch fertig zu designen und zu produzieren
  • Hochwertige Materialien zu verwenden sowie hochwertigen Druck
  • Die Zusammenarbeit mit dem Berliner DISTANZ Verlag
  • Weltweiten Versand zu ermöglichen (im Preis inkludiert!)
  • Tätowieren endlich im Kontext der Kunst zu zeigen

Wann werden die "Perks" verschickt?

Wir starten die Produktion der bestellten Bücher, Sticker und Siebdrucke direkt nach Abschluss der Kampagne. Sobald wir die Produkte erhalten, werden wir sie direkt verpacken und Euch zukommen lassen.

Falls es Fragen oder Bedenken gibt, sendet uns bitte einfach ein Mail an info.smmtrs@gmail.com und wir werden so schnell wie möglich antworten.

ANDERE WEGE WIE MAN HELFEN KANN:

Wenn du unser Projekt unterstützen willst aber nichts beisteuern kannst, teile bitte das Projekt mittels des „Share Buttons“ unter dem Video mit Freunden und Familie.

Das hilft uns damit sich die Kampagne weiter verbreitet. Vielen Dank!

FRAGEN?

Falls es Fragen oder Bedenken gibt, sendet uns bitte einfach ein Mail an info.smmtrs@gmail.com und wir werden so schnell wie möglich antworten.

PROJEKT STATUS & WEITERE SCHRITTE

Wir haben die letzten 6 Monate das gesammelte Material gesichtet und das Buch gestaltet. Jetzt sind wir bereit die Produktion zu starten, aber wir brauchen Eure Hilfe.
Eure Unterstützung wird uns ermöglichen:




Das Buch fertig zu designen und zu produzieren
Hochwertige Materialien zu verwenden sowie hochwertigen Druck
Die Zusammenarbeit mit dem Berliner DISTANZ Verlag
Weltweiten Versand zu ermöglichen (im Preis inkludiert!)

Tätowieren endlich im Kontext der Kunst zu zeigen



Wann werden die "Perks" verschickt?
Wir starten die Produktion der bestellten Bücher, Sticker und Siebdrucke direkt nach Abschluss der Kampagne. Sobald wir die Produkte erhalten, werden wir sie direkt verpacken und Euch zukommen lassen.

Falls es Fragen oder Bedenken gibt, sendet uns bitte einfach ein Mail an info.smmtrs@gmail.com und wir werden so schnell wie möglich antworten.

ANDERE WEGE WIE MAN HELFEN KANN:

Wenn du unser Projekt unterstützen willst aber nichts beisteuern kannst, teile bitte das Projekt mittels des „Share Buttons“ unter dem Video mit Freunden und Familie.
Das hilft uns damit sich die Kampagne weiter verbreitet. Vielen Dank!



FRAGEN?
Falls es Fragen oder Bedenken gibt, sendet uns bitte einfach ein Mail an info.smmtrs@gmail.com und wir werden so schnell wie möglich antworten.

story:
HEELLOOO my name is Renaud and I like to draw penises. It still makes me giggle like a four year old… every time. But I’m a grown man now and I gotta get serious. If I want to draw another penis, I have to go the extra mile. 8000 miles to be exact. Yeah, I want to draw, by GPS, the largest penis in the history of mankind. But why do it alone? Something this groundbreaking deserves to be a shared experience. This is why I am starting this campaign, to get other people involved. Can you imagine how cool it would be if the world got together to draw a giant d*ck? This might even be Guinness World Record Big. The previous record for a GPS drawing was a marriage proposal from japan, and it wasn’t even half the size (it was at least half the size, but still much much smaller). Not to mention the hilarity of crushing such a romantic gesture with a c*ck.

I will be doing this with my girlfriend, Arielle and our nameless friend who owns a car… and I invite you to join me. The trip will start on July 24th until august 24th. We Start in Ottawa and rush our way to Vegas, then we have about 3 weeks to drive through Los Angeles, up the West coast to Vancouver. Then we rush back home. During this trip, I will keep you guys updated through vlogs and twitter. If I pass through your city, let me know and we can grab drinks! The full map will be made available.

I have an approximate budget for the trip of 3000$. That’s based on 1200 for gas and 50$ a day for food and shelter. The rest will cover the fees for Indiegogo as well as the cost for the perks. This is a flexible campaign, so even if we don’t make it to 3 grand, I am still doing this. If by miracle we get too much money, I will give whatever profit we make to a charity for prostate cancer.

Spread the word! #Penisroadtrip

Thank you so much
