story:
Lee & Yolande Clark

We are Lee Horus Clark & Yolande Clark.  We are wood-firing ceramic artists, and we have dedicated our lives to art, to clay, to fire, and to our family for many years. We have worked extremely hard to create a home for our children, and a kiln on our own land. 

We have 3 beautiful children:  Horus, 4, Treva, 2, and Felix, 10 months old.

The pottery and sculptures of both Lee and Yolande are recognized nationally and internationally.  We exhibit both in New Brunswick and abroad, and we have both been the recipients of provincial arts grant funding.

Lee Horus Clark has a large sculptural vessel in the permanent collection of the Beaverbrook Gallery, Fredericton.

Two years ago, after a decade of insecurity, we borrowed more money, and finally moved to our home, a 1/2 acre property in the tiny hamlet (population 75) of Queenstown, in rural New Brunswick.  It took us a year to build our Anagama kiln, and many thousands of borrowed dollars for bricks and materials.  We fired the Queenstown Anagama for the first time in August, when our youngest child, Felix, was 2 weeks old.

What Happened?

Although we have experienced considerable adversity in the past, it now seems as though we might be losing everything.  (**Recent *fantastic* developments indicate that actually, everything is salvageable!  Lots of considerable work to be done, but we strongly believe we will be able to save our home, and our kiln will remain!)

Last week, on June 1st, 2013, there was a large and catastrophic oil spill.  Our heating oil tank began to leak, and the oil streamed into the ground behind our house, down the hill, and pooled around our kiln.  

Our water well is located 4 feet from the oil tank.  A stream, that runs directly into the St. John River, is just feet from the kiln, where the oil is concentrating.  (**Thankfully, we acted quickly and so far, we have been able to contain the spill, and protect the stream and the river.  Our well however, has been greatly compromised, and we will likely need to have a new well dug).

We called the New Brunswick Department of the Environment immediately, and we evacuated our family.  

Over the past few days, we have moved our possessions out of our home, as the nightmare has unfolded.  

What Now?

We have been informed by the Department of the Environment that our home is uninhabitable, our water undrinkable, and in order to clean up the oil spill responsibly, the property will have to be excavated.  

We have been staying with friends and neighbours for the past few days, and we will be moving in the next week.

The market value of our home, outbuildings and property *before* the oil spill, was about $40,000.

Conservative estimates as to the cost of cleanup, have started at $200,000 *if* we forfeit the house and simply bulldoze it.  (**No!  Recent developments indicate that we will be able to save our home, and that the costs may run to about $100,000, all told.)

This does not include the cost of rebulding the kiln, which will likely have to be moved brick-by-brick, the land excavated, and then re-built using many new bricks (as only a % of the bricks will not be salvageable).

The most sickening and tragic aspects of this situation is that it seems increasingly likely that the oil spill has affected our neighbours' water supply, for which we are again, liable and responsible.

We do not have insurance, but we have been told that as our oil tank was just a couple ofmonths over 10 years old, insurance would not have covered the cost.

Last winter, we used 1/2 a tank of oil for the entire season.  We heat our home primarily with wood.  The oil was only turned on occasionally, when the temperatures dipped down below what was reasonable for our kids, in the early morning. 

We have been informed that New Brunswick is one of the only provinces in which the oil company does not bear any responsibility to check the condition of the oil tank prior to filling.  

 

Our Objective

Despite the fact that the full cost of clean-up will be much more than $50,000, we are hoping that this amount will be enough to mitigate the very immediate environmental damage of the oil spill, and to ensure that we can protect our neighbours and their water supply.

We are still hoping to somehow salvage our home, and to work towards some day rehabilitating our property.  This will be a long-term project.

But if we do not take steps right now to hire the approved contractors to begin excavations on our property, we will be in contravention of the New Brunswick law, and we could face some serious legal ramifications. 

Many people have suggested that we simply walk away from our property.  If we had had a fire, this would be possible.  In cases of contamination such as this, walking away would neither be legal, nor moral or ethical.  We have to pay, and failure to do so would put us in contravention of the law, potentially leading to bankruptcy, or litigation in court.

 

What We Need 

We need $50,000 to begin the cleanup, and possibly help our neighbours.  Although at this point we do not know what aspect of the cleanup the funds will go to, we give our solemn oath and guarantee that all funds collected here will go towards the mitigation of the oil spill.  The order of priority will look like this:

  1. Protecting or doing restitution to our neighbours *if* it is discovered that their water has been contaminated (either in the form of water filters or the digging of a new well.
  2. Immediate environmental cleanup, in order to mitigate the contamination of the stream and the St. John River.
  3. Environmental cleanup of our land, in order to protect the wider ecosystem. (This would include dismantling our kiln brick-by-brick, attempting to salvage bricks and stone.)
  4. Environmental cleanup of our house: raising the house off the ground, digging out the foundation of our home, removing and safely disposing of all the contaminated material, pouring a new foundation, electrical, etc.
  5. Digging a new water well on our property.
  6. Rebuilding our kiln.
  7. Filing the massive hole with uncontaminated earth.

The entire cost will not be covered by this campaign.  However, $50,000 will get us started, and will also help to show the Department of the Environment that we are taking responsibility, and action, for this terrible situation.  

 

The Impact

We are passionate and committed to our art, and to the land.  We have always used sustainably harvested or scrap wood for our firings.  And the product of our labour, our wood-fired ceramics, are, in many ways, a statement about the beauty of nature, of work, of slowness, and of values that sometimes seem to be fading in our contemporary lives.  

For so many years we have lived on the edge, from the sale of one coffee mug to another.  We have borrowed extensively from our families in order to buy clay, to buy wood, to feed our kids, and to buy our home and property which was the foundation of our hopes for a more sustainable future for our family.

The most pressing issue at the moment however, is to clean up the oil, so that other people, animals, plants and waterways are not damaged any further.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, please consider spreading the word about this campaign. 

Also, we urge everyone to either get rid of oil heating in their homes, or to make sure they do a thorough check of their oil tanks every month.  The devastation that this kind of event can cause, is astounding, and heartbreaking, for individual families, as well as communities.

 

Thank you so much for your help.  We are grateful.

story:
The playa needs a forest!

Imagine, that you lay down in the forest and you look up into the sky. The longer will you stay, the more you will feel immersed, into the living environment around you – you become a part of the forest! 

This experience and our general love for the woods, was the inspiration for our project "Somnium Communis Silva – The Grove of Collective Dreaming". With the magic of movement sensors, mapping visuals and programmable lights, combined with a cozy and inviting environment, we will bring a forest of a very special kind to the playa this year!

 

A hidden grove inside..

From the outside, the "grove of collective dreaming" looks like a giant silver seed that is about to sprout. Where the shell seems to crack, a green glowing mesh starts to spread its way through to the outside. Inside, a cozy, forestry cradle with fine-grained illumination and a projection in the sky of the canopy invites visitors to lay down and huddle up and to explore the comforting and interesting environment. Chilled air, enriched with soothing odors from the woods and a refreshing humidity, seduce the sudden inhabitant to stay in our green, yet mysterious oasis. 

The projected visuals and LED installations, just as the soundscape in the room reacts to the visitors' presence. Your position and movements influence certain parts of the running algorithms that control the lights, projections and sounds, thus giving an immediate sensory feedback to your actions. All your input directly acts within all the other entities in the room, hence creating a unique composition in every moment. Although a mirage of electronic nature, the grove aims to illustrate the imprint and connections everyone has to each other and their surroundings. Our grove is seemingly alive, but every participant who steps inside contributes directly to the feedback of the installation - just like a forest organically interacts with its inhabitants.
 

 

 

We planted the seed, you help us sprout!

While we got most of the project costs covered so far, we run probably short with our funds soon, especially in order to rent a big Truck from Arcata, where we do most of our Pre-Build, to the playa and back. Additionally, we would like to invest much more in our outside decoration and get even more LEDs for the inside, because more LEDs are always better.

– Truck Rental (incl. Mileage/Gas/Insurance) approx. 1800$ 

– Outside Decoration (eg. Nets, EL-Wire) 500$

– More LEDs (Dotstar) 700$

 

The Grove will care for you!

We value any kind of support!

As an interactive Installation, it is difficult to give a clear picture of an experience beforehand with some 3D Renderings. For this very reason, to reward your trust and support, we came up with an assortment of well-crafted perks, to bring you already some physical and functional quality before even hitting the playa! Your support will enable us to create a multi-sensory experience in Black Rock City for everyone and with everyone!

We created a fancy yet functional Dust Mask, with replaceable filters to let you enjoy even the fiercest whiteout. We cutted, sewn and screenprinted a beautiful yellow Scout Scarf with our Logo, to protect you against sun and the wind. Adding to this, everyone who receives one of our pretty Wooden Amulets, can get a water refill at our Grove on the playa! 

To brace you against wind, dust, and the heat – come to the Grove, because the Grove will care for you!

Thank you for your time, consideration and support!

We hope to see you in the dust!

– The Fellowship of the Grove

story:
A Diet of Worms - is a large format, screen printed graphic poem that brings together many aspects of my artistic enquiries, it is an epic semi biographical tale of faith and desire that pulses through dimensions and time. This is my first book it is sixty pages hand printed, hand coloured and hand sewn it is a limited edition of 50 copies. The images and texts reflect my interest in the ideas and mythologies of Albrecht Durer, GG Allin, Claude Lafayette Bragdon, Max Jacobs, Simone Weil and St John of the Cross.

This project was several years in the making and draws on many aspects of my research. I have been a printmaker for 30 years and have printed several books for other artists, but this is my first. I have already printed all the pages. I just need a little help to finish the project to bind the cover and to purchase an isbn number.

If you love hand made artists books about apocalyptic, erotic, fantasy, theology this project is for you !

I have worked really hard on this book and would love to share it with you.

A book is for life - and for pleasure.

 

Perks

Sh*t Bag

The eyes of Argus

1 Day Screen print Workshop

Adams Apple

Risks & Challenges

The risks are low as the book is already, printed, sewn and coloured - I just have to finish all the covers.

Other Ways You Can Help

I fully understand that these are challenging times for everyone financially so if you are not able to support me with money it would be great if you could spread the word online or just send me good vibes.

Thank you for looking.

This is my first book it is sixty pages hand printed, hand coloured and hand sewn it is a limited edition of 50 copies. The images and texts reflect my interest in the ideas and mythologies of Albrecht Durer, GG Allin, Claude Lafayette Bragdon, Max Jacobs, Simone Weil and St John of the Cross.
This project was several years in the making and draws on many aspects of my research. I have been a printmaker for 30 years and have printed several books for other artists, but this is my first. I have already printed all the pages. I just need a little help to finish the project to bind the cover and to purchase an isbn number.
If you love hand made artists books about apocalyptic, erotic, fantasy, theology this project is for you !
I have worked really hard on this book and would love to share it with you.
A book is for life - and for pleasure.
 
Perks
Sh*t Bag

The eyes of Argus

1 Day Screen print Workshop

Adams Apple


Risks & Challenges
The risks are low as the book is already, printed, sewn and coloured - I just have to finish all the covers.

Other Ways You Can Help
I fully understand that these are challenging times for everyone financially so if you are not able to support me with money it would be great if you could spread the word online or just send me good vibes.
Thank you for looking.

story:
Shibari Sanctuary is a 20 foot tall mountain made up of 11 miles of rope hand tied in a geometric web pattern using Kinbaku, or Japanese rope bondage. As you enter the mountain, you'll find a womb-like interior where you can get tied, relax and enjoy performances by some of the best riggers in the world. The project is an exploration of natural highs celebrating that magical tingly feeling that spreads from the back of your neck down the spine to every corner of your body. I've been living in Tokyo studying Kinbaku with my teacher Kinoko Hajime for a year. My teacher and 11 other members from Japan are coming from Tokyo including a 4 person traditional Japanese band as well as a collection of some of the best riggers from around the world to make this project possible.

Size and scale of the project

Kinoko's rope style

We are grateful to receive an Honorarium grant from Burning Man which has mostly covered our costs of materials and tools. We're looking to raise $5000 in order to pay for the last remaining tools and supplies, and most importantly to get a place to store Shibari Sanctuary after Burning Man. We want to be able to store our ton of steel, lights, rigging materials, and tools in order to build a second iteration of the project at a future Burning Man and/or share it with people at another event.

Geometric rope pattern

The rope!

What We Need

The $3500 will allow us to store the project right outside Black Rock City for 2 years. This will give us enough time to figure out what will happen next on the project. The additional $1500 will go to collecting the final tools and supplies we need including a few super tall ladders, additional lights, and mats for optimal relaxation and tying.

If we don't reach our $5000 goal we will have to focus the funds on the tools and supplies and if we are unable to find another storage option we will scrap the materials and recycle as much of it as possible. Possibly getting a smaller storage for smaller materials.

A early test for Shibari Sanctuary
 

Perks

We're putting all our energy into the project and we are sorry we don't have any crazy perks for you =0. But We'll share the experience with you either in person at the burn or though the digital, and printed photos of the installation and build!

 

Please share this page!

Even if you can't donate please please share this page! We still love you!

 

Thank you and see you in the dust!

Kioko's installation work

story:
Short Summary

Pivot Arts is a producing a three-week long summer festival! 

Pivot Arts was born out of a desire to create a home for innovative performance and to make our community a vibrant destination for the arts. 

By giving to Pivot Arts, you gain the opportunity to contribute to innovation in the arts AND make neighborhoods on the far north side thrive. Because of our diverse programming, when you give to Pivot Arts, your dollars are supporting music, dance, theater, performances for children and events throughout Uptown, Andersonville, Edgewater and Rogers Park.

Join us and all of our community partners – from Northern Trust to Lickity Split to individuals like you - and be a part of a unique arts organization. Your contribution of any size makes a difference.

Our annual festival is a celebration of innovation – and what better way to talk about innovation than through the lens of science? This year's festival theme is ART MEETS SCIENCE! It is an opportunity for you to MAKE GREAT DISCOVERIES. 

From May 28 to June 14, the second annual Pivot Arts features performances from theatre innovators Halena Kays and Jeff Trainor, improv masters Storytown, electric house band BAATHHAUS, acclaimed stilt dancer Kristina Isabelle, and many many more.  

What We Need & What You Get

We can't do it without you! We're looking to raise $3,000 for this summer's festival. Your money will go to:

- compensating our artists

- renting equipment including lighting and sound

- creating more events throughout the community, making Pivot Arts a home for new and innovative performance.

We'll respond with our undying love and support! Our prizes range from public acknowledgement and networking, to free tickets, to free songs, and even chances to meet and connect with our amazing artists! 

Join us for any of our events this summer! For more information and tickets go to: www.pivotarts.org/festival

The Impact

With your help, Pivot Arts can become a home for innovative art, not only on Chicago's North Side, but throughout the city. Our goal is to unite and provide opportunities for artists, established and experimental. You can be a key part of that growth.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't donate now. But there are other ways you can help!

- Share our campaign with your friends! Like us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter!

- Come to a Pivot event! We have events for all ages and all audiences that range from free to just a small ticket fee.

- Invite artists to participate!

Pivot Arts is...

Board Members Alyssa Berman-Cutler, April Browning,  Julieanne Ehre, Sarah Gabel, Gretchen Halpin, Mark E. Lococo, Summur Roberts, Kathy Van Zwoll

Associates Katy Collins, Dan Cox, Ali Drumm, Tanya Palmer, Temple Schultz, Chris Thoren, Genevieve K. Waller

story:
Keep Alive the Spirit of Al-Mutanabbi Street!

Welcome to the al-Mutanabbi Street Project, a lament and a commemoration of the singular power of words, seeking to make visible the literary bridge that connects us all across continents, across cultures and the passage of time. We ask what it means when any powerful group tries to erase culture, attack writers and artists, and control the free exchange of ideas. 

On March 5, 2007, a car bomb exploded in Baghdad's historic literary and intellectual community, named for the famed tenth century Arab poet Al-Mutanabbi. Thirty people were killed; more than a hundred were wounded.

Along with the deeply felt human loss, Baghdad also grieved the attack on its cultural center, a place of lively cafes and thoughtful bookstores, of conversations in tea and tobacco shops. The inventory of al-Mutanabbi Street was as diverse as the Iraqi population, including literature of Iraq and the Middle East, history, political theory, popular novels, scholarly works, religious tracts, technical books, poetry, and mysteries; stationery and blank school notebooks could be purchased on this street, along with children’s books, comics, and magazines. While Arabic was the predominate language, books in Persian, French, German, and English were also represented.

In response to the bombing, Beau Beausoleil, a poet and bookseller in San Francisco, put out a worldwide call to artists to respond to this human tragedy and attack on culture. Two hundred and sixty artists from twenty-four countries answered the call, creating original books, some of which you can see in our video: works that reflect both the strength and fragility of printed matter and show the endurance of the ideas within them.


We, artists and friends of the project, now need to raise $12,000 in order to:
- Ship these artists’ books to destinations in the United States, Europe and the Middle East to hold simultaneous exhibitions from 2013 through 2014.
- Send 260 Artists’ Books and 130 Letterpress Broadsides to the National Library of Baghdad to be part of their permanent collection.

Please contribute and help affirm the commonality of al-Mutanabbi Street with any street, anywhere, that holds a bookstore or cultural institution, a place where ideas are disseminated, debated and discussed. Even a small amount will help affirm a connection between this small street in Baghdad and our own cultural centers, and denounce this attack that was an attack on us all.

If you would like to more information about the Al-Mutanabbi Street Coalition Project, visit
http://www.al-mutanabbistreetstartshere-boston.com/.

Al-Mutanabbi Street Starts Here!  And you are a part of it!

Exhibition Schedule for Artists‚ Books 2012-2014
2012
The Westminster Reference Library, Westminster, U.K. - February 27 - March 17, 2012*
The Powell Library Rotunda, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, March 5 - April 30, 2012 *
Salt & Cedar Letterpress Studio, Detroit, Michigan - August 8 -October 1, 2012

2013
The Cambridge Arts Council, Cambridge, Massachusetts, February - July 2013****
The Santa Fe University of Art and Design, New Mexico -January 25 - March 30, 2013 ***
The John Rylands Library, Manchester, UK.- February 6 - July 29, 2013 ****
The San Francisco Center for the Book, SF, California - February 1 - April 26, 2013 *
Gallery Route One, Point Reyes, California, March 15 - April 21, 2013 *
Grafisch Museum, Gorningen, The Netherlands - October 2013- January 2014 *
Center for Book Arts, New York City, in collaboration with Poets House, New York City - July 10 - September 14, 2013 ****
Collins Memorial Library, University of Puget Sound, Tacoma, Washington - August 19 - October 31, 2013
Newark Public Library, Newark, New Jersey, October - December 2013 **
Newark Public Library, Newark, New Jersey, October - December 2013 **


2014
The Pacific Northwest College of Art, Portland, Oregon- January - March 2014**
The Museum of Contemporary Craft - Portland, Oregon - January - March 2014**
Kate Chappell '83 Center for Book Arts at the University Of Southern Maine -Jan 27 - May 1, 2014**
American University in Cairo, Egypt - March 5, 2014 - (ending date to be determined)
Central Library of Rochester, and Monroe County, New York- June-September 2014
Jaffe Center For the Books Arts, Florida Atlantic University, Boca Raton, Florida - October 2014- January 2015


* designates exhibits of 50 or fewer artists‚ books
** designates exhibits of between 100 and 50 artists‚ books
*** designates exhibits of between 100 and 200 artists‚ books
**** designates exhibits of the complete collection (approximately 260 artists‚ books) of an Inventory of Al-Mutanabbi Street

Great thanks for their willing assistance to:
Claudine Jordan, video filming
Jacquelene Ambrose, video editing and original music

Jesseca Ferguson, Mary Laird, Mike Mandel, Lisa Olson, Greg Shattenberg, Elly Simmons, Stephanie Stigliano, Renee Ugrin, Dan Wood, Amanda Williams, Chantal Zakari, artist donations

story:
This fundraiser is still active and in light of the recent election it is more important than ever for this work to be out in the world making an impact. We are aiming for our original goal of $18,500 - which will get this show to it's next destination. Please join us in making this vision a reality. Your support makes all the difference. Thank you.

 

Beauty  -  Humanity  -  Story-telling  -  Connection

The seeds for this project were planted years ago – when I was 10 years old walking down Market street, in San Francisco with my best friend and our art teacher Barbara Marino. That day Barbara taught me to seek beauty in the uniqueness of each person I passed - a profound way of looking at the world.

Each day I use curiosity as a guide to see humanity with a new lens. The sublime often hides in unexpected places. 

Origins and Destinations

Flash Back. I was at the Miami International Airport, stuck waiting for a plane, looking around, and I noticed what an incredibly diverse population was present there. I started to think about how each person has an origin and a destination that is like a thread that leads them from where they began to where they are going. At that moment what I was witnessing was the living tapestry of all of those threads coming together. I felt deeply inspired.

In the past, I’ve done portrait projects working with communities, where people are either living or working together. But in the case of the Miami International Airport, what intrigued me is that it is a sub-culture of impermanence. I started to think how amazing it would be if someone were to document, show each of these different people, each of these different stories, moving through this complex crossroads. In that moment I conceived this project.

So, first I approached the Miami Airport. They said they did not have funding to help, but they would be happy to give me practical support and that they would love to show the exhibition. Next, I found bi-lingual interviewer Mark Menjivar and Anthropologists Francisco Sastre and Allessandra Rosa to assist me at the airport with the interview process. 

I worked on this project over the span of a full year, making six trips to Miami. Altogether, I photographed and interviewed over 200 people. Going behind security, hanging out with Cuban families at the Customs Exit and approaching complete strangers were all part of the process. The generosity of the participants was beautiful.  No two interactions were alike, each person jumped onboard in their own unique way.  The range of folks that we met and got to interact with was vast and ever changing.

An Invitation for a Different Perspective

One of the things I find interesting about being at an airport is that you're in an in-between stage, between your origin and your destination. This exhibit is made to be presented and experienced in that space. 

I’m offering a multi-faceted experience for the viewer.  The portraits will not be displayed in a conventional setting or a conventional way.  What I envision for the final exhibition is to have 43 of the portraits and interviews printed large-scale on transparent material. They will be hung in front of the terminal windows so that the viewer will actually be able to see through the suspended photographs.

The large images will have a ghostlike quality to them, suggesting the presence and essence of the people that came before on their journeys. Each portrait will have their corresponding interview displayed next to it, giving them identity. Rather than being nameless faces – each person will have a story. 

This exhibition also welcomes awareness of the viewers’ own presence within the dynamic cultural landscape. It welcomes curiosity - and it might get the viewer to look at the person next to them with new eyes. It welcomes belonging – to feel connected to humanity at large.

Your Help Makes All the Difference

Your support will expand this project from a self-funded, self-promoted labor of love to a larger community effort. Teaming-up with you will give “Origins and Destinations” the wings it needs to reach the audience it is seeking, and make an impact.

The money raised during this campaign will go directly to produce the “Origins and Destinations” exhibition. This includes: printing 43 of the portraits large scale, applying them to plexiglas, installing them at the airport, transcribing, editing, translating and printing the corresponding interviews and getting the whole exhibit shipped from San Francisco, to Miami and back. Any money raised beyond my Indiegogo goal will go toward building a website and putting the exhibition up at new locations - so that it can continue to reach a larger global audience.

Any amount you can give will be greatly appreciated. : ) 

Thank you for taking the time to watch my video and support this “Origins and Destinations” campaign. If you can't contribute monetarily, please help get the word out - tell a friend, pass it along through Facebook, Twitter etc. You can even use the tools right on this Indiegogo page to share. 

Your support on all levels adds tremendously to the realization of this exhibition and the spirit of global community and connection it aims to achieve. Thank you ALL from the bottom of my heart.

Budget $18,500

  • Portraits: 43 printed large-scale and applied to plexi @ $285 each = $12,255
  • Hardware for Installation @ $22 each x 43 = $946                 
  • All Interviews Transcribed  $610
  • Interviews printed for exhibition @ $16 each x 43 = $688           
  • Crating and shipping costs for exhibition @ $815 each way = $1630
  • Indiegogo fees $1740
  • Cost for Perks $950

Thank you

It takes a community to bring an undertaking like this to life. “Origins and Destinations” has come this far thanks to the practical help, moral support and encouragement of: My Mom Arlene Wiltberger, Jeffrey Vroom, Cynthia and Jeff Gneiser, Hailey and Craig Dillon, LaCie Corporation, Six Seconds, Francisco Sastre, Florent at Dezign with a Z,  Mark Menjivar, Yolanda Sanchez, Victoria Bogdan, Allessandra Rosa, Matthew Pendergast, Kip Baldwin, Jim Berger, Matthew Wakem, Slim, Kimowan Metchewais, Carolina Salazar, Jane Jones, Hugh and Mary Behm-Steinberg, Karen Stone McCown, Josh Freedman, Claire and Tom Mills, Sabrina Ferrand, Ed Yarbrough, Carlos Arrieta, Sofia Kanavle, Kenan, Jaymie and Solah Malik, Jessica James, David Ventura, Genevieve Walker, Michelle Charles, Sigal Gerber, Ann Jastrab, Mikkel Aaland, Roger Minick, Guru Khalsa, Ben Baum, and Jim Campbell. Thank you ALL.

The “Origins and Destinations” project and exhibition are dedicated to Barbara Marino, my beloved elementary school Art Teacher - I am forever grateful to her.

About Laena    /   Wildervision

For Laena Wilder, photography not only opens dialogue, but it also creates a thought-provoking record. With an under-graduate degree in documentary photography and a Masters of Fine Arts Degree from the University of North Carolina, Wilder uses the camera as a tool for gathering cultural information and facilitating exchange within racially diverse communities.

Wilder’s photographic projects include several ‘kids with camera’s’ projects she created and executed that promote diversity and cultural understanding within communities from North Carolina to Durban, South Africa. Her efforts have earned her a prestigious Rockefeller Fellowship Grant and her visual research has taken her around the world.

Exhibitions of Wilder‘s photographs have been displayed internationally and domestically including: SECCA – the South Eastern Center for Contemporary Art, the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, the Kostroma Municipal Gallery in Russia, and Foto Gallerie in Hong Kong among others. Her work is in several private and corporate collections including San Francisco’s Modernism Gallery and the Gap Corporate Art Collection.

Laena cherishes her many years of experience as an educator. Her curricula have included several practical, conceptual, and historical photography courses taught at Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies, the University of San Francisco, the Academy of Art University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

Wilder teamed up with Anthropologist Mary Strong and the University of Texas Press to produce a very distinctive textbook: Viewpoints, Visual Anthropologists at Work. This book introduces future anthropologists, photographers, and documentarians to the practical, ethical, and cultural issues that arise while working with a camera in the field

Wilder’s projects have garnered generous financial and material support from the Polaroid Corporation, the Rockefeller Foundation, UCIS - the University Center for International Studies, the Epson Corporation, LaCie, Ritz Camera’s, Central Carolina Bank, The Konica Corporation and Community 2000, a division of the Civil Rights Organization.

www.wildervision.com

It welcomes belonging – to feel connected to humanity at large.Your Help Makes All the DifferenceYour support will expand this project from a self-funded, self-promoted labor of love to a larger community effort. Teaming-up with you will give “Origins and Destinations” the wings it needs to reach the audience it is seeking, and make an impact.The money raised during this campaign will go directly to produce the “Origins and Destinations” exhibition. This includes: printing 43 of the portraits large scale, applying them to plexiglas, installing them at the airport, transcribing, editing, translating and printing the corresponding interviews and getting the whole exhibit shipped from San Francisco, to Miami and back. Any money raised beyond my Indiegogo goal will go toward building a website and putting the exhibition up at new locations - so that it can continue to reach a larger global audience.Any amount you can give will be greatly appreciated. : ) Thank you for taking the time to watch my video and support this “Origins and Destinations” campaign. If you can't contribute monetarily, please help get the word out - tell a friend, pass it along through Facebook, Twitter etc. You can even use the tools right on this Indiegogo page to share. Your support on all levels adds tremendously to the realization of this exhibition and the spirit of global community and connection it aims to achieve. Thank you ALL from the bottom of my heart.Budget $18,500
Portraits: 43 printed large-scale and applied to plexi @ $285 each = $12,255
Hardware for Installation @ $22 each x 43 = $946                 
All Interviews Transcribed  $610
Interviews printed for exhibition @ $16 each x 43 = $688           
Crating and shipping costs for exhibition @ $815 each way = $1630
Indiegogo fees $1740
Cost for Perks $950
Thank youIt takes a community to bring an undertaking like this to life. “Origins and Destinations” has come this far thanks to the practical help, moral support and encouragement of: My Mom Arlene Wiltberger, Jeffrey Vroom, Cynthia and Jeff Gneiser, Hailey and Craig Dillon, LaCie Corporation, Six Seconds, Francisco Sastre, Florent at Dezign with a Z,  Mark Menjivar, Yolanda Sanchez, Victoria Bogdan, Allessandra Rosa, Matthew Pendergast, Kip Baldwin, Jim Berger, Matthew Wakem, Slim, Kimowan Metchewais, Carolina Salazar, Jane Jones, Hugh and Mary Behm-Steinberg, Karen Stone McCown, Josh Freedman, Claire and Tom Mills, Sabrina Ferrand, Ed Yarbrough, Carlos Arrieta, Sofia Kanavle, Kenan, Jaymie and Solah Malik, Jessica James, David Ventura, Genevieve Walker, Michelle Charles, Sigal Gerber, Ann Jastrab, Mikkel Aaland, Roger Minick, Guru Khalsa, Ben Baum, and Jim Campbell. Thank you ALL.The “Origins and Destinations” project and exhibition are dedicated to Barbara Marino, my beloved elementary school Art Teacher - I am forever grateful to her.About Laena    /   WildervisionFor Laena Wilder, photography not only opens dialogue, but it also creates a thought-provoking record. With an under-graduate degree in documentary photography and a Masters of Fine Arts Degree from the University of North Carolina, Wilder uses the camera as a tool for gathering cultural information and facilitating exchange within racially diverse communities.Wilder’s photographic projects include several ‘kids with camera’s’ projects she created and executed that promote diversity and cultural understanding within communities from North Carolina to Durban, South Africa. Her efforts have earned her a prestigious Rockefeller Fellowship Grant and her visual research has taken her around the world.Exhibitions of Wilder‘s photographs have been displayed internationally and domestically including: SECCA – the South Eastern Center for Contemporary Art, the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, the Kostroma Municipal Gallery in Russia, and Foto Gallerie in Hong Kong among others. Her work is in several private and corporate collections including San Francisco’s Modernism Gallery and the Gap Corporate Art Collection.Laena cherishes her many years of experience as an educator. Her curricula have included several practical, conceptual, and historical photography courses taught at Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies, the University of San Francisco, the Academy of Art University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.Wilder teamed up with Anthropologist Mary Strong and the University of Texas Press to produce a very distinctive textbook: Viewpoints, Visual Anthropologists at Work. This book introduces future anthropologists, photographers, and documentarians to the practical, ethical, and cultural issues that arise while working with a camera in the fieldWilder’s projects have garnered generous financial and material support from the Polaroid Corporation, the Rockefeller Foundation, UCIS - the University Center for International Studies, the Epson Corporation, LaCie, Ritz Camera’s, Central Carolina Bank, The Konica Corporation and Community 2000, a division of the Civil Rights Organization.www.wildervision.com

story:
Is This Thing On...?

Hello and thank you kindly for taking the time! My name is Doc Diventia, or perhaps more familiar a name, Shane Frost. NO! NOT THE PORN STAR! I am a dedicated creature concept artist whom often reflects their work with the abstract and the unusual. In turn this also drew distinct abstract and usual worlds as well within my mind. I have believed in the quality of subjective meaning as well the fantastical visions of other worldly display, and really I just love to portray and reflect upon the work I continue. With over Ten different galleries and a host of projects I've undertaken down the years, I have lead myself to the most glorifying of all ventures! The realm of children books...but for adults!...who might be kids!...again.

But Doc, Why would we give you money?

I'm really glad you asked, representation of possibly one of you. Well Here's the thing, I've been working on a most fascinating and strange book for a little while. It hits a bit right here, my chest I mean, where my heart is. Let me show you! If I could just...where is....Christ, help me.

I'm not the best with titles alright? What I am alright with however is weird  adventures! This is where you giving me money comes in. I want to make this book a reality on real paper. Paper that I can damage and rough up real good and then force others and you to read. It will be weird. It may not have a point and It won't appeal to cephalopods. It will be weird though, I mean that.
 

 Okay well what kind of book is it really?

Doc Diventia's Book For Kids Who Are Now Adults But Might Be Kids...Again. Is a children's book styled art novel with multiple short visual stories ranging from stress disorder with social anxiety to learning Numbers with a horrible being beyond human comprehension. Each slice of a tale can have multiple meanings, sometimes no meanings at all. It can be inspiring and then depressing, but let's look on the positive with a few examples below!

Well that was weird.

I know, right? It only gets more weird, or normal for some of you very special people. I need your help though because I can make the book big, bigger even. With the intent to eventually Publish it and just throw money at whoever I can to make printed copies, I want to make this book happen. With your help we can see a weird kind of book with even more abstract  tales come into the hands of many and who knows, we might do more good than we're about to do bad!

So What Does All The Money Go Into?

STOP ASKING SO MANY QUESTIONS THAT I CANT- ... I mean... All pledges made will go absolutely into production and printing coverage costs necessary to produce high quality physical copies of the book! Besides what is taken out by these leeches, every single penny is going into these things. I'm not in this for making a profit. I'm not asking for your help because I want to eat ( even though I really, really want to right now. ) I'm asking, even pleading because it's a dream to me. A dream to see what this can be and chase it. 

 Let's be real for a second.

I know I come  rather off the beaten path and lord help me that's probably true. What I am though is an artist and in many ways still a human finding his way among the rest of you. With this outreach I am extending my hand out to you all and doing the one thing that terrifies me most. Making contact.

  I  know I cannot offer like others with extravagant rewards and showy givings that pat you on the head and make you feel like you got the collector's edition....but... what I offer is the fullest of my appreciations for the first run I've ever made as a timid artist. Offering the chance of companionship as we make this book happen and above that, offering the chance to see yourself in it's pages for others to see as well. I know we can do this, I've my heart set on it and the biggest reward to myself is just seeing it through for the first time.  

OKAY NOW THE REWARDS!

Just because they may not be big time, doesn't mean I'm skimping out altogether. There needs to be incentives, there needs to be draw. Allure, my own special kind of way to thank all of those who even look at this thing without spitting on me. That's why I'm going into this head first with my fists open air. How? Why, raffles of course.

Unlike the perks listed off to the side, these are their own separate rewards altogether. Let's cut into the turkey however and explain how this goes down.

* These rewards are dependent upon the success of funding goals.

Up To Three Raffles can be held in honor of those that have helped make this happen.

Raffle #1 $250 Met- One original character of the winner's choice to be placed on one of the many pages. Or just you...you know..if you're not so original... It could be anywhere. Doing anything. Spooky. They'll also be done in the style of the story! Even more spooky! Your character as well you will be credited on the special thanks page so you don't sue! Spookiest!

Raffle #2 $500 Met-  One original character of the winner's choice in a short story. ( 4-5 Pages, even more. I'm crazy. ) You can whisper in my ear the theme you would wish for or you can let me go wild with it. May be good, may be bad for you.

Raffle #3 $1000 Met- I will find someone to produce a hard cover version of the complete book, ship it to myself and damage it in various ways ( The way it was meant to be )  then ship it to you, the winner. shipping on me. It will be one of a kind ( Unless you count Patreon but I STILL STAND BY MY WORDS ), you lucky person you! * This one might take a small bit to get worked out so don't freak. I got your back!

The Risk

Yes, there is that horrible word. I want to erase that thing. Makes all of this seem like I'll drag you all to hell for even assisting me. Relax, I'm going alone. There are always risks when it comes to any project, whether it's inside or outside. For me it would be the outside. I could be screwed over by bad publishers, the guys handling print might suddenly have amnesia and forget I placed an order and threw money at them. A world of issues in the infinity numbers. We're not about numbers though are we? No, we're about seeing this happen. Let's be positive!....right?

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not have the wallets for all this. Some of you may despise children's books and think I'm the next Hitler for even having a go at this. Regardless of your situation or disposition, there is a way to benefit myself even without the use of your wallet or hearing you curse me to the high heavens and lowest hells. Spread the word. Spare a link, take a minute or two just to nudge others along here. They may hate it as much as you do or even love it as much. With that being said, I hope we can make all this work come together in a glorious flaming wreck!

story:
outoftheCUBE is an online platform to promote the work of early career contemporary South African artists

www.outofthecube.co.za

  • outoftheCUBE is our passion and to date, has been completely self-funded by us - the co-founders Mandy Conidaris and Kevin Sneider! 

  • this project has developed out of Mandy's five years of lecturing in the UNISA Visual Arts department, where at year-end she became despondent that so many talented graduate students had nowhere to go to show their fresh and thought-provoking work. At the same time, as a collector of contemporary South African art, Kevin recognised the huge need for support for new artists ...

  • ... so together we conceived the website outoftheCUBE as a stepping stone for early career artists by providing an online facility for them to hold solo exhibitions. Much of these artists' work is cutting edge, conceptually strong, and made with great integrity, yet is often non-commercial at this stage in their careers.

  • through outoftheCUBE, the artists are able to direct their own networks of peers, supporters and other interested parties to their online exhibitions as a way of promoting their work within the context of other contemporary South African artworks.

  • see below for two testimonials from artists who have exhibited with us.
  • to provide increased exposure for our artists, we have committed to exhibiting the outoftheCUBE platform at the Johannesburg Turbine Art Fair (TAF14).
  • by contributing, you will assist us in promoting the outoftheCUBE platform. This will enable us to offer even more exhibiting opportunities to early career artists.  


what we need & what you get

  • we would like to cover our exhibiting costs at TAF14, which total beyond our campaign goal of USD 1 800.
  • the cost of the booth rental and extras at TAF14 is USD 1 200; our framing costs amount to USD 400 - the framer has subsidised us considerably here; and the balance will cover other miscellaneous costs.
  • anyone who contributes USD 15 or more will receive an artwork! everyone will receive a big 'THANK YOU!' on our Facebook Campaign page.
  • should we not receive our entire goal, we will distribute the funds proportionally.

challenges we have faced

  • outoftheCUBE is a unique concept within the South African art world.
  • this uniqueness has created two significant challenges: developing professional credibility in an art world more used to looking at art in a physical space; and looking for ways to encourage this new way of viewing contemporary art. A main obstacle here has been that being web-based, we are not able to communicate in person with the viewer. 
  • although we have been operating for 15 months, much of this time has been spent in research, meeting with artists, and making the site content heavy with work we feel is representative of contemporary art-making in our country.
  • at this point, we feel we are ready for our first solo Art Fair exhibition. The TAF14 exposure will enable us to begin addressing the above challenges by engaging with people about our project face-to-face and showing them how to navigate the website.
  • outoftheCUBE has just started a professional relationship with Mashauri, an online organisation that helps start-up businesses with strategic planning. http://www.mashauri.com/about/overview 

other ways you can help

  • we understand that not everyone can aid us financially, but we'd appreciate your sharing our campaign with anyone you know who may be interested.
  • other forms of assistance would be that you visit our site regularly and follow us on Facebook and Twitter (links on site),
  • and you could pass on word of our campaign via the Indiegogo share tools!

                                                      and that's all there is to it!

TESTIMONIALS

I have thoroughly enjoyed my relationship with Mandy Conidaris and Kevin Sneider, especially because of their innovative ideas in creating their virtual platform to represent and provide much needed support to new and upcoming artists.

Mandy is to be commended for her outstanding professionalism in curating my very first online show. outoftheCUBE’s approach in putting together an exhibition in a virtual space demands no less effort and work than putting together a physical exhibition. I believe that their commitment will contibute a great deal to the company’s future success.

To express my appreciation for Mandy and Kevin’s exceptional work, I have donated five of my photographic prints toward their Crowdfunding Campaign cause to be used as perks.

Yolanda Warnich - artist


outoftheCUBE's on-line curation is one of a kind: thought-provoking and executed with integrity, care and compassion towards exhibitors. As such it is a not to be missed opportunity for artists to expose their work on a worldwide platform without becoming one of the masses.

Emma Willemse - artist and contract lecturer, Visual Arts (Cape Town), Dept of Art History, Visual Arts and Musicology, University of South Africa (Unisa)

story:
Where We've Been

Two years in the East Bay art scene has taught us a great deal, and now, with 6 events under our belt, we are looking to go the next step. 

Our first show included a gallery and some food, and a host of open studios.  Since then we have added a design bazaar, fashion shows, a theater, more open studios, free BART shuttles, and much, much more. The attendance has been great, and support from our community has been extraordinary.

What we want to do now is huge: we are pulling together resources for one last time- and in doing so help us launch a self-sustaining show, that needs no fundraisers or outside donations to exist- while still remaing free and open to the public.

Where We're Going

We need $3500 raised to throw the next F3. Beleive it or not, each show costs us this little amount to put on! F3 is an all-volunteer effort, and so our costs stay minimal. Our volunteers are amazing- and it is their fault we can do so much with so little!

Your donation will go a long way- our expenses go primarily to transportation- our event shuttles, security and event insurance- but out of that you'll get to help ensure that we have a ton more of these in the years to come! 

F3 is a unique experience- get a first hand look at a thriving arts community, buy some cool stuff, check out the latest works of our residents and guest artists from around the Bay Area- all around, a fun and cheap night for everybody.

Donors will receive F3 stuff- Stickers, Magnets, T-Shirts, gifts from our residents, and VIP treatment at the event- all just to help out an organization you were already thinking of donating to! See perks below for more info.

The Impact

F3 has a great impact on the arts community- showcasing local art to an area burgeoning with great work, but not enough outlets or access points to get the community involved. This is where we come in- F3 is, and has always been FREE and open to the public, allowing better access to those who might not normally fit an art show into their schedule or budget.

We've done 6 of these shows, so we know what we're doing. Your donation will only allow us to grow and make a better art show!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please post the link to this on your various social networking sites, we are looking to raise this money quick! And we need your help ASAP. 

We also need volunteers for the day of the show- if you think you'd like to help us set up for the event, or work the front desk, or anything else, please contact us at info@f3oakland.com, and we'll get you set up!

story:
Thank you all for stopping by to look at my campaign page.  Many of you I already know, but for those of you who are just getting to know me, let me give you a quick background.  In just under 3 hours from now I will be turning 35 years old.  I feel that at this less than midpoint in my life I have found my passion and one of my true talents.  It has been a circuitous journey to this point but I am confident that I am on the right path. 

This campaign will raise money so I can purchase some more professional photography and graphic design equipment and turn my hobby into an eventual self-sustaining career.  I have seen on a small scale the number of my Facebook friends who have enjoyed or been moved by some of my pictures.  One friend told me she had found peace from one of my photos during a particularly stressful day.  I would love to reach more people and not only give them something beautiful to look at but also also to affect a positive change in their everyday lives.

 

My funding goal is $3160.83.  Anything over that amount will go towards upgrading the camera I am looking at right now.

I have used Amazon.com to price out the things I need to get my business up and going.  Your generous donations will go towards these items:

Canon T2i 18MP SLR Camera $849.00

Apple iPad 64 GB $816.00

Canon Photo Printer $349.97

SanDisk 32GB Flash Memory $32.65

Adobe Photoshop CS5 $599.98

2 packs of Canon Color Ink Tanks $170.04

5 packs of Epson premium photo paper $138.75

iPad case $32.95

iPad screen protector $19.97

Triple tripod kit $29.95

Indiegogo commission  $121.57

 

If I don't reach my goal, I will prioritize the money I do receive and will purchase the camera and iPad first.  

 

For every $25 that you donate to my campaign or for every referred person who donates $25 to my campaign, I will email you the high resolution picture of your choice without the watermark from my facebook page (http://facebook.com/phoenixmetacreations).  For people who are able to donate at the $150 level, I will print out and frame the 5X7 picture of your choice and send it to you.  

 

It is very humbling when a family member or friend entrusts you with their own money to go and pursue your dreams.  For those of you who are just hearing about me for the first time and choosing to donate to my cause, it will be nothing short of inspiring to have you see my potential and give your approval.

 As someone who is using a crowd funding platform, I know firsthand just how difficult these times are financially for many people.  If you are not able to donate money right now, please consider sharing this campaign with your friends and family.  Indiegogo makes it easy with their sharing tools.  Word of mouth advertising is essential to a fundraising campaign like this.  Additionally it also demonstrates to me how much you believe in my work because you shared it with others. 

In a world where we are inundated with negative images, thoughts, and messages, I hope my photos will offer people a respite where they can recenter their mind and soul.  If just a single person takes away something positive after looking at my pictures, your contributions will have helped one small corner of the world be a better place.

Any of my friends and family can attest to the fact that when I find something I am passionate about I see it through.  In my heart and mind, there is no other option but to fully realize this dream and make it a reality.

Thank you all so much.  I truly have the best family and friends in the world.

 

Andrew

story:
About The Project


PY // Art From Parkland's Youth is an art exhibition being put on by Sarah Wise. Sarah holds a BFA in Graphic Design from Pacific Lutheran University in her home town of Parkland, WA. She is currently working towards her MA in Arts Administration from the Savannah College of Art and Design, and this is her final project for that degree. The purpose of this show is to build positive community relationships through art. The students of the local Franklin Pierce School District's two high schools will submit their own original artwork to a jury comprised of PLU students, who will determine which pieces go on display in the Wekell Gallery at PLU. The community will then be invited to a weekend-long exhibition featuring this artwork, showcasing the creative talent found right here in Parkland.

PY // Art From Parkland’s Youth Business Sponsorship

Businesses may contribute to PY // Art From Parkland’s Youth in a variety of ways. The following are suggested levels of participation. Local businesses wishing to support the Parkland community and this project are encouraged to do so in any way they see fit. For more information about the PY // Art From Parkland’s Youth project, Like us on Facebook at facebook.com/pyartshow.

Donations

Monetary donations are accepted. Contributions in any amount will be accepted. Funds will go towards the following:

  • Catering for the gallery’s opening night
  • Printing of all promotional materials for the show
  • Art supplies to help students prepare their work for the gallery space
  • Art-related prizes for students winning 1st, 2nd, and 3rd prizes
  • Any additional funds at the end of this project will be donated to the Franklin Pierce School District for arts education

Businesses making a donation of $30 or more will receive promotion as a “featured sponsor” in the PY // Art From Parkland’s Youth social media campaign. Promotion will include a special thank you to the business and a link to that business’ website (or phone number for businesses that do not have online presence).

Businesses making a donation of $75 or more will automatically receive space in the Sponorship section of the gallery program, which will be distributed to viewers during the show. This is in addition to promotion online through the social media campaign.

Participation

Businesses are also encouraged to participate with promoting the show amongst the Parkland community. There are endless possibilities for how a business may participate in the show. Here are some suggested ways to participate:

Feature student artwork in your place of business. Artwork is a great way to liven up any space, and what better way than to feature artwork from local high school students? Artwork may be installed in your place of business, along with the artists’ name, school, year in school, and information about the PY // Art From Parkland’s Youth exhibition at PLU. Here are the details:

  • You may feature just one piece or however many you’d like, depending on availability
  • Your business will be included as a sponsoring business in the social media campaign online as well as in the printed gallery program at the show

Allow promotion of the show. If you don’t have the space to host artwork, another option may be placing flyers advertising the show in your business. We simply ask that you place at least one flyer in a visible place that will attract customer attention. Do you have a community bulletin board? What about your shop window? Inform the community about the upcoming show, and show that your business is involved with the community and the arts. Here are the specifics:

  • Post at least one flyer; we are happy to provide more at your request
  • Your business will be included as a sponsoring business in the social media campaign and will receive special thanks at the gallery show (please note: special thanks will be verbal during a speech for the gallery opening. This is not the same as being featured in the sponsors section of the printed program) 

Post a link to the show’s Facebook page or blog on your business’ website. We’re happy to accept a little web traffic from your customers! You can raise awareness by featuring a link on your website and informing the community about this unique opportunity. Here are the specifics:

  • Place a link to the show’s Facebook page or blog
  • We will link back to your business in our sponsors section online

Because the purpose of this project is to build community relationships, any form of contribution to the cause is welcomed! If none of these options match your business’ needs, please reach out to Sarah Wise at wise.sarahe@gmail.com to discuss other options. Together, we will find the perfect relationship for your business to support this project. Thank you!

story:
Passionate paintor.

I am a passionate painter who loves the story and beauty in old peoples faces. Been painting since I was a kid and cant stop. I have five years of artschool. In helping me, you will help me accomplish one of my long time dreams. To make a huge carbon painting. 2 meters or more tall. I fell for the expression of this old lady. I believe the final result of such a big painting will be breathtaking.

I have five years of schooling in art,  which doesnt count for much in finding a job so I am struggeling to find one.. So while I apply and am in wait for a job, I can use the free time to create this great image.

The funding goes towards:

The funding goes to a special paper that can handle continous work, it is not sold here in Norway, so I have to have it shipped here and the rest will go to the framing, which is the bulk of the funding.

Once the painting is completed I plan to  exhibit it, and "wow" people with the beauty of age.

For my previous works in carbon; http://asketchaday.blog.com/category/charcoal/

http://asketchaday.blog.com/2011/01/27/539/

 

It doesnt have to be money,  if you know a framer or someone who has paper, that will help too. The best paper for this work is; Canson Fineface paper. Maybe you happen to have a roll of it and you arent using it? I know there are 10 meter rolls sold of this particular paper.

Please spread the word. Any help and support is greatly appreciated and I will keep my funders informed along the way about the process.

You can also find me on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/lynn.moltzau.art?ref=hl

Thank you so much!

story:
I am a young artist who graduated from the ArBA-esa [Brussels Royal Academy of Fine Arts – Graduate School of Arts], and currently an assistant lecturer in the (AesP) [Art in Public Space] studio of that establishment.  This position entails providing advice and support for the artistic approaches of students in creative and software-learning workshops on the question of real and virtual motion picture (video recording and 3D modelling respectively).

aerophagics contemporary is a fictional art gallery.  It questions (on the Web) the visibility and communication of institutions, galleries and actors in the field of art.  In the manner of a semionaut, it conducts a critique of social networks and the art market.  The latter is based on exclusion, because it concentrates exclusively on certain names which become products, the artistic value of which develops for the benefit of the market.  I was determined to create my own “stable” by giving it a name and logo.  To attain this positioning, I created a Facebook page and a stick with the same name affixed on the window of the premises during a stint as artist in residence in Ixelles.  aerophagics contemporary was included in the web page of Ixelles, as the opportunity arose, and is listed as a gallery established on the territory of that municipality.  aerophagics was thus made official and institutionalised, or at least it is henceforth visible “on the art scene.” What started as an appearance or illusion of an art gallery, at least from the outside, has now become reality.

In partnership with the AesP studio of the ArBA-Esa, I shared this project (in 2009-2010) with the students of that studio.  They created avatars on social networks such as Facebook, LinkedIn and Twitter, by providing archetypes on how a gallery should be run “properly” by means of poses struck by aerophagics contemporary employees, artists, and collectors.  This fictitious entrepreneurial assemblage promoted mock discussions (exchanged e-mails) between collecting avatars and non-fictitious artists.  In order not to linger on a misleading false parody of supply and demand, genuine fictional works by artists gradually emerged through artistic productions and constructed identities (biographies, profiles and historical contexts, questions about art, philosophical discussions, etc) to lead to a real, autonomous identity, which continues to develop in cyberspace today by modelling exchange and information and by the note of the principles of interaction.  Some of these fictional creations were consigned on audio and visual media.  All this work can be viewed at the following address: http://aerophagics.com/aerophagics-contemporary.html

I am currently seeking funding to produce a soapbox derby racer of a Delahaye 135M.  If this soapbox derby racer is produced, it will enable me to take part in various soapbox championships in Europe and the world.  Most people who make soapbox derby racers think only of such aspects as aerodynamics, weight and speed.  For its part, aerophagics prefers to focus on such aspects as appearance, shape and visual impact.  In fact, although this project is a virtual gallery, it is still a project that enables me to reflect on the question of entrepreneurship and its dominant form today:  the company.
I have drawn myself all the plans needed to build the soapbox derby racer using an AutoCAD software.  I have created 3D images using the 4D cinema software.  Having no skills to build the soapbox derby racer, I have turned to a former world champion in the field who has the technical tools and expertise to see the project through.
He agrees to make the soapbox and was very impressed by the finesse of the plans I produced.  As he has a numeric control device, the 3D plans that I produced using AutoCAD will enable us to make a true to scale polystyrene mould, i.e. 309 cm x 129 cm x 51 cm.  Once the mould has been produced, we are going to use it to make the body in fibreglass.  To reduce costs, I will see to all the finishing works (painting, lettering, etc.).


These €15,000 will be used to

Produce the soapbox derby racer true to scale

Build the bodywork.
Build the chassis
Finishing (painting, seat, etc..)

Produce two suits with the colours of aerophagics

Produce two helmets with the colours of aerophagics

I will assume the transport costs to participate in the first events.

If the funds I raise are not sufficient to see this project through I will reinvest them in a publication project I am pursuing with a group of young Brussels artists.

 

If you want to see the plans I have produced, you can contact me using the following form: http://www.aerophagics.com/contact.html

I thank you in advance for your kind attention and always at your entire disposal, I remain

Cordially yours

 

 

Jeune artiste diplômé de l’ArBA-esa de Bruxelles, je suis actuellement assistant conférencier dans l’atelier (AesP) au sein du même établissement. Cette fonction consiste à accompagner les démarches artistiques des étudiants, dans le cadre d’ateliers créatifs  et d’apprentissage de logiciels autour de la question de l’image réelle (captation vidéo)/virtuelle (modélisation 3D) en mouvement.

aerophagics contemporary est une galerie d’art fictive. Sur le web, elle questionne la visibilité et la communication des institutions, des galeries et des acteurs du champ de l’art. À la manière d’un sémionaute, elle trace une critique des réseaux sociaux et du marché de l’art.Le marché de l’art est basé sur l’exclusion, car il se concentre uniquement sur quelques noms qui deviennent des produits dont les valeurs artistiques évoluent au profit du marché. J ‘ai eu la volonté de créer ma propre ‘écurie’ en lui attribuant un nom et un logo : aerophagics contemporary. Pour la réalisation de ce positionnement, j’ai crée une page facebook et un sticker éponyme collé sur la vitrine des locaux  pendant une résidence d’artiste  à Ixelles.  aerophagics contemporary a été reprise, par opportunité, sur la page web de la commune d’Ixelles et répertoriée comme étant une galerie d’art implanté sur son territoire. aerophagics contemporary s’en est retrouvée officialisée, institutionnalisée, ou du moins, sa visibilité ‘sur la place de l’art’ était désormais acquise. Ce qui faisait apparence ou illusion, d’une galerie d’art, du moins extérieurement, prenait statut de réalité.

En partenariat avec l’atelier AEsP de L’ArBA-Esa de Bruxelles, j’ai partagé ce projet en (2009-2010) avec les étudiants de cet atelier. Ils ont crée des avatars sur des réseaux sociaux tels que Facebook, LinkedIn et Twitter, en caractérisant les archétypes des identités du "bon" fonctionnement d’une galerie au travers des postures figurées par des employés, des artistes, des collectionneurs d'aerophagics contemporary. Ce montage, entrepreneurial fictif, a donné lieu à des simulacres de discussions (échanges mails) entre avatars collectionneurs et artistes non fictifs. Pour ne pas en rester à une fausse parodie trompeuse, de l'offre et la demande, de véritables fictions d'artistes se sont progressivement constituées  par des productions artistiques et des identités construites (biographies, profils & contextes historiques, questionnements sur l'art, débats philosophiques etc.) pour aboutir à de véritables identités, autonomes, qui, aujourd'hui encore, continuent à évoluer dans l'espace cybernétique par la modélisation de l'échange et de l'information et par le billet, des principes d'interaction. Certaines de ces fictions ont été consignées sur des supports sonores et visuels. Tout ce travail est visible à l’adresse suivante : http://aerophagics.com/aerophagics-contemporary.html

Actuellement je suis à la recherche d’un financement pour réaliser une caisse à savon d’une Delahaye 135M.
Si cette caisse à savon est produite, elle me permettra de participer à plusieurs événement  autours des championnats d’europe et du monde de caisse à savon. La plupart des gens qui réalise des caisses à savon ne pense uniquement à l’aspect aerodynamique, poid, vitesse. Aerophagics préfère elle penser à l’aspect forme, esthétique et impact visuelle. En effet bien que ce projet soit une galerie virtuelle, il n’en n’est pas moins un projet qui me permet de refléchir sur la question de l’entreprenariat et de sa forme dominante aujourd’hui : l’entreprise.
J’ai déssiné moi même tous les plans nécessaires à la réalisation de la caisse à savon via le logiciel autocad. J’ai réalisé des rendus images 3D via le logiciel cinéma 4D. N'ayant aucune compétence pour la réalisation de la caisse à savon j’ai fait appel à un ancien champion du monde dans le domaine qui possède le savoir et l’outillage technique pour mener à bien le projet.
Il est d'accord pour produire la caisse et a été très impréssionné par la finesse des plans que j’ai réalisé. Etant donné qu’il possède une commande numérique, les plans 3D que j’ai réalisé via autocad vont nous permettre de réaliser un moule en polystyrène à échelle. C’est à dire de 309cmx 129cmx 51cm. Une fois ce moule réalisé nous allons nous en servir pour réaliser la carosserie en fibre de verre. Pour réduire les coûts  je prends en charge toutes les finitions (peinture, lettrage...)
Ces 15000 euros serviront à

Produire la caisse à savon à echelle 1

Réalisation de la carosserie.
Réalisation du chassis
Finition (peinture, sticker, banquette etc..)

Réalisation de deux combinaisons aux couleurs d’aerophagics

Réalisation de deux casques aux couleurs d’aerophagics

Prise en charge des coûts de transport pour participer aux premiers évènements.

Si les fonds que je récolte ne me permettent pas de réaliser ce projet je les réinvestisserai dans un projet de publication que je mène à bein avec un collectif de jeunes artistes bruxellois.

 

Si vous désirez voir les plans que j'ai réalisé vous pouvez me contacter via le formulaire suivant : http://www.aerophagics.com/contact.html

En vous remerciant de l’accueil que vous ferez à ma proposition et restant à votre entière disposition.

Cordialement
