story:
Bonjour à tous et à toutes !


Qui êtes-vous..?

Nous sommes 2 jeunes étudiants, Jennifer & Quentin, tous deux passionnés par le théâtre.
Nos chemins se sont croisés il y a 3ans, au papillon noir théâtre à Caen, et depuis nous ne nous sommes pas quittés et continuons de faire notre route ensemble !

Et, que faites-vous au juste..dans la vie..?

Du théâtre !

Nous venons de terminer nos 2 années de formation à l'école de théâtre internationale LASSAAD à Bruxelles. C'est une formation qui se découpe  en deux années dans lesquelles nous explorons diverses formes théâtrales ( Commedia dell'arte, pantomime, bouffon, clown tragédie...) , tout en gardant le mouvement comme base.


A la fin de la première année, nous étions tous les deux très motivés pour monter un projet en duo, alors nous avons profité des vacances d'été
pour réaliser un spectacle de théâtre muet, Mots sans dire, et c'est naturellement que nous avons créer notre compagnie : Le Théâtr'o'QG.
En restant sur la dynamique de l'école ( qui consistait à créer des petits "spectacles" toutes les semaines ), nous avons créer le notre et l'avons fait tourner dans plusieurs régions françaises. Dans les rues, ou chez des particuliers, nous cherchions un maximum d'occasion pour jouer notre spectacle. Et une fois rentrés à Bruxelles en septembre,  nous avons profiter du temps qui nous restait avant notre rentrée pour le présenter dans quelques festivals belges [ La fête de l’Équinoxe au château de Fisenne, et à Murmurez Frénétique à Bruxelles ]. Nous avons aussi été programmé dans un théâtre [ Les MicroFactures à Bruxelles ] !

Et par la suite, qu'est ce que vous comptez faire ?

Notre idée c'est que nous fassions du Théâtr'o'QG une compagnie de théâtre muet itinérante. Nous voulons parcourir le monde et lui raconter des histoires uniquement au travers de nos mouvements et gestes.

L'avantage du muet, et que nous sommes "universel", nous utilisons un langage que tout le monde comprend, celui du corps, de cette manière nous supprimons la barrière de la langue.

Et donc, vous avez besoin de mon aide pour...?

Eh bien ... pour présenter notre spectacle aux Etats-Unis, à Chicago !

Un de nos amis, étudiant à l'école LASSAAD , nous a invité à venir présenter notre travail chez lui. Le fait est, qu'un si grand voyage au sortir d'une école n'est pas évident à assumer financièrement.

Vos dons nous permettrons de bien nous lancer dans ce voyage, et de partir sur de bonnes bases pour cette compagnie naissante.

Cela nous aidera notamment dans l'achat des tickets d'avion pour nous rendre là-bas, et des frais qu'implique un voyage ( passeport, VISA, valises, logement une fois sur place, nourriture..)

Nous pourrons aussi investir dans du matériel de décors, des costumes & des appareils techniques pour nos futures représentations. Votre aide nous aidera également à financer les droits d'auteurs de certaines musiques que nous utilisons pendant notre spectacle.

Une fois sur place, nous ne voulons pas passer à côté d'occasions qui nous permettrait de jouer dans tel ou tel endroit, ou de devoir refuser une résidence ou des lieux de répétitions. Vos dons nous permettrait de financer les frais de location d'une salle de répétition ainsi que les déplacements liés à cela.

Votre soutien sera d'une grande aide pour nous, car vous nous permettrez de continuer à développer notre projet, et à le faire prospérer  !

Avec votre soutien financier, vous contribuerez à la création et la diffusion de notre spectacle ainsi qu'à son bon envol dans le monde du théâtre.

Nous sommes une compagnie pleine d'envie et d'entrain, nous avons le bateau & la voile, aidez nous à faire souffler le mistral  !


Merci de nous avoir lu, et d'avoir porter un intérêt à notre projet.

Si vous ne pouvez pas y contribuer, n'hésitez pas à partager cette page, à en parler autour de vous, cela nous aidera beaucoup !

Merci !

Jennifer & Quentin

Votre soutien sera d'une grande aide pour nous, car vous nous permettrez de continuer à développer notre projet, et à le faire prospérer  ! 
Avec votre soutien financier, vous contribuerez à la création et la diffusion de notre spectacle ainsi qu'à son bon envol dans le monde du théâtre.
Nous sommes une compagnie pleine d'envie et d'entrain, nous avons le bateau & la voile, aidez nous à faire souffler le mistral  ! 
 
Merci de nous avoir lu, et d'avoir porter un intérêt à notre projet. 
Si vous ne pouvez pas y contribuer, n'hésitez pas à partager cette page, à en parler autour de vous, cela nous aidera beaucoup !
Merci !
Jennifer & Quentin

story:
Short Summary

The Minotaur was born to the queen of Crete, after she mated with a sacred bull. The king, Minos, to hide his shame, had Daedalus construct a Labyrinth in which to hide the monster. Minos then forced the Athenians to send as tribute 14 of their young people, seven men and seven women, to be locked in the Labyrinth for the Minotaur to eat. To stop the slaughter, the hero Theseus volunteered to enter the Labyrinth and fight the Minotaur. On the instructions of the king's daughter, Theseus brought in a ball of thread, which he unwound as he went through. He found the Minotaur, killed it, and then used the thread to find his way out of the maze.

  • We are Kim and Chris Cleary from Vermont.  We've been building burnable art for a few years, and have worked tirelessly toward perfecting our craft.  Last year we traveled from Vermont all the way to the hills of Georgia to bring Alchemy a burnable art piece you may remember; Father Time.  
  • Father Time was a opportunity for us to expand our horizons and let other people see our art.  Since Alchemy we've met so many wonderful artists and people, and we'd like to bring another sculpture to burn for Alchemy 2015.  This campaign is to help us get additional funding provided outside of the Alchemy 2015 Art Fundraiser.  We were able to raise $1600, and need $500 more to cover the cost of transportation all the way from Vermont!  
  • By contributing you are making it possible for everyone present at Alchemy 2015 to have a great burnable art experience.  The Minotaur will be 15' tall, and will burn Friday night if we're able to meet our funding needs!

What We Need 

  • We need $500 to cover the cost of transportation from Vermont to Georgia.  Last year we came out of pocket for the expense, but this year we don't have the financial padding we had for Father Time!  Please help us bring our next work of art to Alchemy!!!

story:
"A-BIENNALE (Behold the intangible)" as an art biennial in a form of the book is a reflection on current expanding and inflationary model of the biennials and big exhibitions in general. Its aim is to draw attention toward writing and critically thoughts instead of propagate even more artists, curators, venues, fairs etc. and move the interest to intangible economies within the art market. 

Its main subject is relation of the art work to the (art)world in different notions and contexts of fiction(s), raising a question about its function, relationship and influence on knowledge and aesthetic transformation. Its attempt is also to explore the socio-political as well as cultural and artistic factors that may influence critical judgment of fiction. 

The idea to establish Biennial in written/pritned form was inspired by the fact that over a hundred cyclical events around the world are organized and we are unable to keep the track of everything that happens. Many recipients both amateurs and professionals, feel that those complex projects exceed their perception and capabilities of the human body. Inter alia, for this reason I decided to create a biennale only in a form of its catalogue that gives the event more structured and organized form which, at least theoretically, we can embrace. It is also a kind of counteract the recent expanding and inflationary biennial model (more artists, more venues, more cities etc.).

Therefore the exhibition exists in a material form (book/catalogue) which contains non-material artworks, existing only in our imagination, occupying simultaneously the material space of the book and mental space of imagination constituting its topology, existing somehow without the time and physical space. 

The main goal is to focus on the art world as a medium to create an art work. It brings up the problem of art as a medium in its own right and raises the question whether can (or even “should”) speak for itself? Whether art may be a way to rethinking the art history? 

It is, in some way, a kind of comment on the art world, however, in the same time - another "piece of art". 

"A-BIENNALE" includes the work of both imaginary and existing artists as well as the art works, with participation of over 20 artists, theorists, writers, which are inter alia: 

Eve Andree Laramee, Michael Arcega, Michael Blum, Tim Etchells, John Fare, Dirk Dietrich Hennig, Diego Guiterrez-Valladares, Mikko Kuorinki, Brandon LaBelle, Matthieu Laurette, Matts Leiderstam, Via Lewandowsky, Marcos Lutyens, Sean Lynch, Gabriele Naia, Erik Niedling (with Ingo Niermann), Meriç Algün Ringborg, Tommy Stockel, Pilvi Takala, among others.


Page size: 15 x 21cm / 5,9 x 8,27inch

Number of pages: aprox. 150 

Estimated date of publication: 2014

Publisher: Sternthal Books


The collected fundings will go towards the production and printing of the publication.



[*All the benefactors will be listed in the publication]

story:
SUPPORT ANDRÉ WITH IS NEW PIECE "LAY STILL, IT'S (NOT) OVER"

I'm a Performer and Visual Artist from Lisbon, Portugal, currently living/ studying/ working in Berlin, Germany.

I just completed the 1st Semester of a prestigious Master of Arts program called SODA (Solo/Dance/Authorship) at UDK-HZT, where I've been busy integrating my previous experience as a visual artist into a dance/performance context.
 During the 1st Semester, I've been receiving loads of input from artists, academics, and theorists and I've find myself confronted with many questions surrounding existing notions of art, issues in-forming the visual and performative body, object, functionality and the political/economical status (of an artist) in the nowadays society. 

The Semester was fulfilled with lectures and Intensive Workshops from/with:
 Boyan Manchev, Helmut Ploebst, Noémie Solomon, Frédéric Neyrat (Theory of Twilight Imagination), Isabel Lang, Helmut Ploebst, Litó Walkey (Writing and Research); Sophia New (Performative Writing); Eva Meyer Keller (Creating New Work); Constanze Schellow (The Evil eye of an auditory) and Nik Haffner.

Since July 20, I've been working on "Lay still, it's (not) over" and now I'm out to you to support me and get me through the next steps to continue this work. In October I will present "Lay Still, It's (not) over", in HZT, Uferstudios, Berlin. 


DESCRIBING THE PROJECT 
This project intends to investigate the use of the body in visual writing formulas, establishing relations to action or suspension, being the main focus increasingly on the notions of sharing between performer/audience as well the space created for that (shared) situation to happen. I've been interested in creating a space that makes possible a sharing moment - a space where transformation happens in the eyes of an audience. 

"Lay still, it's (not) over" could be a celebration about the impermanence of life. A "solo" celebration of being here trapped trying to escape from one’s own "fugue" - trying to escape from an idea that soon everything will vanish with our bodies.

I've been working obsessively with one object (party hats) but I'm not just interested in the object-meaning, but also in is materiality and conic form that resembles an idea of sharpness and openness, as if the little edge would project to the infinity and at the same time and opposite, would reduce it to nothing. I intend to create on stage sculptures that tend to transform themselves in installations that will get inhabit. 

A reflection upon a way society as trying to mirror and reducing an existence to consumption, creating an anxiety of wanting to produce more and more, to be more and more. The media sets up the "perfect" space for images / perspectives to clash, but creates a big gap between bi-dimension/three-dimension images/emotions. The relationship between audience/performer, and in an exhaustive “peeled onion” - public/private, individual/collective, visible/invisible, context/perspective become the core of this work embedded with thoughts and doubts.

Our way of thinking sometimes can be very simple, while our experience is always extremely complex. 


BUSY
... working obsessively with an object
... with transformation
... putting languages together
... with the overload of images
... trying to be in the present
... trying not to do everything at the same time
... trying to share



RAISING THE MONEY!
With your money I will be able to support the research period and the creation of this new piece. I need your private support to help me reach my goals. This means that I need to raise 1.000€ for the whole project.


The funds will be used: 

- for the production of the piece "Lay Still, It's (not) over": 200€
- for materials (props/objects) + costumes + set design: 250€
- for research materials (books, copies, etc.): 150€
- for collaborators: 200€
- for the production of the video: 200€

The amount covers the period of research from July 20 till October 11 + presentation.

Important note about the transfer: don't get shocked if you don't see my name on the paypal account! Because I don't own a credit card I can't verify the paypal account - so I'm using my brother's paypal account!
Don't get confused! It's just about the "logistic".



THE IMPACT
Your contribution will be very important in this critical point of my development as an artist and thinker. I will be very grateful to know that I have private people supporting me and who believe in my work - sharing my own perspective about the world and in a way to explore other possibilities of behave towards the world.

There is also some works on the Gallery Tab above, or you can also find more of my work on my website: www.andreuerba.com

If for any reasons you will not be able to come and see my Performance, I will share some images and a short version of the Piece. The workbook will be available online after October.

During the campaign period I will update the current information and upload new material on the Gallery. I've put details below so you can read more about my work.



ABOUT MY WORK
I consider that my work is always in between visual arts and performing arts, dissolving its borders and regarding the relation with a spectator or an audience. I’ve been focusing my research and interest on moving and still image (bi or three-dimensional image) as most of my projects start with a "mental" image that represents something I observed/experienced in relation to other's body. 

The body in relation with its environment is the main matter. In this way, I use performance to write visual formulae with the body, always looking for a way to elicit emotion - and so my work becomes, in part, an unconditional account of my reactions to death, physicality, sexuality, society, politics, relationships and my own perspective and relation with the world, an inhabiting body living in all these different layers of perception and time in the society context. 

I do not consider my work documentary because I believe that reality is a creation of a collective (and individual) consciousness through sharing and that everyday existence is an illusory veil hiding us from the reality where we truly dwell – the reality as a fiction “stage” – where the spectator is retraced and implied. 

Everything created ("on stage") reflects a personal experience initiated/trigger by other's body. Everything created is, in this way "dedicated" to someone, directed to one single person that did trigger my way of thinking/feeling somehow. I turn than into "just" a channel that makes things flow to the outside world, after the observation and/or trigger takes place.

The "idea" of something used to "decorate" a space (beautify) as been following me for a while, perhaps a counter reaction to the way media mediate images and "messages" nowadays. There is always something hidden behind that "decoration", there is always a life there, always a secret not revealed. I wish to "collect" moments and not objects. 

When I start a project I’m droned by intuition through places without knowing the "terminal" station. So, my concerns while creating are also in a matter related to time and projections. I discover what I want through doing. I call projections to those things that don’t exist in the present but that could exist in the near future – a vehicle to imagination.

In the process of showing something to an audience, the singular word becomes plural, because the audience (singular word) is composed by many individual people.



ABOUT THE MASTER SODA
The MA in Solo/Dance/Authorship (MA SODA) situates itself as a practice-led MA within the histories and contexts of dance, theatre and fine art performance practices. It encourages students to generate and develop forms of individual, solo and collaborative practice that respond to contemporary culture, and its social, political, aesthetic and poetic contexts and implications.

MA-SODA is a two-year full-time modular course. The award of Master of Arts in Solo/Dance/Authorship is validated by the University of the Arts in full time study. 

MA SODA focuses on individual solo and collaborative dance and body-based performance making within the wider field of contemporary arts practice. Taking a practice-led, critical and reflective approach the course concerns itself with making through thinking, and thinking through making in relation to issues of composition, authorship, collaboration, and process. In the plural and crossdisciplinary contexts of contemporary arts practice MA SODA focuses on the development of a student’s own individual performance work as an essentially collaborative and interrogative practice that is in dialogue with other artists, thinkers and practitioners, and that responds to the contexts in which it take place.

MA SODA is designed for students to undertake a sustained and structured development of their methodologies for practice, reflection and study. This should enable students to widen their choice and capacity for professional practice, other employment or higher study; to participate in debates in and around contemporary arts practices and cultural policies; to develop strategies as practitioners in a time of continuing technological, social and cultural change; and develop a valuable ensemble of adaptable and transformable skills at postgraduate level.


HZT Hochschulübergreifendes Zentrum Tanz Berlin
story_txt:
SUPPORT ANDRÉ
WITH IS NEW PIECE "LAY STILL, IT'S (NOT) OVER"I'm a
Performer and Visual Artist from Lisbon, Portugal, currently living/ studying/
working in Berlin, Germany.
I just completed the 1st Semester of a
prestigious Master of Arts program called SODA (Solo/Dance/Authorship) at
UDK-HZT, where I've been busy integrating my previous experience as a visual
artist into a dance/performance context.
During the 1st Semester, I've been receiving loads of input from artists, academics,
and theorists and
I've find myself confronted with many questions surrounding existing notions of
art, issues in-forming the visual and performative body, object,
functionality and the political/economical status (of an artist) in the
nowadays society. The Semester was fulfilled
with lectures and Intensive Workshops from/with:
Boyan Manchev, Helmut Ploebst, Noémie Solomon, Frédéric Neyrat (Theory of Twilight Imagination), Isabel Lang, Helmut Ploebst, Litó Walkey (Writing and Research); Sophia
New (Performative Writing); Eva Meyer Keller (Creating New Work); Constanze
Schellow (The Evil eye of an auditory) and Nik Haffner.

Since July 20, I've been working on "Lay still, it's (not) over" and
now I'm out to you to support me and get me through the next steps to continue
this work. In October I will present "Lay Still, It's (not)
over", in HZT, Uferstudios, Berlin. 
DESCRIBING THE
PROJECT This
project intends to investigate the use of the body in visual writing
formulas, establishing relations to action or suspension, being the main focus
increasingly on the notions of sharing between performer/audience as well
the space created for that (shared) situation to happen. I've been
interested in creating a space that makes possible a sharing moment - a space
where transformation happens in the eyes of an audience. 
"Lay still, it's (not) over" could be a celebration about the
impermanence of life. A "solo" celebration of being here trapped
trying to escape from one’s own "fugue" - trying to escape from an
idea that soon everything will vanish with our bodies. 
I've been working obsessively with one object (party hats) but I'm not just
interested in the object-meaning, but also in is materiality and conic
form that resembles an idea of sharpness and openness, as if the
little edge would project to the infinity and at the same time and
opposite, would reduce it to nothing. I intend to create on stage
sculptures that tend to transform themselves in installations that will get inhabit. 
A reflection upon a way society as trying to mirror and reducing an
existence to consumption, creating an anxiety of wanting to produce more and
more, to be more and more. The media sets up the "perfect" space for
images / perspectives to clash, but creates a big gap between bi-dimension/three-dimension
images/emotions. The relationship between audience/performer, and in an
exhaustive “peeled onion” - public/private, individual/collective, visible/invisible,
context/perspective become the core of this work embedded with
thoughts and doubts.
Our way of thinking sometimes can be very simple, while
our experience is always extremely complex. 
BUSY... working obsessively with an object
... with transformation
... putting languages together
... with the overload of images
... trying to be in the present
... trying not to do everything at the same time
... trying to share


RAISING THE
MONEY!
With your money I will be able to support the research period and the creation
of this new piece. I need your private support to help me reach my
goals. This means that I need to raise 1.000€ for the whole project.

The funds will be used: 
- for the production of the piece "Lay Still, It's (not) over": 200€
- for materials (props/objects) + costumes + set design: 250€
- for research materials (books, copies, etc.): 150€
- for collaborators: 200€
- for the production of the video: 200€
The amount covers the period of research from July 20 till October 11 + presentation.
Important note about the transfer: don't get shocked if you don't see my name on the paypal account! Because I don't own a credit card I can't verify the paypal account - so I'm using my brother's paypal account! Don't get confused! It's just about the "logistic".
THE IMPACTYour
contribution will be very important in this critical point of my development as
an artist and thinker. I will be very grateful to know that I have private
people supporting me and who believe in my work - sharing my own perspective
about the world and in a way to explore other possibilities of behave towards
the world.

There is also some works on the Gallery Tab above, or you can also find
more of my work on my website: www.andreuerba.com

If for any reasons you will not be able to come and see my Performance, I will
share some images and a short version of the Piece. The workbook will be
available online after October.
During the campaign period I will update the current information and upload new
material on the Gallery. I've put details below so you can read more about my
work.
ABOUT MY WORK
I consider that my work is always in between visual arts and performing arts,
dissolving its borders and regarding the relation with a spectator or an
audience. I’ve been focusing my research and interest on moving and still image
(bi or three-dimensional image) as most of my projects start with a
"mental" image that represents something I observed/experienced in
relation to other's body. 
The body in relation with its environment is the main matter. In this
way, I use performance to write visual formulae with the body, always
looking for a way to elicit emotion - and so my work becomes, in part, an
unconditional account of my reactions to death, physicality, sexuality,
society, politics, relationships and my own perspective and relation with the
world, an inhabiting body living in all these different layers of perception
and time in the society context. 
I do not consider my work documentary because I believe that reality is a
creation of a collective (and individual) consciousness through sharing and
that everyday existence is an illusory veil hiding us from the reality where we
truly dwell – the reality as a fiction “stage” – where the spectator is
retraced and implied. 
Everything created ("on stage") reflects a personal experience
initiated/trigger by other's body. Everything created is, in this way
"dedicated" to someone, directed to one single person that did
trigger my way of thinking/feeling somehow. I turn than into "just" a
channel that makes things flow to the outside world, after the observation
and/or trigger takes place.
The
"idea" of something used to "decorate" a space (beautify)
as been following me for a while, perhaps a counter reaction to the way media
mediate images and "messages" nowadays. There is always something
hidden behind that "decoration", there is always a life there, always
a secret not revealed. I wish to "collect" moments and not
objects. 

When I start a project I’m droned by intuition through places without knowing
the "terminal" station. So, my concerns while creating are also in a
matter related to time and projections. I discover what I want through doing. I
call projections to those things that don’t exist in the present but that could
exist in the near future – a vehicle to imagination. 


In the
process of showing something to an audience, the singular word becomes plural,
because the audience (singular word) is composed by many individual people.
ABOUT THE MASTER SODAThe MA in Solo/Dance/Authorship (MA SODA)
situates itself as a practice-led MA within the histories and contexts of
dance, theatre and fine art performance practices. It encourages students to
generate and develop forms of individual, solo and collaborative practice
that respond to contemporary culture, and its social, political, aesthetic
and poetic contexts and implications.
MA-SODA is a two-year full-time modular course. The award of
Master of Arts in Solo/Dance/Authorship is validated by the University of the
Arts in full time study. 
MA SODA focuses on individual solo and
collaborative dance and body-based performance making within the wider
field of contemporary arts practice. Taking a practice-led, critical and
reflective approach the course concerns itself with making through thinking,
and thinking through making in relation to issues of composition,
authorship, collaboration, and process. In the plural and crossdisciplinary
contexts of contemporary arts practice MA SODA focuses on the development of a student’s
own individual performance work as an essentially collaborative and
interrogative practice that is in dialogue with other artists, thinkers
and practitioners, and that responds to the contexts in which it take
place.
MA SODA is designed for students to undertake
a sustained and structured development of their methodologies for
practice, reflection and study. This should enable students to widen their
choice and capacity for professional practice, other employment or higher
study; to participate in debates in and around contemporary arts practices
and cultural policies; to develop strategies as practitioners in a time of
continuing technological, social and cultural change; and develop a valuable
ensemble of adaptable and transformable skills at postgraduate level.HZT Hochschulübergreifendes Zentrum Tanz Berlin

story:
Welcome! My name is Brutus and I am looking to start a “severed head” business. Utilizing my own head, I need to create a high quality mold to cast multiple pulls to use as props (severed heads and masks ), gags (exploding heads) to be used in movies, and novelty items such as lamps, wall sconces, piggy banks, ash trays, and trophies.

My goal is to raise $1500.00 American dollars. This will allow for the production of the number of casts needed to market my various product ideas.

For a donation of $50, you will receive a pull from the mold of the face only – not the full head. This cast will be lightweight, cast of plastic.

For a donation of $100, you will receive a full head - cast of plastic. The cast will be painted a solid color, hollow, and will be lightweight .

For a donation of $200, you will receive a full head - cast of foam or plastic (your choice). The cast will be painted either a solid color or lifelike (your choice) and mounted on a stand… much like a trophy.

Join me in achieving this goal and be one of the first to proudly proclaim: “I HAVE BRUTUS’ SEVERED HEAD”!

What We Need & What You Get

  • The funding will go to the best materials available needed to make a high quality mold and high definition casts.
  • These casts will be the perfect "prank" gag that is of a higher quality and range that will offer a better option to the cheap heads available currently in Halloween stores.
  • If the goal isn't met, the funds will still go to fulfill project - just with a slower rate of completion.

The Impact

  • A higher quality of prop.
  • The application of the Severed Head Project is limited only to the customer's imagination.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this exciting campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Any donation amount will help, and remember:

With your support, we can all "get a head"!

story:
What is "In Their Dotage?" 


"In Their Dotage" is a series of portraits of senior performing arts workers in Nova Scotia. The project consists of two kinds of photos of each artist: a simple portrait and a photo of them working at their craft. 

*The artists I am photographing are not "in their dotage." They are active, working artists. The images aim to disprove the title of the project.  The series acknowledges the value and continuing contributions of working senior artists.

What am I fundraising for?


The series is an ongoing project that began in October 2015, but this campaign will help fund the next few steps of the project: 
  • creating final images of the first wave of artists. (See below for list of confirmed artists)
  • framing/ mounting all of the final image selections.
  • presenting the selections during Halifax's Mayworks Festival 2016. 
  • 20% of the total donations will be given to PAL Halifax, an organization that supports professional arts workers. (Click the link for more info about PAL)


Who am I photographing?

This wave of artists currently include:
  • Mary Lou Martin - Director, choreographer, educator
  • Hugo Dann - Actor, queer rights activist
  • Mary colin Chisholm - Actor, director, playwright
  • Sherry Lee Hunter - Actor, physical theatre perfomer and educator

Where does your donation go?

Every donation, big or small, helps me cover the following expenses:

  • Film Costs  
  • Light Rental 
  • Space Rental
  • Film Developing Chemicals  
  • Printing
  • Mounting/ Framing 
  • Misc. Expenses (gas money, promo materials, snacks for photo sessions, etc.)
  • Project savings for continuing beyond the upcoming presentation for Mayworks
  • 20% of donations will go to PAL Halifax

Why Am I Making These Images?

I want to create compelling images that serve the following purposes:

  • Documentation of our local arts community.
  • Celebrate the work these artists contribute locally and beyond. 
  • By recognizing these artists as active workers, the images challenge the perception that "In Their Dotage" implies. 


Why Should You Donate?

I am very excited to share this work at Mayworks in the spring, and your donations will help make it happen. 

That being said, I also want this project to have a life beyond Mayworks. I want to continue to document our community in this way and to celebrate the many arts workers in this province. This campaign is hopefully just the beginning. 

Need more reasons? Check out the perks on the right >>>


Other Ways You Can Help 

Unable to donate? No problem. You can help a great deal by sharing this campaign on your social media. 
Or, if you know someone who might be interested in supporting this kind of project, send them a link to the campaign.

More About Me and My Photography

You can see some of my photographic work on my website.
www.zachfaye.com

xo 
Zach Faye

story:
Hello, we are a group of dedicated students from the Fine Art undergraduate course at the University of Gloucestershire. We are looking to raise some money for the amazing opportunity to exhibit our degree show in London in the summer of 2016 and we thought we might give crowd funding a shot. We are looking to be a part of the Free Range Show (www.free-range.org.uk). Free Range opens up a fantastic opportunity for emerging artists to showcase their work in the centre of London’s buzzing creative scene. Free Range has a lot of media coverage and exposure in the art industry. In participating in Free Range we also gain exposure through their printed catalogue as well as an online portfolio for each artist, which will be viewed by thousands. Such an amazing opportunity comes at a high price; we just need a little help. There are 20 of us graduating students trying to get our hands on a great street level space, which would allow our year some great exposure and a huge amount of space to display our work. we have been working towards this moment for a long time.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for around £3000 for this project, we know it seems like a lot and we appreciate that entirely. Most of the money will go towards the production of the show, for material costs such as getting work framed, transport, and AV resources, as well as any materials we would need to get the space ready. 
We have already been fundraising by doing bake sales, art sales, helping run events at our university gallery and other crowd funding campaigns. We are planning charity walks and other such events, and we’re trying as hard as we can to get this exhibition up and running! Any bit of help would be greatly appreciated.

The Perks!

All artworks available as prints can be selected as postcard or full prints! Please feel free to message us if you have any questions about availability. Once you've chosen your perk and donated (thank you in advance!), we'll send you a message to  confirm what work you would like and when it will be sent out to you.

Please follow the link below to see what artwork is available.

https://www.behance.net/s13078796023

The Impact
As mentioned before this degree show and the opportunity to exhibit it in London has been something we have dreamed of for years and have been diligently working towards for the last three. Of course if we receive no funding we will still push our hardest to produce the best show we can achieve but with a little bit of help, it will make all the difference.
We appreciate not everyone can help in a major way but even just £1 can make a huge difference if everyone does it. And if you can't help in that way if you could share this project with your friends and family that would also be much appreciated.

story:
Our Story

We are approaching this project in four phases. Extra funds from a phase will be rolled into the next phase.


Phase one: Start CDL training two drivers for the bendy bus. Bacon (Josh) and Sissy B. (Nick P.) are hoping to become the drivers for the bus. With two drivers the bus will hopefully be available more often. 


Phase two: Now that we have drivers in training lets get the bus legit. The Bus will needs to have insurance. It currently has valid plates until January and hopefully the bus will be supporting itself by time that it needs new plates.


Phase three: Time to give the bus some mechanical touch-up. A new windshield wiper motor, oil change, and filter change.


Phase four: The big finish! The final push to add the interior, sound system, and get her party ready! 


The Impact

Phase one will not only help the drivers of the bus not fear the long arm of the law for driving a 50,000 lbs bus with air-brakes without the proper papers but it will open new door for the drivers themselves. 


Sissy B./Nick is currently a straight truck driver for an outdoor company and the addition of a CDL will give him the chance to move up to driving larger trucks. 


What We Need 

Temporary license $65.00 each = $130.00

DOT medical exam 50.00 each = $100.00

CDL instruction $1500.00 each = $3000.00

Road test $220.00 each = $440.00 

IndieGOGO fee at 9% = 330.30

Credit card fees at 3% = 120.01


Total = 4120.31


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the fundraiser

Email bendybusdetroit at Gmail dot com if you have any skills or resources that you would like to donate for the BendyBus

story:
Free Fringe Philly

Last year, we rocked this out and paid out of pocket for the zine and website (huge discount for printing, thank you Fire Ball!) 

This year, we want to cover costs for this year and next so we can keep doing this.

Here is where the money goes:

  • Website (squarespace)
  • Zine (printing)

That is it.

We do everything else on the house. Free. Volunteer. For the common good.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $504 each year. 

$1008 for 2 years (2020 and 2021).

We won't have to pay out of pocket for the zine and the site.

You get the gaggle of clowns rallying the crowds to put on Free Fringe.

And also, you get an inspired community spirit and more of a chance for individual artists and ensembles to make and create art with very little barrier of entry.

We all get to participate.

Not just a select few who are curated or with the right amount of money.

The Impact

Last year, our first year, we had hundreds performances. Theater artists, comics, storytellers, dancers, performance artists told us WE WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN ABLE TO DO THIS WITHOUT FREE FRINGE.

Why? Because the cost to produce a show is HIGH. It's even HIGHER if you apply to some of the festivals that require fees, insurances, take a cut of your tickets and compete with your show with mega giant curated shows. Then you have to cover all your promotion costs, etc. This can make things tough. 

Free Fringe rally's the crowds and spaces to get folks to donate their venues and services free of charge, to help make Fringe ACCESSIBLE to more individuals. We have a force of volunteers who media boost before and during the festival. We have dozens of business owners offering their space to artists. And all shows are 100% free to attend. Our artists are encouraged to pass a hat after their show and guess what? THEY MAKE MONEY.  WHOOT.

  • We do all this for free.
  • We have lists of free resources on our site, volunteers and spaces that are available.
  • We are not curating anyone or anything. We are making more resources available for YOU.

The main thing we want to say is that we are NOT in this for the money. We are in it for the glory.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about Free Fringe!
  • Share this campaign!
  • Our festival starts Sept 10th, Go see shows! They are freeeeee!

And that's all there is to it.

The main thing we want to say is that we are NOT in this for the money. We are in it for the glory.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about Free Fringe!
Share this campaign!
Our festival starts Sept 10th, Go see shows! They are freeeeee!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
21 Stops : ni de aquí, ni de allá : neither here nor there

A collection of 21 written works exploring migration, movement, and the “in-between”

For the last several months I have focused my work as an artist and writer on transit, migration, and the relationship between private and public, personal identity and collective identity. In order to do this, I positioned my “studio” on buses, trains, and at Union Station in Downtown Los Angeles, spending many, many hours working directly in, with, and alongside public space, people, and things— drawing out information, making observations, encountering stories, learning about the spaces we share… and ultimately learning an incredible amount about “us”, myself, and where we might be going together. This work continues and I am completely humbled by it everyday…

As a part of this long-term project, I am pulling together a collection of written work that reflects these themes, combining unique voices, styles, and vantage points—in order to construct a dynamic portrait of the many ways we enter a conversation about belonging, place, and community. For the first edition of this collection, the Metro Goldline will be the focus of a “zine in migration”.

The Metro Goldline train route stretches from the most Eastern end of East Los Angeles, through Boyle Heights, Downtown L.A., Chinatown, North East L.A., Pasadena, and finally into Sierra Madre. For me, this route has come to mean many things as my daily migrations to and from school and work encounter countless other daily migration stories, the likes of which weave together to create an ever changing collective narrative, composed of infinite personal histories, contrasting social realities, told through the unpredictability of people in movement.

21 writers were invited to contribute to this edition of the zine, representing the 21 stops along the Metro Goldline route. I will be appropriating the design and form of the Metro Goldline train schedule and the zines will be available in the schedule holders on Goldline trains, in both Spanish and English, camouflaged among the actual train schedules. This unexpected surprise for the traveller aligns with a commitment to distribute “art” in our everyday shared spaces: nearly invisibly, gently, and very generously… challenging the idea that “art space” is separate from our lived or public space by integrating our cultural work covertly within public structures. Through this form of publication, art becomes a gift through a generous, loving act of resistance.

This is just the beginning! The vision for this work continues as plans are made for additional editions of the zine, travelling along public transit routes throughout Los Angeles. I sincerely hope you will consider supporting this project with a donation. Your contribution will help carve out space for the telling of these important stories and the cultivation of community through cultural work.

With love and gratitude,

Kristy Lovich

story:
Funds are requested to support Miami Photo Salon, a week-long International Photo Festival that will promote interaction among different communities within Miami Dade County, encourage the participation of the general public in a fine art venue, and empower emerging artists by providing local talent with the exposure they need to advance their careers. This event will be held at the Wolfson Audiorium/Kaplan Hall of the Temple Israel in downtown Miami during the week of Art Basel,  in the heart of the activity generated by visiting international art fairs.  This location will provide unprecedented visibility for artists who may be exhibiting work for the first time or who have no previous exhibition history in the US. This project promotes interaction among diverse communities across South Florida, and  and uncover exhibition opportunities within the US and internationally.

 
MPSF supports local emerging artists by providing international exposure and the opportunity to have their work seen at a time when Miami is hosting the most important international art event in the world. These artist’s careers will also benefit from exhibiting their work alongside the work of recognized international artists.  Because the event will be so highly visible due to its venue and timing, our selection committee will be adhering to the highest curatorial standards when selecting work for this exhibit.
 
Miami Photo Salon encourages the participation of the general public, and encourages local artists to submit work even if they’ve never exhibited before.  By providing a yearly opportunity for local artists to exhibit work to a global public, the discipline of photography will be elevated and strengthened in Miami, reaching the level of excellence and visibility that Miami’s visual art community has achieved.

 Cuban American Phototheque Foundation's production of the Festival will promote itself to a vast international audience by producing this Salon, and  will be providing materials that will direct visitors to our location in the budding Bird Road Art District as well as to our web site.  Our display of published material is also an additional way to expose the work of artists who have previously exhibited work at the Phototeque, so that the organization is leveraging the careers of our exhibiting artists on a continuous basis.

story:
In the Footsteps of Turner


My name is Andy Parker and I have been working professionally as a self-employed artist for over ten years. Mainly, I consider myself a landscape painter, although that can stretch to cover quite a wide area these days - but generally it requires me traveling to paint and draw outdoors, around the country and further afield.

JMW Turner's series of paintings known as the Ports and Harbours of England, and the resultant prints, did more to establish his name in the minds of the general public than anything he'd painted previously and provide an indelible snapshot of the people, ports and places he visited.

My project, In the Footsteps of Turner, will be to follow behind to see what remains, what has changed and what has stayed the same in the two centuries since Turner set out - inspired by the painting and drawings of Turner's trip. 

The project is important to me for several reasons - principally, I believe that it is time for us to look at Turner's legacy and influence once again. Art schools and critics have praised him and then dismissed him, as fashions change, yet he remains one of the country's greatest painters.

From his earliest work, producing scenic landmarks for replication by engravers, through the majestic seas and skies he painted as he traveled, to the epic and dynamic, abstract later works - Turner's pictures have provided artists from all areas with continued inspiration, myself included.

In addition, as well as both working extensively outdoors we also share a common birthplace in London's Covent Garden - having been exposed to his work locally from my earliest times, this project finally allows me to properly acknowledge that formative influence.

Brighton Storm (16x20") Oil on Canvas

It's quite an epic journey. Most of my regular painting involves riding from London and then painting in one place, for a week or two. In the Footsteps of Turner requires a much more systematic approach, where I travel to each area chronologically - starting in Yorkshire and working around the coastline in a clockwise direction, to finish in Falmouth, Cornwall. 

I estimate that it will be well over 1000 miles of road from start to finish. The 15 locations I will visit should provide me with at least 30 paintings on canvas, as well as a number of painted works on panel and drawings.

Posting updates and video clips as I travel, will allow people to follow my progress and experience the locations as I visit.


Harbour Fog - Hastings (6x8") Oil on panel

The sum I am asking for is £10k in total. This will allow me to undertake the trip in the most compact manner - in can't cover every expense that can occur, but it will allow me to sleep indoors at night, work outdoors in all weathers in clothing that doesn't leak, maintain my vehicle and cover my living expenses while I am on the road - with the security of some contingency, should the unexpected happen. Vehicle maintenance becomes especially important when traveling this way, unlike my normal shorter, point-to-point painting trips.


The budget will also allow me buy a camera and laptop, to upload video images as I travel. These will be posted on a dedicated website and will go to producing a short DVD of the trip once the dust has settled. I will also be able to engage an assistant with marketing experience, to help me co-ordinate these activities.

After the road trip is finished, following a short break, the studio work begins. This is  where I can complete the initial paintings, and then assess and produce further work from studies made on the road. It will also allow me to start on the framing and mounting of works for the exhibition, cover the hiring of a suitable venue and the marketing and presentation of the show.


Rock Hopping - Etretat (6x8") Oil on panel

The Exhibition will be where people can finally get to see what I have achieved! Contributors, of course, will already have some idea of how its all been going by the regular updates and mail-outs sent out to record my progress..

As well as keeping you informed about my progress, all Contributors will receive a personal thank-you letter from me and an invite to the Private View of the Exhibition in London.

As a reward for supporting my efforts financially, Contributors will also be able to have some excellent perks to choose from: including specially-created limited edition wood-cut prints, drawings and paintings, both panels sketches and larger works - these latter ones can be chosen after the trip is completed or from my existing landscape and seascape paintings, should you not want to wait that long!

Should the appeal not reach its full target, then the project will start with the money raised so far, if it exceeds £2000 - this will allow me to get underway on the road, but will mean that I have to work more piecemeal on location, over a longer period,  and it will delay the final phase of framing, marketing and exhibiting until finances permit.

In The Footsteps of Turner is an important project for me and it will happen. Your generosity will allow me to stay focused and bring all it about within a practical timeframe.

Duck Day Afternoon - London (6x8") Oil on board

JMW Turner set out to depict his life and times and I hope to do the same. By contributing to my trip, your help will enable me to create a lasting body of work and show others how the influence of this great artist has echoed down the centuries.

All the locations he visited are still ports and harbours, but fortunes turn like the tides and I want to encourage people to remember just how influential and important their maritime heritage is - the power of this country was established by its maritime trade.

Turner's views were painted looking back towards the shore - this often being the first, and sometimes last, sight of land for the people on ships - and as much as anything the paintings concern the weather and the skies, the drama and the light, as they do the actual ports. I want  to see the world that Turner saw and discover the similarities that still exist since his day and to provide my contemporary contribution to maritime art, inspired by him.

My intention is to create this body of work as a contemporary update to the original series. By doing so, In The Footsteps of Turner will not only raise my profile and provide me with a new audience, but help to keep the work of England's greatest painter in the public consciousness, where it rightly belongs...

Limehouse Dawn - London (10x12") Oil on canvas

Although I intend to produce 30 finished paintings within a relatively short time, I am used to working fast outdoors - this is necessitated by the changing light and weather conditions - so I make studies and sketches quickly, to capture the moods and moments, as well as painting directly onto canvas. I paint using both canvas-and-easel and wood panel, with a pochade box, so can always produce work in the most inclement conditions!

My day starts at 5am and continues until it is dark again - this is why I won't start the actual trip until Spring 2015 to give me the fairest weather and the ability to start early on location.

Although this trip is more ambitious in scope than anything I have previously undertaken, after surviving for over ten years as a self-employed artist I have extensive experience of managing and finishing my projects - an unfinished project represents future unemployment!

The biggest challenges for a project like In the Footsteps of Turner are the weather and the light - the Spring produces clear blue skies, the trees starting to show blossom and the early hints of the summer to come. However, it can also give us leaden, flat grey skies for weeks on end, where there is little to inspire and tickle the senses of outdoor painters. In my experience though, the weather is usually quick to change when painting by the coast so I don't expect to be confined by it for long. Better the drama of a crashing storm, than grey predictability...

Other than that, my main obstacles will be mechanical reliability and concentration, keeping the tiredness at bay when I'm  hauling  the bike around the roads continuously for weeks on end!

Sleeping River - London (10x12") Oil on canvas


I hope that, as a Contributor you will feel a sense of accomplishment in supporting art, both my own as a working painter and, by association, the work of an  established master like JMW Turner, in whose steps I am treading.

If you would like to help but are unable to contribute, do pass on details to your friends or anyone else that you might think would be interested.

The Indiegogo share tools are nearby, so please feel free to post, re-post, tweet and transmit any of the information here, the better to inform the world.

Drop me a line by email (turnersfootsteps@gmail.com) and I'll send you an invite to the exhibition, by way of thanks!


(Check out http://cnn.it/1mdXWCM for some of the press interest that my initial proposal outline has generated)
